snippet.textDisplay:
I made a comment response video: https://youtu.be/rR-a3zIOE2w

Apparently the ps3 and xbox360 versions of Scholar did not change the enemy placement, so this video doesn't apply to those versions.

2 things to correct in the video:
1: Scholar did not get rid of the 1 million souls skip to get to Drangleic Castle. I thought that I had heard this from another Dark Souls 2 video essay, but I was wrong.
2: The dragon skeleton in Aldia's Keep can come alive in Scholar, but you have to light some torches so it's hidden away and I still prefer how Vanilla handled it to Scholar.

Also, the comments have told me that Shrine of Amana was nerfed into the ground after release, so that's probably part of the reason why I liked it in Vanilla while other people hated it.

I finally decided to make the "In Defense of Dark Souls 2 video" unlisted because it had too many mistakes. You can still watch it with this link.
https://youtu.be/2A6s_Wq-6PU

Great video! It’s such a travesty that SotFS is the version available on modern consoles and is positioned as the “definitive version” when it clearly is not.

Side note: it’s this video that actually inspired me to play DS2 on Steam instead of PS5/4, considering the latter is where most of my souls games are (and I am completing all of them for the first time in order as my first souls experience). Honestly even Vanilla was still a slog but nothing compared to the unlubed ass raping Scholar would have been…so in short THANK YOU for this detailed comparison. You might have saved my life.

snippet.textDisplay:
I just finished ds2 scholar of the first sin and it's my 2nd soulsborne game from DS1 which I absolutely loved and found no negatives for it whatsoever (maybe very tedious stuff but overall the game mechanics, level design, difficulty curve and enemies felt justified) 

ds2 however felt like an uphill battle from the getgo. forest of the fallen giants was an absolute piece of garbage considering your low level and just the sheer number of enemies you have to fight simultaneously, then followed by with no mans wharf which is just a genuine piece of garbage where the enemies aggro radius is absolutely fucking ridiculous and you just provoke the entire area to fight the flexile sentry or whatever 
but when I got to iron keep. I noticed that genuinely, the game is designed to be hard and absolutely unbelievable. I didn't run past all the enemies and played the game like it was originally designed to ; not running past, killing all enemies I see, exploring etc. 
this approach made me improve overall and yes the game was difficult, let alone the dubious features of ds2 which are infuriating. but it's like a guilty pleasure. for ds2 there's no in between; you absolutely hate the game or absolutely love it. I was on the latter end and found the game really good. 
One key concept that made love the game was just avoiding any opinion or critics on the game WHILST PLAYING which can negatively impact you mentally when going through the game. I played it blindly whilst only knowing initial impressions that ds2 was harder compared to DS1. and that's it. I knew the game received negativity mainly from the community so I didn't want that to impact how I experienced the game. and I didn't even know there was a vanilla version. I thought scholar of the first sin was the same game and they just slapped on the dlc with it. I went through shrine of amana actually happy with the overall design. it felt new, refreshing and like they changed their approach to their design. also with iron keep where I ended up despawning all the enemies including archers before killing the smelter demon. 
the game's bad features, in a way, is what makes the game good and ill always have a soft spot for it.

snippet.textDisplay: Damn bro. You know, I played vanilla ds2 back when it first released. Then, recently, I go and pick up Scholar of the first sin. I guess in the 10 years or so I had forgotten quite a lot about what the first version of ds2 was like. But after watching this video, it finally explained this nagging feeling I've been having about sotfs the whole time I played it. Like I wasnt having any fun, despite the fact I recalled having played the original and could vaguely recall the feeling that I actually enjoyed playing the game. It makes so much sense now, sotfs ruined ds2. What's even worse is now I kind of wanna play the original version, except i dont have a ps3 anymore and I'm not about to spend 40$ to buy it on pc when I already own the ps3 version and sotfs for ps4 😂. Here's hoping if we ever get a ds2 remake, it's just a finished version of the original and not this "definitive" bs. Anyways thanks for the video, very entertaining and I feel like your script writing was even better in this one than your sotfs video.

snippet.textDisplay:
Having played both a huge amount over the years I hope to see more players discover vanilla and give it a shot. Like every other souls game both versions of dark souls 2 are hideously flawed in their own ways, with some overlap in design problems. But the changes that scholar made to the game so often can only be interpreted as 'this has been done for the sake of pissing the player off'. Enemy placement and variety is so important to the game, especially during areas that the player will have to traverse many times, many of scholar's enemy changes don't add difficulty to the game in a meaningful way - the area isn't harder to get through a first time, but it IS hideously boring to retread that area when the placement of the mobs does things like prevent the player from accessing a trader or a bonfire EVERY time they have to visit a location.

 Similarly, many of the key item changes and in particular the Fragrant Branch redesign didn't lead to a single positive change to the game's pacing or perception - shutting out a huge portion of the tutorial, adding many statues in shaded woods that are often block opposite ends of the SAME path, locking some key items behind randomly placed statues spread throughout the world when branches are significantly harder to acquire now and vastly easier to 'waste' on a useless statue. There are things to admire in both versions of the game, but the technical improvements don't factor into Scholar for me - it's not like dark souls 1 where dsfix was mandatory for the game to be actually playable. Dark Souls 2 was playable and functional, and judging both versions of the game on their own merits, scholar feels like a version that lacks replayability and leaves a poorer taste in the player's mouth. Due to the excessively tedious and repetitious segments and areas of the game, combined with lazier enemy placement and the lessening of player choice in terms of routes they have to progress the game early due to arbitrary statue placements I hope to see more players visit vanilla in the future. It gives the player a much more memorable and complete experience, however much like the undertone of dark souls 2's story, the memory too has been eroded by time

snippet.textDisplay:
I played Demon Souls, Dark Souls and Dark Souls 2 in the released state. Yes they are hard but that's to expect with these tittles, you need to be mechanically skilled and strategic in every oppenent. There is a fulfillment that time and bragging rights to your friends.

But when Dark Souls 3 came out I've only played probably the first 30 mins of that game, everything seems to be so easy as you can do multi rolls and very predictable enemies.

What I'm trying to point out is Dark Souls series now is meant for casual gamers and not for the "Git Gud" players. Players just whine about how hard the game forcing devs to adjust to their level of skills instead of sucking it up and figuring out a strategy to beat every challenge.

snippet.textDisplay:
it's a funny thing: now I see that this video is a masterclass in cherrypicking, BUT I am still thankful for it, sincerely! 
if it hadn't pushed this distorted picture, I'd have never played ds2 at all (given all the negative reviews it gets from ds3 lovers). 
the fact that you made this (albeit spurious) argument actually made me play ds2 vanilla and enjoy it (i find coming into these games the frame of mind is the most important). 
now, after having finished both scholar and vanilla 3+ times, I can honestly say that scholar is easier, LESS ganky, and overall makes the most sense. 
Who said that lies, manipulations and shoddy research are useless??

snippet.textDisplay:
I no lifed DS, so when DS2 came out, I was stoked. Ran out to family video and rented it for 2 days. I was determined to beat it before my rental expired, and I did exactly that. At 23 hours and 25 minutes of game time, I finished Vanilla Dark Souls 2. I didn't even have internet on my xbox 360, so no patches. I explored every inch of it in that time, and honestly? I was pissed. I obviously missed something. So i saved up and bought a copy. Bought the dlcs one by one and downloaded them on a hard drive at my buddies place. I put at least over 1000+ hours into vanilla DS2 with dlc. Right before DS3 came out, I picked up SOTFS edition, and after hearing about how much better it was online, I prepared to play DS2 again. It was amazing being able to play the same game in a completely new light. Being able to again experience the journey of not knowing what was around every corner, where enemies were, or what items would be there. But that quickly wore off for me after my 10th gank death. Mind you, I completed the vanilla with no death, no bonfire, deprived builds with no leveling. And SOTFS feels unfair, everything about it from enemy placement to the FBOY artificial hurdles. SOTFS was made specifically to challenge veterans of vanilla to purposefully go "oh you thought that you would go get the blue sentinels covenant for his miracles early? Screw you have a bunch of heide knights and a bloody dragon. " it is the definition of what I would call artificial difficulty. The whole point of the almost 2x enemy spawns is to make you spend more time slogging through it, thus soft locking you until you either A. Kill all enemies in an area, at which point your healing items are gone, and weapons are broken. Or B. Learn the new enemy layout and just fucking run through everything. I hate playstyle B as it literally gives the player incentive to ignore entire parts of the game. In addition SOTFS enemy ganks lose a core experience of dark souls as a whole, which is the feeling of equal fights. Not of the battles themselves being equal, no but of the very concept that skillful play, good equipment, and accurate foresight can win you the day. In any of the souls games you can slowly approach every room, area, dungeon, boss or hazard and overcome it without feeling cheated when you die. Most of the deaths in DS and DS3 feel fair, oh I was poisoned, oh I was bled to death, dang that guys grapple was brutal and got me. But rarely do they feel like "why the f*** are there 6 enemies in this small room that all have huge poise damage attacks that are incredibly large sweeps!?" It feels cheap, and SOTFS has so many of these moments. It feels like a slog in almost every area to kill all the enemies, and rarely feels worth it. Vanilla ds2 will always hold a special place in my heart and SOTFS while refreshing as a sort of NewNew Game Plus, is genuinely far worse than the vanilla experience.
10/10 video

snippet.textDisplay:
It will never stop pissing me off that people play SotFS first. Its just NOT made to be your first experience with the game 😭

Also, 20:42 that is EXACTLY me. When I was first playing dark souls 1 I had a friend who was really into watching speedrunners and challenge runners. He gave me a lot of tips and tricks and the biggest one that he gave me was that you can roll however you want if you don't lock on. This also let you angle your attacks differently depending on the swing of your weapon which could let you hit multiple enemies that would otherwise need worse positioning to do so, or swing with different timing to hit the enemy at the perfect moment to let you roll before their counterattack. Dark souls 2 felt like the natural progression for players like me. I was so frustrated at people complaining about group fights in dark souls 2, i just wanted to shake them and yell "DON'T LOCK ON! THAT'S ALL YOU NEED TO DO!"

snippet.textDisplay: DARK SOULS 2 IS A SLOW PACED GAME. YOU HAVE TO MOVE SLOWLY. i am bored watching people with no skill talking about difficulty. dark souls 2 is a pretty easy game , shrine oof amana is extremely easy and it teaches you to play with ranged attacks. You cannot expect it to be easy, if you are new to the game play with friends or summon, YOU ARE NOT A NOOB IF YOU SUMMON, you just want to have fun. people will go around talking about the gangs and the copy paced enemies , but they forget that its a 2011 game , also they forget that many areas and mechanics were first time around , so i get some problems, but for gods sake, that game is one of the best souls game out there , yes it might not be dark souls 3 but its a fantastic game and its really fun too. I just replayed it and it was so easy , i first timed all bosses and i never had to play an area more than 3 times . So yes gangs might be annoying but you have to thing that many areas are castles or ports where there is many enemies, it makes sense having many enemies, but enemies have very low health , so its pretty easy. if you play correctly you are a good level and 2-3 hit every enemy. So get good and stop crying about many enemies, elden ring did the same thing and no one is talking about it .

snippet.textDisplay:
I saw the tone change and other things that turned me off to DS2 when I decided to test it out, I got Scholar's. I had no idea how many enemies they had added. I was like
Damn, shoulda played the first one. It takes FOREVER to clear areas. And I specifically used a repair build in order to have a weapon half the time. Lv 1 run was the easiest and by far, the longest. Bosses were a joke. I think the mirror night was the only one I struggled on? Most of them I 1 shotted. Now that we have a reference, DS2 difficulty matches that of Failguard but instead of “give the enemy way more hp”
It was drop 2-3x times the enemy, that just compounded the weapon degradation problem.

I'm a recent convert to the school of "Dark Souls 2 is a good game." I still think it is an imitation of Dark Souls that kind of misses the point in many respects, but I also can't stop playing it. From what I've seen so far it looks like Scholar makes a lot of minor changes that add nothing to the game.

One of the features that I really like is that if you kill the same enemies enough times they don't respawn anymore. It helps with those gauntlet boss runbacks and reinforces the idea that you're supposed to fight the enemies and not avoid them.

snippet.textDisplay:
I recently did a DS2 run to get the vanquisher Seal super early in the game (80k soul memory) and was like "Huh, this game ain't as complete dogshit as I remember, maybe I was just being a contrarian hater".
Then I booted up scholar, since it's the version my friends have, and I figured I'd get a grip on it to be able to carry during our co-op run.
It was hands down the most intense downgrade I've ever felt. The enemy placement and level design in general is the most juvenile "haha gOTtem haha LOL GOTtem ha hyuGh".
Honestly nothing but contempt for Scholar. Genuinely the only positive change I've felt is that you can now confidently farm your bling thanks to the CoC, but it is a truly horrendous experience. I'm convinced that if someone claims Scholar is the best souls game, they are straight up rage baiting. 

Anyway, cool video, I don't think there were any points I violently disagreed with and I even figured out why I sometimes get the itch to replay this doo doo ass game (locked off combat is pretty cool) with the boys.

If only I saw it on release xddd

snippet.textDisplay:
I knew scholar and the original had differences but I did not know it was this drastic, always thought the abundance of enemies, with the ability to see you through walls/across the world and then them ganking you every second when you think your safe was just the entire dark souls 2 experience. No wonder me and my friend were able to make it to the dragon rider boss fight as 10 or 9 years old (our first Souls game btw) and my friend defeating him by the boss falling off and dying since the boss is great at doing that on the original version meanwhile me 20 years old is struggling even using the overpowered rapier to go through that entire area on scholar, among other stuff 

I honestly now don’t feel bad spamming the bow or getting a 10+ greatsword and high level slightly early (although both versions let you do that very easily) but unfortunately I’m too deep into scholar to restart on the original and there’s paying a quite a bit of money for it on steam of course so I might as well beat it to the end :/

snippet.textDisplay: Scholar of the first sin was my first dark souls, I loved it and dumped hundreds of hours into multiple playthroughs and PvP fight clubs. You can imagine my surprise when this game I have lots of fond memories of, is driving me absolutely fucking insane. Maybe it’s because I’ve gotten a taste of the better or just the straight up good souls games like dark souls three and lots of Elden ring but something is not adding up this game is driving me up the fucking walls and I just don’t understand why I didn’t see any of thatyears ago when I loved it

snippet.textDisplay: Super late into the discussion here, but I played vanilla on release, for those wondering about Shrine Of Amana or whatever, before the nerf, it wasn't as bad as Scholar but it was hard. Basically the nerf toned down the mages in the area, not the amount but their magic. They used to fire their spells faster and more often and the main change was that they were less homing after the nerf. Pre-nerf the projectiles basically had infinite range and would chase the player in a full circle for a few seconds if you tried to run from them, it was basically homing magic spell hell for all directions constantly while fighting the melee enemies, like STRONG homing. Again not impossible by any means but the boss run back was really annoying on NG+ and beyond, especially in human form for full HP with the invasions and extra enemies of NG in DS2.

snippet.textDisplay: Wow. You could have just tweeted "Scholar has too many gank squads" and saved me 40 minutes. I understand the frustration, and while the increased enemies is actually what made me enjoy scholar more than any other souls game, there are some unfair moments, that's something I won't deny. However, if u take your time thru each level, you'll end up farming a plethora of souls. And if an area is too hard, just chisel away at it until the enemies despawn. Then u have a peaceful run to the boss AND a couple levels. We don't have to agree about scholar being a masterpiece, but I think we can all agree that this guy's video could've been a tiktok...

snippet.textDisplay: The problem is you play like shit. Only frigid outskirts is worth of criticism. You run around aggroing all enemies and then let yourself get surrounded. I kinda feel like an insane person watching this video. Dark souls 2 SOTFS was the first dark souls experience I had when I was a kid and recently it turned out to be the first dark souls I ever finished. So I played the entirety of the game having no idea that I was playing basically a obnoxiously hardcore version of the original game. I simply got used to the stone statues, the hidden archers, the constant gank fights and learned to abuse every drop of exploit out of the game, thinking that was the genuine dark souls experience. And as hard (and apparently unfair) as it was, I really fucking liked it. Honestly I don't even feel like playing vanilla DS 2 coz it would probably be frustratingly easy after all I've been through

snippet.textDisplay: Theres more to it than just enemy placement. The small changes Scholar makes does a great job at making the game seem significantly smaller than it felt in vanilla. Branches of yore blocking progression making the game more linear massively impacts the feel of the game when you replay it. Vanilla was extremely non linear in its progression compared to SOTFS literally just because of these statues being everywhere. Or vengarl, in SOTFS, you find his head, talk to him, then find his body later on in the area. Mid game weapons just in the middle of a beginning area. In vanilla, you have to progress all the way to Freja to find his body. This makes the quest feel a lot larger, the placement feels more enigmatic and interesting, and its more of a satisfying climactic ending to the quest rather than making it all happen within 1 area. Another example, in Vanilla the Bastille key is unlocked by defeating the gargoyles. So you have to do a bit of extra progression if you want to make the Last Sinner easier, rather than in SOTFS its just sitting right after you beat the ruin sentinels. This again made the area feel larger and the original, it gave more reward for exploring side areas. Or another, when you find McDuff in the Lost Bastille in SOTFS you get his ember right after the persuer, again reducing a NPC quest to just one area. In the original, you dont get the ember to unlock him until Iron keep, this is once feels more rewarding once you finally find his ember, it makes his quest feel larger, it changes the progression of the entire game not being able to get certain upgrades until iron keep. All of these changes might seem silly and pedantic, and they were all added in the name of "QOL", but in reality all of these in combination with each other change the entire feel of the game, it makes it more theme parkey, on the rails, and linear, as oppposed to vanilla which feels much more open , non linear and larger. It's hard to explain, but if you have played through both games you will understand.

snippet.textDisplay:
Interesting take. Personally I think you're incorrect with your take and over dramatizing the issues. DS2 SotFS was my first souls experience and I have zero reference as to what the games were. I made it through just fine and enjoyed it so much that it started me on my dark souls journey.

Honestly the only enemy I actually have an issue with are the jihad jimmies because they broke my gear and rings (especially my delicate rings). Every other enemy was a simple or less simple puzzle to solve. I don't mind swapping weapons and spells to adapt so I never felt forced to use a playstyle I didn't enjoy, plus I was good enough at the game to simply not get progress locked because of my setup. I was either able to overcome it without too much issue, or I was happy to adapt.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: 6:21 I played DS2 before (Scholar version) and I got to the first area only for those 20 enemies to be sleeping. This allowed me to fight each enemy one at a time. The only way all those enemies could ambush you at once is if you actively decided to wake all of them up and agro them all at once. I played all the souls games and I don't remember a single game that rewarded blindly running past every obstacle. Also, the Heide Knights in Heide's Tower of Flame as shown in the video are also all sleeping and optional to fight. The only 2 ways to wake them are to either attack them yourself or kill The Dragonrider boss in the same area, but by then you'll already be at the next location.

snippet.textDisplay: I will say, DS1 endgame gets such a bad rep. The Archives is well designed. New Londo Ruins both flooded and unflooded are solid. Super fun mechanics, fun to explore, etc. The Catacombs is also great if you didn't do it early game. The actual bad areas are Demon Ruins to Lost Izalith, Tomb of the Giants, and the Crystal Caves. About half of the ending is bad.

snippet.textDisplay: Honestly I’m playing DS2 SOTFS right now after having finished DS1. I genuinely don’t understand what you’re on about. Maybe it’s because you’re running past all the enemies but I just kill them get a shit ton of exp and level my character. Bosses are an absolute joke so far and what you were describing about No Mans Wharf makes no sense. Im literally almost  done with that area with the only death being my dumbass attempting to parkour cause I thought there was a secret behind and area that looked reachable via a jump. Maybe my mind will change after reaching Iron Keep but so far I think it’s a good game. Not great and DS1 absolutely crushed it in terms of gameplay but it’s got some nice ideas like bonfires restoring your weapons and what not that DS1 DESPERATELY needed. I cannot explain the utter horror I felt when I got to the bottom of Blighttown and my weapon had broken. I didn’t know about the Repair Box at that point. Sheesh what a nightmare that was. As for stuff like Hyde Knights and what not, what are you talking about? I killed those guys so easily I decided to farm them out of existence for the free souls. Literally just stab stab dodge repeat till dead. Idk I feel your pain points with this game all have to do with running past everything instead of just getting better and actually learning to play the game.

snippet.textDisplay: DS2 isn't the best soul game and it has many flaws but Vanilla in no world is better than Sotfs. Vanilla is stupidly easy and the so-called "peaks of difficulty" do not exist since ds2 has a tendency to give you the best weapons/magic/heals at the beginning of the playthrough while having the most friendly soul-level requirements in the series. Another thing, the problem isn't that they gank you a lot, is that enemies don't stagger. In DS3 you get ganked 90% of the time yet you don't feel it since enemies get staggered by the wettest napkin possible. Also playing a first-time playthrough will always be harder than a second playthrough, I find it unnecessary to even bring that out.
snippet.textOriginal: DS2 isn't the best soul game and it has many flaws but Vanilla in no world is better than Sotfs. Vanilla is stupidly easy and the so-called "peaks of difficulty" do not exist since ds2 has a tendency to give you the best weapons/magic/heals at the beginning of the playthrough while having the most friendly soul-level requirements in the series. Another thing, the problem isn't that they gank you a lot, is that enemies don't stagger. In DS3 you get ganked 90% of the time yet you don't feel it since enemies get staggered by the wettest napkin possible. Also playing a first-time playthrough will always be harder than a second playthrough, I find it unnecessary to even bring that out.

snippet.textDisplay:
I recently played all of souls games through after buying a ps3 for nostalgia reasons and it came with a copy of demons souls. I played them all in order of release (bar bloodborne but I’ve literally just ordered a ps4 so I can play it)  and I can safely say I will happily play every single one of them again bar DS2. The entire experience felt so disconnected from what made all of the other games feel so special. The level design just feels off, everything looks like a cheap imitation and washed out. Movement feels sluggish and unresponsive even compared to OG demons souls. I don’t even need to mention the hit boxes or the ADP stat. People say it’s the best for clothing and weapon variety but none of the clothing looks any good imo and the weapons are quantity over quality defined. What was most disappointing was the boss fights, all SUPER easy which makes the terrible boss runs seem even more cheap. It’s like they didn’t know how to make challenging enemies so they just cheap out and put gank mobs in to ensure they kept the “dARksOuLs iS HaRD” moniker going. 

TLDR, DS2 is a badly made game, fight me.

snippet.textDisplay:
I love DS2, played it for more than 800 hours. No souls game is perfect, and neither is ds2, but people love to eat up whatever Miyazaki makes and shit on everything else just for the fun of it. Imo SoTFS is the inferior copy of ds2, sold with the promise of Miyazaki fixing the game, what a joke. I think I played SoTFS a total of 5 hours before dropping it.
Vendrick is easy because it's an emotional fight, akin to the last fight in ds1.
The ancient dragon fight is bad, the run to it (as many others in the game) can be made easier by using the mechanic in the game where killed enemies don't respawn after a certain amount of deaths. So you can farm the enemies from the bonfire to the boss, get stronger, and just walk up to the boss for the fight.

snippet.textDisplay:
I just completed my first playthrough of DS2, after being a frequent DS3 player for years. I played Scholar, and I do share a lot of your opinions (especially about those stupid statues), but I rarely felt the urge to run past the enemies on an area. Maybe it´s due to my patient nature, but I actually enjoyed coming up with strategies to beat the various ganks. I agree that there are too many ganks, but a lot of them can be avoided by taking it slow. Sure, Shrine of Amana was BS, but it never felt impossible to beat. 
My main critique is that for the most part it wasn´t explained really well why I am doing stuff. In DS3 most Bosses made sence and I knew why I was fighting them. In DS2 I felt like they just needed more Bosses, and just put random guys in armor and gave them a big health bar. I wasn´t excited to learn what Boss I´m gonna face after ne next fogwall. My fist DS1 playthrough (which i only did days before my DS2 playthrough) felt way more exciting, because (most) Bosses felt unique and had a learning proccess. DS2 was just running to the right until the Boss swings.
But overall DS2 (even Scholar) is fine. To me still the weakest of the trilogy, but not bad. I enjoyed it for the most part. I even liked Iron Keep, I was just very let down by Old Iron King. Smelter Demon is cool tho

snippet.textDisplay:
I’m one of the few who’s only experience is SOTFS. I bought the Trilogy for Xbox One so SOTFS is all I know.

It’s…it is weird. The difficulty spikes felt massively out of place compared to the sensible ramp up of Dark Souls 1; Heidi’s Tower, Iron Keep, Shrine of Amana, etc. Even Black Gulch was a bear if you didn’t slow down and tackle the poison statues.

But, I’m not having a bad time with it because:

1. Craftsman’s Hammer. That thing is absurdly strong. It just cleans up most enemies. I whooped the Ruin Sentinels, and some other bosses that historically gave people trouble.

2. Greatshield. I can’t explain why, but parrying felt more useless in DS2. I picked up a Twin Dragon Greatshield and got infinitely more utility out of having attacks just bounce off; made the gank squads much more manageable. 

To that end, felt like SOTFS didn’t allow for ANY play-style like DS1 did. Looking back, not sure how I’d have gotten through some areas without a greatshield.

My real question is why are you using that shitty sword and shitty armor? Do you like to hurt yourself? They don't even seem upgraded.
Funny thing is, i've never really struggled with scholar and I like the game, but that may be linked with the fact that my playthrough were done with a colossal sword, which makes a lot of enemies significantly easier since you can aggro them and then two shot them all at the same time.

So a lot of balancing issue kinda go over my head, but it's cool to see a video explaining correctly what's so different about the two, and I do agree that a lot of choices in scholar seem very weird.

snippet.textDisplay:
The issue with a lot of Dark Souls 2 critiques is that the person complaining didn't actually play the game. Early Souls games are far more about the level design than it is about the enemies or the bosses. Dark Souls 1 had bosses that were complete shit and even the best bosses like Ornstein and Smough are very simple bosses but the gank nature of the boss fight changes things but alone, they are very easy. I would say until Dark Souls 3, bosses weren't really the main focus of the Souls series. Dark Souls 2 has impeccable level design if you pay attention to what the game is trying to do. In many of the combat encounters in Dark Souls 2, the game is giving you a combat puzzle. You have to figure out the way to get around the puzzle or risk running to the exit which can be very risky. Dark Soul 1 also had these combat puzzles all over the game but Dark Souls 1's combat puzzle was very simple in comparison. Oftentimes the solution was just run at the ranged attackers and kill them then switch your focus on the melee attackers. However, in Dark Souls 2, you will often get punished for trying to focus down the ranged attackers, either through traps or through enemies ambushes.

Dark Souls 2 Scholar Iron Keep isn't that bad. All of those "ganks" are ambushes that you can avoid. You can fight the knights 1 v 1 in the room before the Smelter Demon if you,

1. Don't try to kill the archer before trying to take care of the knights coming up the stairs and falling down to attack you. If you get on the bridge, the knight at the very end of the bridge will come after you, which will make the fight with the stair knight much harder. The enemies are spaced out enough, so you won't be overwhelmed even with a +0 weapon. To avoid getting shot by the archer knight, used the arches next to the bridge to cut line of sight off from the archer.

2. Don't run to any of the captain knights, there are two Alonne knights that will drop down from the Pharos Lockstone place that will ambush you. Wait for them to get to the bridge and either kill them there or if you're a low poise bitch, pull them to the wider platform near the entrance of the room.

3. All of these ambushes are visible and noticeable if you're patience or cautious.

The room after the smelter demon has falling trap doors that you can use to kill the enemies with the lava. Utilize it.

Shrine of Amana can be complete done no range weapon easily. I did it with a Santiers Spear +5 and a torch. Use the building to get close to some of the wizards to kill them. You can dodge the arrow by running to your left or right. I only died once attempting this and I usually complete this level by using a bow.

I also did this with the default ADP of 9. So, it's very possible and very doable.

snippet.textDisplay:
Your main thesis for why the remaster exists (a 'cashgrab') is completely ignorant of the visual upgrades and porting to the then-already-existing newer platforms. In 2014, XB1 and PS4 were already out. DS2 was always going to get a cross platform release. 60 fps, higher rez, etc. you can still critique the enemy and item placements, but to act like they repackaged the same game for no other reason is really disingenuous. 

On PC, yes, there is no good reason to opt for the remaster apart from size of online community, but on console the choice is much murkier as the newer generation of consoles get a much improved looking and running game, but at the expense of the shittier placements.

There's no cash grab to release the game a mere year later updated for new consoles. That's a welcome and wanted product worth the price.

Your video should have distinguished this.

Also you kinda acknowledged in a post but to be exceedingly clear, Scholar of the First Sin refers to 3 things: a patch, a bundle, and remaster.

snippet.textDisplay:
Played over 500 hours of vanilla and i just recently beat sotfs, i can confidently say sotfs is inferior. 

Video hits the nail on the head with there being 3x the enemies and the pointlessly blocked paths. Few other thing's are the fact you'll fight some bosses upwards of 5-6 time's and there are 3x the amount of npc invaders some of which will not stop invading even after beating them.

I can handle the difficulty but due to the sheer amount of enemies you're forced to either slowly lure out groups 1 by 1 or spam roll and sprint away from the hoards in order to make space to land a hit. Simply not fun.

snippet.textDisplay:
I agree with everything but playing Scholar has made me into a superhuman
to the point where if sth is NOT hard as scholar.. it bores me.
I still appreciate the beauty of Demons, DS1 and Vanilla DS2.
but there is something about the paranoid approach I feel inside of me when I'm playing Scholar
that truly sharpens my senses.. 
I know the devs were too stupid to know what they were doing without Miyazaki's guidance
but accidently they've created something that is just so PERFECT for massochists like me!~

after playing Scholar.. I rarely do boss runs.. 
I just treat each boss death as a way to get more souls from the individual MOB that is in my way 
until I reach the boss again. 
I take my time each time I "run" to the boss.
cause if I end up fighting the boss the same way again and again 
and crossing my fingers that this time it'll work
well that is literally the definition of insanity

but DS1 is still my favorite souls game of all time cause its not just a video game for me.
DS1 is a place I'd like to visit and actually LIVE IN for a while.
the lore.. the characters.. the environment.. the sounds.. the stories.. the visuals.. the ATMOSPHERE!~
its my favorite game of all time.. DS2 is just a beep boop video game to pass the time lol

also also imho
Bloodborne and Elden Ring are two empty pieces of boring krap
DS3 is just Bloodborne for PC.. its a bit better than Bloodborne but still.. empty..
and Sekiro is Dark Souls for ADHD kids. superboring

as may people have said the 1mil skip to drangleic castle still works

you were not taught to run from enemies from scholar. the forest of fallen giants is a master course of just the opposite. the army of guys wake up one at a time if you dont run up to all of them so that you can complain about it in your video, the ironclad teaches you about explosive barrels and that positioning is more important than dodging, the pursuer encounter teaches you to expect enemies from all places around loot, the hidden ballistae and pate teach you about traps, the gank on the sword is a obvious trap that reinforces previous lessons and is easily avoidable if you stop part way and check for enemies above, they drop down infront of you if you do just that and you can retreat off the sword to fight in a fair location. scholar is easiest if you play slow, and worst when you run past every enemy because they will follow you. 

scholar's difficulty curve is no different if you just play the game, shrine of amana is probably the hardest location in scholar pre dlc because of the magic and basement dweller spam, but again mitigated by positioning and fighting in spots that make sense for what youre fighting.

the optional areas for the dlc are BS and everyone hates them, i only ever do iron passage when i want to do the doritos meme build because "haha funny swords glow like chip colors"

snippet.textDisplay:
As someone who's played Vanilla first, neither is a bad game or worse than the other. Scholar is just a different flavour, it makes the game hella easy in some ways while harder in others.

If you complain about branches, I doubt there's a way to get completely stuck. It's just you'll have to do more work. And that's an integral part of Dark Souls.

And if you complain about Heide knights, gangs, iron keep and whatever else you can use magic to cheese them, arrows and parry. Again, this is Dark Souls, so you have to ✨✨ git gud ✨✨

And I might be wrong, but a person in Iron Keep with falconer's armor and a broadsword leaves an impression of a noob.

snippet.textDisplay:
In my experience, the vast majority of people that disparage Scholar are those that just won't learn to stop rushing in. Enemies are perfectly spaced so that if you actually take your time and carefully observe your surroundings, you will rarely have to deal with more than 2 enemies at any time. There are the occasional mega-ambushes, but they always have an escape route and are meant to be just that; ambushes. But they're also perfectly spaced so that if you keep trying to rush in to "Get it done faster" you aggro a ton of enemies that will all swarm you. If you actually pace yourself through areas like the Iron Keep, you can actually complete the entire area only having fought a single enemy at a time. If you immediately run into the main area like an idiot, then yes, 6 Alonne Knights will aggro on you all at the same time.

Scholar is meant to be dangerous and you're supposed to be paranoid because enemies are on every side of you.

I'm sorry to say that if your primary complain of Scholar is the enemy placements: 
You're a rusher. Plain and simple. You are the EXACT kind of person that real ambushes are meant to easily kill; people that don't stop to check their surroundings and rush in heedless of danger.
You're blaming the game for your own failure to adapt.

snippet.textDisplay:
I did play DS2 at launch, all DLCs then bought SotFS and I do believe DS2 is a great game.
I think people who complain about hitboxes in DS2 may not have played BB or have taken dangerous amounts of copium because my man, if people think hitboxes are bad in DS2, I double dare you to try BB. The Watchdog of the Old Gods in Cursed and Defiled Chalice will make the hitboxes of DS2 feel like joy.

Regarding DS2 in general, I think it's a good game. In my opinion, it's a better game than DS1 in many ways. It is also a worse game than DS1 in some ways.
It's fine not to like it though, however I'm really questioning the logic behind specifically hating it when liking Bloodborne. It's quite the mystery to me.

snippet.textDisplay: I can be good at both versions, no version splits my view on which is better, but I dislike that they made a version with entirely different enemy placings, so far apart from each other that sometimes I am playing one of the two versions and I am like "Wait? I was expecting two enemies to gang me here and I do remember there was an item there, but nothing". This would be like the equivalent of iD making two entirely different versions of classic Doom, with such vast differences between each other, that you don't know which of the two is the pirated bootleg hack of the game. Or as I put it in another video, it's like I am stuck in a double mandela effect world where both Berenstein and Berenstain Bears exist. A split in my brain.
snippet.textOriginal: I can be good at both versions, no version splits my view on which is better, but I dislike that they made a version with entirely different enemy placings, so far apart from each other that sometimes I am playing one of the two versions and I am like "Wait? snippet.textDisplay:
15:13 As far as I recall, the Shrine of Amana nerf was just reducing the tracking of the magic projectiles of the enemies there. It was never as bad as some people make it out to be.

19:26 The dragon skeleton actually can be activated in Scholar as well, but it requires lighting a bunch of braziers further inside the keep, so if you do that it's pretty much always going to activate while you're behind it, and you'll just watch it crumble from far away. Yeah, I don't know why they thought this was a good idea.

19:31 I'm fairly sure the statue in Dragon Aerie can be skipped by going around a different way, but yeah, it's totally pointless.

32:11 I can't speak for anyone else I guess, but I played Dark Souls II vanilla to death when it first came out, and I came to pretty much the exact conclusion you did about Scholar when I first played it in 2015 or so, despite having played through vanilla an ungodly number of times before that. I honestly don't understand how anyone can defend most of the crap changes that were made. Initially I figured it was just that they played Scholar first and got used to all of its ridiculous bullshit, but since you apparently played Scholar first and still prefer vanilla, maybe that's not it either.
snippet.textOriginal:
15:13 As far as I recall, the Shrine of Amana nerf was just reducing the tracking of the magic projectiles of the enemies there. It was never as bad as some people make it out to be.

19:26 The dragon skeleton actually can be activated in Scholar as well, but it requires lighting a bunch of braziers further inside the keep, so if you do that it's pretty much always going to activate while you're behind it, and you'll just watch it crumble from far away. Yeah, I don't know why they thought this was a good idea.

19:31 I'm fairly sure the statue in Dragon Aerie can be skipped by going around a different way, but yeah, it's totally pointless.

32:11 I can't speak for anyone else I guess, but I played Dark Souls II vanilla to death when it first came out, and I came to pretty much the exact conclusion you did about Scholar when I first played it in 2015 or so, despite having played through vanilla an ungodly number of times before that. I honestly don't understand how anyone can defend most of the crap changes that were made. Initially I figured it was just that they played Scholar first and got used to all of its ridiculous bullshit, but since you apparently played Scholar first and still prefer vanilla, maybe that's not it either.

snippet.textDisplay: Fun factoid about the dlcs that a lot of original players probably know already; the utter BS areas for the DLC optional bosses are designed as specifically co-op areas, whether you think the whole game is coop balanced or not. This is, of course, why there are two summons (the same ones) across all 3 dlcs in the entries to the co-op areas in Scholar. To encourage co-op and to market the dlc, they also made it to where in the original, you could do the co-op areas of the dlcs as a phantom with others whether you had purchased the dlcs or not by placing a summon sign in the statues in the dlc lobbies.
snippet.textOriginal: Fun factoid about the dlcs that a lot of original players probably know already; the utter BS areas for the DLC optional bosses are designed as specifically co-op areas, whether you think the whole game is coop balanced or not. This is, of course, why there are two summons (the same ones) across all 3 dlcs in the entries to the co-op areas in Scholar. To encourage co-op and to market the dlc, they also made it to where in the original, you could do the co-op areas of the dlcs as a phantom with others whether you had purchased the dlcs or not by placing a summon sign in the statues in the dlc lobbies.

snippet.textDisplay: I genuinely don't like Dark Souls 2 anymore... But I did love it for the first 6 months I spent playing vanilla. Its problems are abundantly clear now that Fromsoft has made better games from that feedback, but Scholar has always been a version I have no desire to play. Every change I've seen to the level design and enemy placements has made it look like the most exhausting garbage experience Dark Souls 2 could provide
snippet.textOriginal: I genuinely don't like Dark Souls 2 anymore... But I did love it for the first 6 months I spent playing vanilla. Its problems are abundantly clear now that Fromsoft has made better games from that feedback, but Scholar has always been a version I have no desire to play. Every change I've seen to the level design and enemy placements has made it look like the most exhausting garbage experience Dark Souls 2 could provide

snippet.textDisplay: I want to point out a bit about shrine of amana that's almost been lost to time: Vanilla 1.0 Shrine of Amana was much harder, but a patch cut down on the number of enemies in a patch.  Scholar essentially reverted that change.  I don't think it's exactly the same, but it's much more similar.

snippet.textDisplay:
See, your first mistake was using a broadsword. Either use an Ultra Greatsword like the Greatsword (great naming scheme btw), or use a Rapier (halberds are great too). Never use a straight sword.

I should know since I made that mistake my first Scholar playthrough, and it was a living hell playing it that way.

Second mistake was just entirely a skill issue ngl. Why would you run past all the enemies when you KNOW that doing so usually winds up getting you killed? Like sure, yeah I get it, your dps was low and the game having more enemies than Vanilla means you have to spend more time taking them all out, but choosing to run past everything just ENSURES that you’ll get swarmed by the enemies. “Try luring out” is some pretty basic advice found in the player messages because people know that getting swarmed sucks. When you take on the enemies one at a time instead of getting your blood veins ruptured because YOU allowed yourself to get swarmed by all 17 of the enemies within the area- look man, that’s just plainly on you.

Ngl though, seeing that Vanilla had a big Basilisx in the Shaded Woods DS2 is really cool. That’s good game design right there; showing me cool ass shit. Hell yeah, Vanilla

snippet.textDisplay:
The DS2 DLC is where From Soft lost the plot and ruined the series, and then everything else. DS2 was by no means a masterpiece, but had a lot of great ideas that just weren't done justice. The DLC decided that dude spam gank squads and cheap crap you have no means of avoiding on your first go was how to do things. That led to DS3 being absolute cheese beyond cheese as it moved further and further away from a game where you plan out your every move and more towards a T&E R1/O spamfest where you roll 6 times in a row because 8 of 10 enemies in the room are all swinging on you at once. The most obnoxious part is that that crap leaked out of DS3 and into Armored Core as well, soiling what was once my favorite series and turning it into big robot Sekiro with that utterly moronic stagger system that not only makes absolutely no sense (How do you temporarily stagger a damn helicopter and suddenly your bullets are doing 4x the damage despite hitting the same spots just because a magic bar filled up?) but completely changes how the game is played on a core level (Can't be slow and methodical wearing them down over time because you HAVE to fill that damn bar and you can only do it via barbarian rage aggression).

Vanilla DS2 pre-DLC is the last game where you aren't forced to spam attacks and dodges but can play methodically and get rewarded for it. Meanwhile DS3 has sections and enemies you quite literally cannot counter (Such as the nuns who drain your health just by looking at you, meaning you HAVE to rush them down because that HP doesn't come back even if you aren't hit, or that section in the knock-off Tower of Latria where the nuns are literally invisible and undetectable until you pick up the item at the end of the corridor with nothing hinting it could be a trap). 

The last Armored Core is For Answer, and the Souls trilogy is Demon's Souls, Dark Souls, and Dark Souls 2.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have been replaying both versions, now playing SOTFS again and I keep questioning what was the point of the random enemy placement changes? Few of them are good, most of them are bad. So, instead of fixing the hitboxes and other clanky mechanics of the original, they just added more mobs?

Now, personally I have become so good at those games, that I can manage even the more annoying areas. I am just puzzled at them. I was playing Iron Keep yesterday. Sure, what I do in both the original and the vanilla, I carefully kill enemies, I never do the run past enemies to the boss. The weird mechanic of making enemies dissapear after many tries might help there if the boss is hard, but that might be a cop out. But anyway, I was like wtf, I don't remember the original having so many of these armored samurais at you.

And then the atmosphere of finding the Heide Knights in the original, who were very rare and scattered all over the world? Just why the ganged them up in the same area? It totally spoiled it for me. I can carefully manage this area, I do have my fun with SOTFS too, but thematically they killed it. Even though most people say it was killed already with all the disconnected locations, but whatever.

Then there are few good changes. One change is, in the original to get the Dull Ember so that McDuff the blacksmith would be able to infuse weapons for you and sell stuff. That one was at some broken staircase in Iron Keep. I could be playing this area very last in my playthroughs I was full there and still couldn't infuse weapons or buy enough large titanite. In the SOTFS you find the ember early in the similar area as McDuff.

Even smaller changes, like there used to be some crystal lizards that had something iconic, where you chased one and there was an ambush, or one dropped in a pit in some places. There are few of them, others are changed. Some iconic moments are lost. There are few other in SOTFS that can be a bit iconic in a different way. But now? They shouldn't have made a rerelease with different enemy placements. When I play either of the version, I don't remember what to expect at some areas, I am like "I do remember here there was a crystal lizard, or a hidden enemy or a certain item, but where is it?". As gaming will create memories around certain areas and items/enemies and traps you will encountered, those are very mixed for me when I play either version.

But yeah,. after finishing another time the SOTFS, I'll stick to the original when I replay.
snippet.textOriginal:
I have been replaying both versions, now playing SOTFS again and I keep questioning what was the point of the random enemy placement changes? Few of them are good, most of them are bad. So, instead of fixing the hitboxes and other clanky mechanics of the original, they just added more mobs?

Now, personally I have become so good at those games, that I can manage even the more annoying areas. I am just puzzled at them. I was playing Iron Keep yesterday. Sure, what I do in both the original and the vanilla, I carefully kill enemies, I never do the run past enemies to the boss. The weird mechanic of making enemies dissapear after many tries might help there if the boss is hard, but that might be a cop out. But anyway, I was like wtf, I don't remember the original having so many of these armored samurais at you.

And then the atmosphere of finding the Heide Knights in the original, who were very rare and scattered all over the world? Just why the ganged them up in the same area? It totally spoiled it for me. I can carefully manage this area, I do have my fun with SOTFS too, but thematically they killed it. Even though most people say it was killed already with all the disconnected locations, but whatever.

Then there are few good changes. One change is, in the original to get the Dull Ember so that McDuff the blacksmith would be able to infuse weapons for you and sell stuff. That one was at some broken staircase in Iron Keep. I could be playing this area very last in my playthroughs I was full there and still couldn't infuse weapons or buy enough large titanite. In the SOTFS you find the ember early in the similar area as McDuff.

Even smaller changes, like there used to be some crystal lizards that had something iconic, where you chased one and there was an ambush, or one dropped in a pit in some places. There are few of them, others are changed. Some iconic moments are lost. There are few other in SOTFS that can be a bit iconic in a different way. But now? They shouldn't have made a rerelease with different enemy placements. When I play either of the version, I don't remember what to expect at some areas, I am like "I do remember here there was a crystal lizard, or a hidden enemy or a certain item, but where is it?". As gaming will create memories around certain areas and items/enemies and traps you will encountered, those are very mixed for me when I play either version.

But yeah,. after finishing another time the SOTFS, I'll stick to the original when I replay.

snippet.textDisplay:
I came here after watching your Hate Critique of SotFS video, and I agree with the points in this video, and see no need to make corrections as the pinned comment explains more.

I want to say from the perspective of someone who played the vanilla version before recently deciding to 100% SotFS achievements to show on my steam page, I have no idea what people were smoking to think the changes made in the 'Definitive Edition' made the game better (but I would have liked some while playing to ease the frustration of having to beat the game two and a half times to avoid grinding a dead online for 3 spells). In NG+, the devs of Scholar said "You know, beating the game once was not hard enough, so we'll add even more enemies to every area", which is the moment I stopped having any sort of fun with the game. Beating NG Scholar made me feel accomplished and victorious over a poorly designed game that took me 50 hours to perfect, but then NG+ removed the rush I had to make to get the remaining items due to adding new variables into areas and boss fights alongside higher hp values, stretching the amount of time I needed to beat the game an extra 20 hours, compared to DS1 where I only need 8 hours to do the remaining things I needed to do in NG+ and NG++ for all achievements. An even worse part of DS2 NG+ is that the amount of souls you need to open the Shrine of Winter is multiplied by your playthrough number. I didn't do this for NG+ where you needed 2 mil souls and regret it, but I did it for NG++ for 3 mil by using company of champions in black gulch with 2000 fire arrows and slowly grinded all the souls I needed as I was done with the shitty level design, and managed to do it in 2 hours.

If someone else reads this and wants to do the Dark Soul achievement for Vanilla or Scholar, I recommend reversing the order I did this. Grind the 2 mil souls in black gulch so you can level up a ton and spend less time doing repetitive shit, then on your third playthrough grab the old boss souls when you are overlevelled and get everything you are missing. Make sure you do all your weapon enchantments before going onto your second playthrough as the fastest way to beat the levels of NG+/++ scholar won't let you do infusion.
For your third playthrough, take this path: Rush to pursuer, then pick your poison of wasting more time to get the antiquated key with a clever firebomb to skip ruin sentinels or just fight them yourself, I recommend the skip to save a fragrant branch of yore for straid to get the old souls spells. Kill Lost Sinner, then go to Tseldora and just do it normally, you can rush from Majula to Quelaag poison clone without killing a single enemy. Rush Heide tower just to get the girl to move the path to Iron Keep and make that your third objective to do normally, and if you can, find another branch of yore somewhere to save for the secret gulch bonfire in case something goes wrong at the Rotten which did happen to me as his attacks get quite stronger for some reason. Then get your old soul spells from Straid, go to Drangleic, and get the ghost's spells, and you are done as long as you did the Sol Belfry Mad Warrior grinding and are rank 3 in Heirs of the Sun.

I booted up my old Xbox 360 to see how much I faired as a 15 year old in vanilla vs 25 year old me in Scholar, I beat Vanilla with 78 deaths in my loot goblin/kill every enemy 12 times grindset of 120 hours with most of my deaths occurring at Smelter Demon, Ancient Dragon, and Pvp. In Scholar, I beat the game in 147 deaths with a spread of deaths fairly consistent, with most of my deaths occurring at Shrine of Amana and Old Iron/Ivory DLC. After getting 100% in scholar, my deaths rose to 201 deaths as I attempted to find a more efficient way to grind bell keeper by trying online to do 10 1v1's with the same guy and win only 2 of them, getting killed by new random red phantoms, and other random 1-hit bullshit.

snippet.textDisplay:
I do prefer the "vanilla"/DX9 version of DS2 in quite a few ways, and I also think it's quite terrible in other ways, especially compared to SOTFS' changes (most notably item acquisition; for instance, like requiring Ascetics or farming covenant rewards; most of these things were reworked in SOTFS).

But this video is disingenuous in at least one way.
SOTFS wants you to be observant and take it slowly, and you, as a player, refuse to do so. What you want and what the game asks of you are two different, unreconcileable things. That is part of why you died 200+ times in SOTFS.
You chose to run past areas where you should've slowed down, and applied strategy and patience. You assumed that the intent of some areas were for you to run past everything, when that (most of the time) isn't the case. With the exception of DS3, aggro'ing every enemy in the level gets you killed in these games, no matter which game it is.
The other part of why you died 200+ times is probably because (at least based on the clips you showed) you played like a fool - for instance, in SOTFS footage of the area where the Heide Knight used to be, you aggro'd like 7 hollow infantry and then you kept horribly whiffing like 5 swings in a row instead of repositioning or running/rolling away.

But this video is disingenuous in at least one way.

snippet.textDisplay: Rare take, I love scholar of the first sin. I was huge into dks2 especially with PvP being mostly fixed comparatively to dks1 PvP and the 2 major complaints was that the game was way too easy because of the new healing mechanics and that it was too ganky. The B team said haha okay fuck you and added a ton of red phantoms and higher tier mobs all over the place almost as a direct challenge to everyone complaining about how easy it was (at the time). Never though play scholars as your initial dks2 experience, it's basically a hateful love letter to dks2 fans who whined a lot. They even advertised it as a revised, harder, version of dks2 which seems they were hoping to target the dark souls demographic not new players. Scholars was a revised experience for dks2 fans that basically started in ng+ and was kinda advertised that way. It's sad that hardcore dks2 fans have convinced new players that it's the "definitive edition" when it's just the edition for hardcore dks2 fans.

snippet.textDisplay:
as someone who has played vanilla dark souls 2 so many times to the point where my last playthrough was a no estus/lifegems run for _fun_, and i could consistently get to shrine of amana without a SINGLE death, probably could no-death casually if i actually...tried... and whos only seen the scholar changes through the playthroughs of others, alot of this is my thoughts exactly.

ignore the people defending scholar, when i look at the differences, the scholar edition looks like those "ascended"/unfair mods youd find for all the games, to the point where im surprised it ISNT.

i would genuinely like to know WHO decided on changes like this, so i can hop back in time and slap them so hard their entire lineage will feel it for the rest of time so that they can look back at them and rightfully blame them.

Vanilla Ds2 feels deliberate like there was cognizant thought and effort and passion put into it, scholar feels like they made all the changes after a night of drinking themselves half to death hours before they were supposed to ship the game.

snippet.textDisplay: I first played DS2 during a period where I had no internet for about 6 months so I never downloaded any updates. As a result, my first 6 months of playing DS2 were pure vanilla day one version goodness. You can imagine my distaste when I finally got the remastered SotFS and played that. So many things about a game I once loved had been destroyed. Yes, it’s never going to be in the same league as DS1 & 3 but it was a decent game in its own right. But scholar ruined it completely. I don’t think it’s a coincidence that Miyazaki included the “Ruin” armor set in DS3 as a little nod to 2.

snippet.textDisplay:
Idk how anyone who claims to be a souls veteran could ever like Scholar. It literally feels like fan mod it is so bad. They just dropped more mobs in every area and made game way more linear by putting statues to block every single path. It so bad and lacks any quality control. Is it not a problem of it being harder, it is a problem of it being done horribly. They just went,  lets spawn 3x the amount of mobs. Now give us another 60$. They're are so many paths items once easily accessible blocked for no reason at all. 

In the original you could very well fight Orenstien copy cat as your very first boss. In Scholar they made Hiedes towers have 20 hiede knights that are constantly active at all times that over lap with 10 mobs already there. Not only are you heavily encouraged to just run past everything and not interact with the content, the path to Orenstein is blocked by a huge over sttated Dragon that has 1000x the hp of that area's mobs, plus one shots you, plus spews fire across the map for no reason. So that entire path way which one created an alternative route for each play through is just now gone for no reason. Most players will get hard stuck behind the over statted Dragon then only come back when they vastly out level Orenstien and two shot him. That is objectively a horrible way to "improve" the game. It is also one of the most infamous lore violation and jokes. They just completely stepped on the Dragon Slayers lore and character by putting a random no name dragon outside his arena. This famous joke everyone knows ONLY comes from Scholar, not the original. That just goes to show how completely thoughtless all of Scholars changes were. The devs probably did not even play test the content, or even realize their changes would break levels and lore, they just haphazardly changed things just to change things.

snippet.textDisplay: I just watched a couple videos comparing DS2 with Scholars, and it's interesting how different they are. In the other video the reviewer had more deaths and was a lower level on vanilla (despite playing it second), while in your video you had more deaths and a lower level on Scholars. I think this suggests that the difference really comes down to playstyle. In the other video he fought most of the new enemies, which gave him more experience and leveled him up faster, making bosses easier. On the other hand you chose to run past everything, missing out on experience and making bosses harder (also more vulnerable to ganks). I don't think either of these is wrong, just two very different perspectives.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you for making this video. I've only ever played vanilla DS2, and I remember I played each Dark Souls game in order on their releases on Steam, I felt like I enjoyed Dark Souls 2 the most. I loved Dark Souls 1, I hated Dark Souls 2 when I first played it (mostly due to enemies having finite respawns and finite Life Gems/humanities as a result), but as I got further in Dark Souls 2 I just began to love it more and more. I actually liked the world and level design, the story was extremely compelling to me, even moreso than Dark Souls 1. I cared more about Drangleic than Lordran. I cared more about Vendrick than Gwyn. I loved the varied environments I got to visit. The NPCs felt more alive than just random merchants. I liked the Black Gulch more than Blighttown. And probably most odd of all, I liked the bosses more than the Dark Souls 1 bosses, even if they're less memorable. I just felt like I had a more "fun" experience by the time I finished Dark Souls 2 than I did when I finished Dark Souls 1. And Dark Souls 3 I just felt was "alright" by the time I finished it. I barely remember anything about it. So as a result, my memories of the three games made me think Dark Souls 2 was my favorite because I remembered feeling it was the most "fun" of the three after finishing them. But, I only played the DLC of the first one, not the next two games. So I only played vanilla DS2 and DS3. I never played Scholar, so now that I'm replaying all 3 to get ready to play Elden Ring for the first time, I was thinking about trying Scholar because everyone seems to praise it over DS2 and say it made DS2 way better, given they all hate DS2. I'm glad I didn't because Scholar looks stupid compared to vanilla, and I imagine everyone who loves Scholar and/or hates DS2 didn't play vanilla now. Because my memories of vanilla DS2 are exactly as you described: a slow ramp up in difficulty, a curve that makes sense.

I loved the varied environments I got to visit. The NPCs felt more alive than just random merchants. I liked the Black Gulch more than Blighttown. And probably most odd of all, I liked the bosses more than the Dark Souls 1 bosses, even if they're less memorable. I just felt like I had a more "fun" experience by the time I finished Dark Souls 2 than I did when I finished Dark Souls 1. And Dark Souls 3 I just felt was "alright" by the time I finished it. So as a result, my memories of the three games made me think Dark Souls 2 was my favorite because I remembered feeling it was the most "fun" of the three after finishing them. Because my memories of vanilla DS2 are exactly as you described: a slow ramp up in difficulty, a curve that makes sense.

snippet.textDisplay:
Both games (DS1 and DS2), each has a special place in my heart❤. They are different and I feel something different towards each of them, but I really wouldn't elevate one above the other🤔. 
Regarding the two DS2 versions, SotFS was my first one, and I only now have started the vanilla game. It's really fun playing through a slightly different version of your favorite game 😊. I've only come until Huntsman's Copse so far, but yeah, the levels feel a little bit easier, but maybe it's because I know the enemy archetypes. Experience is still experience. I do die once in a while tho tbh.

snippet.textDisplay: I disagree. Scholar of the First Sin is the best DLC of all Dark Souls games. It offers a completed background and story with puzzles and difficulty worthy of the Dark Souls name. I played and passed the original version first and the story made little sense, but when they released all the stories, it all came together with better clarity. The three DLC to complete the crowns gave us memorable puzzles and mazes to find the four crowns in ancient Egypt, the frozen storming tundra, and the clockwork tower.  You need to explore the original game to understand the need for better story telling and adventure. In my opinion, the DLC made DS2 a classic.
snippet.textOriginal: I disagree. Scholar of the First Sin is the best DLC of all Dark Souls games. It offers a completed background and story with puzzles and difficulty worthy of the Dark Souls name. I played and passed the original version first and the story made little sense, but when they released all the stories, it all came together with better clarity. The three DLC to complete the crowns gave us memorable puzzles and mazes to find the four crowns in ancient Egypt, the frozen storming tundra, and the clockwork tower.  You need to explore the original game to understand the need for better story telling and adventure. In my opinion, the DLC made DS2 a classic.

snippet.textDisplay:
Honestly, most of this guys deaths in Scholar seem to be because he didn't have any points in Adaptability. He was getting hit by a lot of stuff in the middle/end of his roll animation, likely due to low adaptability or dex(agi). You don't need a ton of points in it to make rolling more effective. Also instead of just trying to run past everything, find an effect route/routine to defeat enemies. Once you die to a gank you know it's going to happen so you should be able to prepare yourself for it and do a lot better after dying to it few times. It really seems like this guy is average at best in terms of skill and game knowledge. Also I rarely saw him using bows/magic at all, some of the complaints are literally not an issue for people that use bows/magic.
I don't think he's completely wrong on everything but I don't feel like he was that good at the game to have such strong opinions, especially after seeing how many things he had wrong in this video too.

snippet.textDisplay:
I liked Scholar when it came out, but it might be just as you say, I saw it as a hard mode of some game I enjoyed and beat several times over. I never felt the need to run past enemies, and instead relied on life gem spamming and jump-attack kiting.

I'm going through Scholar again these days and so far I don't die much. I'm just coming back from an Elden Ring playthrough so it feels like I'm allowed to get hit by enemies since they don't deal ridiculous amounts of damage, but at times I'm forced to just run back to an area's entrance and hope enemies don't stay too close to each other.

I think they wanted to capitalise on the fact that enemies won't respawn more than ten times in DkS2, so if an area is too hard you're supposed to try to get at least one kill on each run. I remember when I first played the DLC years ago, I thought they balanced the game around that feature, and I hated it. But the feature itself is fine tbh, I like being able to get closer to my objective no matter what I do. That's actually how I beat the blue smoldering demon, I just went back and forth making sure to deplete every spawn before actually trying my luck on the boss.

You made me want to play vanilla DkS2 again though, so I'm going to do just that!

snippet.textDisplay:
I recently beat Scholar for the first time and while I found things to like about it - in particular the variety of levels that came from the disconnectedness and the fast rate of leveling, which is perfect for a leveling nut - it *was* overall incredibly tedious and frustrating and felt mean-spirited in many parts where DS1's deaths usually felt earned. 

Then I started playing Vanilla since a friend of mine has it in his shared Steam library and MAN. It's such a weird feeling. I got so used to SotFS hostile environments that Vanilla feels like a brisk walk in the park right now (I'm still on the lord souls though). I absolutely agree with the notion that Vanilla feels like it has a difficulty curve. It was refreshing to play Forest of the Fallen Giants and it feeling reminiscent of Undead Burg in terms of difficulty. It was *also* refreshing to play No-Man's Wharf and have the difficult part not be dodging gravity while a pirates army chases you over the planks, but rather the later part of the level where the weird fire-averse abominations house. It's gradual difficulty progression in every area. I love that because it lets me appreciate the areas more - I already liked Noman's Wharf a lot conceptually in SotFS, but it was massively dragged down by the gameplay experience resulting from all those newly placed hanging pirates that prevent you from dealing with the archers safely. SotFS feels like one of those Kaizo mods in retrospect.


Something that does feel weird about Vanilla though, are some of the empty spaces. In the Lost Bastille as an example, there's that one room that's totally empty except for a chest in the back. In SotFS, the Pursuer spawns there if you interact with the chest. In Vanilla, nothing happened when I looted it, which made the entire space kind of... meaningless? This happened a couple times over, and leaves me wondering what exactly happened. Some areas feel like they were made with SotFS enemy placement in mind, leaving them feeling empty in Vanilla. I still don't know if that's my Scholar conditioning shining through. It's strange.

All I can say is that Vanilla so far feels much better. No area that makes me dread going through it again on NG+ or a replay, while that was nearly every area in SotFS.

snippet.textDisplay: The issue with this game was lifegems. So instead of buffing the estus and limiting or removing lifegems, they increased difficulty by increasing ganks and fights where you are stupidly outnumbered to compensate. The problem with that was that gameplay became a boring "run run, turn around hit a couple of times, take one hit, turn around and run, lifegem lifegem, and repeat. All of this because you could trivialize fights in vanilla by running and lifegeming. They detected a problem and screwed up the fix.

snippet.textDisplay:
I generally like the idea of the video. I played Dark Souls 2 when it came out as a huge fan of the souls series, and seriously I liked it, a lot even. And after playing scholar (on PC) I thought, what the fuck were they thinking with the changes. It's like all "soul" was sucked out of the game (heh heh.....), the enemy replacements were plain AWFUL. So yeah. But I have to say. IMO this video has some, hmm.. very midwit, generalizing takes such as "the first level of a game should be easy!" "why would the game troll the players by not giving a perfect amount of branches!!!"  "losing max HP when dying is dumb!!" 
Like you WANT games to be logically sound, also known as safe and stale, no harsh edges allowed even if it's part of the artistic vision? Although I agree, in Dark Souls 2 the fact that the early game of vanilla is easier and there's a more clear difficulty curve is a good thing in this case. But it's in no way a thing that games should strive to do.
Also Shrine of Amana - yes, on release, it was difficult. If I remember correctly they nerfed the tracking of the magic shots. But despite that, I LOVED the area on the release version. Having to slog through water that slows you down while trying to avoid magic bolts that curve towards you was such an unique and neat idea, and the fact that it felt unfair was just spicy fun. If the area was easier, I felt it would ruin the whole idea. Like it's supposed to be unfair and a struggle. Like hot food. Great gimmick imo and I completely disagreed with the community outrage in the first place. Gamers are just artless, spineless pussies who whine and want their tortilla with no sauce. A game like dark souls throwing "unfair" shit at you is completely fine if it's tastefully done and has some vision behind it. Shrine of amana or losing max HP on death are good examples, but the constant, non-stop hordes of enemies and ganks in scholar is a bad example.

IMO this video has some, hmm.. very midwit, generalizing takes such as "the first level of a game should be easy!" "why would the game troll the players by not giving a perfect amount of branches!!!"  "losing max HP when dying is dumb!!" 
Like you WANT games to be logically sound, also known as safe and stale, no harsh edges allowed even if it's part of the artistic vision? Although I agree, in Dark Souls 2 the fact that the early game of vanilla is easier and there's a more clear difficulty curve is a good thing in this case. But it's in no way a thing that games should strive to do.
Also Shrine of Amana - yes, on release, it was difficult. If I remember correctly they nerfed the tracking of the magic shots. But despite that, I LOVED the area on the release version. Having to slog through water that slows you down while trying to avoid magic bolts that curve towards you was such an unique and neat idea, and the fact that it felt unfair was just spicy fun. If the area was easier, I felt it would ruin the whole idea. Like it's supposed to be unfair and a struggle. Like hot food. Great gimmick imo and I completely disagreed with the community outrage in the first place. Gamers are just artless, spineless pussies who whine and want their tortilla with no sauce. A game like dark souls throwing "unfair" shit at you is completely fine if it's tastefully done and has some vision behind it. Shrine of amana or losing max HP on death are good examples, but the constant, non-stop hordes of enemies and ganks in scholar is a bad example.
