Dark souls just gained so many fans via dark souls 3 and Elden ring, that many people, like myself, started with scholar. Although, I jumped on the dark souls hype with dark souls remastered on the switch.

snippet.textDisplay: I liked dark souls 2, I haven’t played vanilla though. It certainly wasn’t quite as good as 1 or 3, but my only major gripe was the health loss, you could limit the impact and eventually get around it entirely, but it was just unnecessary. Reminds of the Mark Roberg study, when he imposed an artificial penalty for failure, participants were much more likely to quit than if their was no penalty at all. I think the health loss killed folks motivation much quicker on a subconscious level. The amount is small, and you can recover it, but it feels harsh and it is off putting for a lot of people.

snippet.textDisplay:
I definitely felt like SOTFS was harder in spots like fire keep and shrine of amana and the arbitrary petrified statues was a bad choice. One of your complaints is that you dont know if you're supposed to run past enemies or not. The first thing I learned playing any of the Dark Souls games is you NEVER run past enemies. It always leads to a death screen.
At least they did have a feature that many people seem to not realize exists solely in DS2 is that if you kill enemies enough times, they stop respawning. I actually had to use that for the runs through Shrine of Amana and the run to the optional fights in the DLC's. Felt nice being able to just walk to the boss with no encounters along the way.

snippet.textDisplay: This is by no means a defense of SotFS or DS2 in general. The awful hit boxes and seeming total lack of i-frames early game are some of my worst gripes. However Scholar's saving grace with enemy placement might be that all enemies have a respawn limit so eventually the ambushes stop (if you stop to kill them instead of running through). In vanilla this could be a con since farming is difficult and limited without a bonfire ascetic but in Scholar it's almost a pro. Also the statue in the Lost Bastille while still really dumb, there is a branch in the room right next to it which is pretty obviously meant for that exact statue. I'm unsure if the branch exists in vanilla DS2 or not though so that might not be a valid argument.

You've completely missed the point of Vendrick, entirelty. The whole lead up to Vendrick is to evoke memories of Gwyn, this ancient King who rekindled the fire who I now must vanquish. Instead he's this completely hollowed out being who doesn't even care that you are there. 
The King is nothing, he has failed and that's the entire point!
His entire purpose gone, lost to the curse of hollowing. 

That's Dark Souls 2s point, they don't even mention Gwyn in the story because he's been completely forgotten, this cycle of fire has gone on for so long nothing is remembered. The curse of being hollow is the issue.

You're constantly showing footage of yourelf, running blindily into groups of enemies and then trying to fight 1 vs 3 while being anihilated into oblivion. Shouldn´t you try to study first what's in the room? Check your surroundings? Lure enemies one by one? Isn't all that the point of any souls-like game, to punish you for being careless and too much in a hurry?

What's the point of playing ir you intend to past running 90% of the enemies?

I'm a pretty below average souls player and I don't find SOTFS all that bad. Some areas get tiresome (Iron Keep for the most part), but everything is manageable with some strategies.

This mechanic is, for some reason, always overlooked by reviewers yet I do feel like the devs design the level with this in mind. Think about it.

Although I agree with fragment of branch takes and shrine missile spam. I enjoy the scholar more since well it was more fun. The fights were more fun, since I took my time and look and the iron keep area only added like 3 enemies compared to vanilla, excluding the invaders. What got changed was the Aggro range, which is it a bit tedious. But generally the items placement and I enjoy the ganks, since if you took a bit of time you can see it coming and qol were also great. I don’t believe it is a cash grab take, I think it is disingenuous take when you compare it to prepare to die edition which had no changes.

PS: also it is a bit shady including your first play through of ds2 scholar deaths compared to vanilla since well the death counts would be down since it would be your second play through. If you wanted make more relevant, you would have to do a 2nd play through of each and comparing the numbers of deaths, but I guess it would take too much time, since you seemed to not enjoy scholar and well I’m not making videos, I’m just an asshole who likes scholar more.

snippet.textDisplay:
Something else that SotFS made worse was this game's version of the Rare Ring of Sacrifice.
It's essentially a tax on saving your Souls; got 5k? Toss the ring on, you'll lose most of them repairing if you die, but you have several and but each death is your own fault, so it feels like a good trade.
In the re-release, it's like, 20k to repair, and there's only one or two. I never felt like I was in  a place to risk 20k souls until fairly late into the game, because farming to earn those back would take faaaar too long.

snippet.textDisplay:
I didn't play SOTFS because I deemed paying for a patch, as I had bought the DLCs already, quite retarded. In fact I think SOTFS is still one of the worst examples of company greed and retarded consumerbase in history.
But aside from that my actual point would be that no, vanilla DS2 wasn't good either. It still has most of the issues the SOTFS version has (obviously, since SOTFS is just a worse enemy placement plus Aldia, from what I gathered).
Sure, if we're to compare vanilla to SOTFS then I suppose vanilla is the better game, but it's still what it is. A clunky mess made by less talented people that didn't understand much of what they were trying to copy.

snippet.textDisplay:
Funny, I hate gank fights in DkS1 and don't ever really fight without lockon and hate DkS2. I played Vanilla immediately since the first game was already my favorite game by the time 2 rolled around and I preordered vanilla. I hated it. It was a terrible game i got through with my buddy. The same friend wanted to play again years later so he bought us Scholar and I hated it all over again. I don't find any version of Dark Souls 2 bearable and regularly replay the first game. I will say however, while I recognize that From ran out of time and money at the end of the first game and that the areas arent the best I don't mind going though them at all. They aren't hard at all and the more runs I do the more I don't really mind and just see it as finishing up the playthrough. This isn't to say the bed of chaos isn't annoying but doing so many runs I genuinely havent died to Bed in my past runs over the last few years because of a new strategy I didn't have years ago. 

Dark souls 2 is forever my most hated game of the series, I hate every change, I don't care for powerstancing even, I thought it was better in 3 where it was relegated to specific weapons to atleast make it more balanced and easier to understand and use. Life gems suck, soul memory sucks, how the character controls sucks. The only praise I can legitimately give this game without regretting it is the soundtrack isn't bad. I have over 300 hrs in the game, around 150-175 in each version. I hate Dark Souls 2 and I think even the first game and Demon's souls outclasses 3. I hear bloodborne is great but unfortunately don't have a ps4, Sekiro is amazing however, Elden Ring was pretty good but not so much for multiple playthroughs in my opinion. In my honest opinion if you are on PC or have a way to play all the games honestly would just tell people to skip the second game and emulate Demon's Souls.

snippet.textDisplay:
I am doing a blind Broken Sword SotfS Playthrough right now and I want to defeat every single Boss there is, I just beat Throne Watcher & Defender and I even did it on my first try!
I hate almost every hour of my 30 hours spend so far for mainly 2 things: The early Game being absolute hell because of enemy spam, the way the broken sword deals with enemy spam (it doesn´t) and adaptability being to low to not die to shitty Hitboxes.
I do not hate the mid game where I think I am at because, well, it´s just to easy. The Leveldesign is awfull almost every time, but all of the bosses are a complete joke difficulty-wise because of your Roll being op af. From Ruin Sentinel ( I beat them after the Wharft), I died most to the Royal Rat Authority´s little mice´s poison xD. Vendrick and Mirror Knight were a fun and good fight but didn´t require more than 10-15 Lifegems. So far, there wasn´t a real and proper Dark Souls Boss Fight as challenging than Pursuer, who was my first "git gud" Boss.
I really hope that the Late Game gets more challenging and I really hope for something like O&S, Artorias, Midir, Gael or Friede fight. At least the Rings are fire.

snippet.textDisplay:
The only thing I’m disappointed about with Scholar is that the Heide Knights only appear at the tower of flame, as opposed to them being the new Black Knights and placed in random locations across Drangleic, only to be agrod when you attack them.
But I do find it funny that no one seems to realise that you have to bait out enemies and kill them one by one, it’s entirely possible in the likes of Iron Keep, Huntsman’s copse and No Man”s Wharf, and it’s pretty much compulsory to fight these enemies as the game punishes you for simply trying to run past everything like a scaredy-cat. They punish you for being a coward, but reward you for fighting by despawning enemies eventually. The part with the sleeping army in the forest is a perfect tutorial for that. In spite of its massive flaws i still love Scholar and it’s brutal, crushing, horribly uncomfortable difficulty.

snippet.textDisplay:
I never played Vanilla, but from the footage I can see why you hate this game: 
This is  the worst game to just run past enemies. You really have to have a route through the level if you want to run. In DS1 and 3 it's much easier to ignore everything apart from the bosses.
And how the hell do you think the lategame is easier than the early game, all the DLCs are much harder than the base game. All the problematic areas like shrine of Amana and Iron Keep are only really bad on your first playthrough, when you don't know where you are save from the ranged guys. I really liked my second time in Amana and I only play melee. Iron keeps outer ward with the furnace is pretty shitty though, because you have to go back into the room you came from after aggroing an enemy.

And I remember being attacked by the dragon-skeleton, so it has to be in scholar.

snippet.textDisplay: I just stumbled upon this video and I have to thank you for this. After beating DS1, 3 and Elden Ring, I wanted to give DS2 a go. I had purchased SotfS some years ago on steam and never played it, so now was the time. It took me an hour to realise the enemy placement was off, as I was getting ganked and swarmed all the time, something that very rarely happened to me in the other games. Playing through the Forest of Giants alone (yes I know this isn't far) turned me off so much that I had given up on DS2. Now, your video made me reconsider and I might just pick up the Vanilla version and play that instead.

snippet.textDisplay:
Completely unrelated, but I always laugh when I see people using broadsword against heavily armored enemies

I struggled HEAVILY on my first playthrough, giving up after Heide's because I was running with a dagger and straightsword
Stopped playing for a few days, remembered that I have this key to Lenigrast, acquired mace and.. wooow my damage is suddenly enough to two shot the knights?

It really feels like that the first starter weapon you stick with will heavily influence your overall opinion of the game because the Rapier and Mace are just that godlike for the majority of the game.. jokes aside, if you +10 those two and maybe an Estoc as a backup, you will not have a single problem with 95% of the game, and even less if you use an upgraded bow to bait enemies

Nowadays I'm kinda tired of DSII in any form, but whenever I start playing against, I go first for the illusory rings.. and seemingly won't have much problem other than gravity if I use those weapons, anything else is just a ticking timebomb and that is terrible

snippet.textDisplay: I never played DS2 and are currently playing Scholar. I must say, I agree with some points. It doesn't feel as much as a world as DS1 did, just a collection of maps where you go through. Also the petrified statues are VERY annoying as well as some other elements. Overall I still like Scholar as it really has a great atmosphere nevertheless. I learned something through your video, though, what was bothering me and hadn't noticed before. 😄 I'm more a methodical player and clear an area before I proceed. Some areas are really tough, and now I know that is because there are much more multifights in Scholar than in DS1, and I usually try to avoid that. So I had a really hard time doing some bosses, because I have to learn to play without lock on and pay attention to multiple enemies at the same time. With the bow, you can still lure out many enemies to take them singled out, but if you do that, you are not really prepared for bossfights with multiple oponents. One thing it already tought me is, that I no longer rely on armor. In fact, I started to drop most of my armor for boss fights, in order to be more nimble, so I usually wear the armor only on regular play, but then mostly for the look, because I hate how my char looks like when only wearing this loincloth and I can't stay human long enough to bother with it. 😁

snippet.textDisplay:
you can aggro a ton of the alonne knights in the run-up to smelter demon in SOTFS iron keep and fight most of them one-on-one or at worst two at time in a few cases. 

the first one just runs at you just after leaving the bonfire. kill him and the two annoying phantoms and open the door.  then you can proceed to inch your way into the first room to aggro the far knight on the stairs, lure him out of the room, kill him, then go for the knight immediately on your right as you enter the first room proper as he'll aggro right away. the archer will also aggro but its very easy to keep the one pillar in the room between his shots and you while you aggro the first two knights.  continue to your right toward the shop NPC and another knight will sprint down the stairs that will be on your left, kill him too.  there's another knight at the top of these stairs who usually just chills there til you go right up to him.  kill him, and then you'll probably have to go back the way you came as the archer will have probably dropped down out of his window.  kill him, double back up the stairs, go through the two illusory walls and kill the unsuspecting knight behind the second, preferably with the ballista.  Then IIRC one more knight will enter the room from the large outside area leading to the boss fight after you venture a certain distance into the room you're in, kill him too.  The archer on the suspended bridge will aggro immediately upon seeing you along with a single knight who will run at you after you enter the large outdoor area proper, lure him into the previous room and kill him while avoiding the archer.  you can now avoid the archers shots by again standing next to the large pillar near the bridge, one knight should aggro from the level below near the first bridge lever, and two should drop down from the platforms way on the other side of the room after that, you can usually fight these one at a time.  there's a captain there too but he shouldn't aggro. pull the lever next to the furnace to lower the bridge, kill the archer and another knight will aggro from the far end of the bridge, off him too.  The next part is easily the worst, the alonne captain next to the boss fog will fire at you on-sight while you're on the bridge.  there will be another regular knight right at the the end of the bridge should you lower it all the way, and two more will drop down from the elevated area with the pharros' contraption opposite the boss fog once you leave the bridge. you can lure them back across the bridge and kill them without having to deal with the archers after lowering it.  One more knight will aggro from a platform below the captain when you drop down to lower the bridge all the way and turn off the big furnace. after they're all dead, the alonne captain at the far end of the room opposite the boss fog can probably be skipped as long as you pay attention to his shots while fighting the other one next to the boss fog.  

most of these enemies can be fought one at a time, i find this area one of the least-offensive in terms of enemy placements and the ability to peel them off one at a time to safely kill them without having to deal with the whole horde.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you for this video. I was legit going nuts. I played about 12 hours of Scholar before giving up. I decided to give vanilla one last try (I played it ages ago but I didn't know how to play souls so I went to Heide's Tower of Flame first instead of forest, lol, I just assumed 2 was always bad cuz scholar was such a negative experience). I finished Dark Souls 1, 3, and played a bit of Demon's Souls and a bit of Blood Borne before I gave Dark Souls 2 that final try and I'm really glad I did, because despite it's problems, it's my second favorite souls game (we'll see what happens when Blood Borne finally runs at 60fps and I play it for realzies, that might take 2's spot). But when I looked up to find if anyone else had such a polarizing experience, I just found that reddit post and eventually this video. You are dead on the money when you talk about Playing Scholar first and Vanilla second. I even tried going back to scholar after playing vanilla, nope, it still sucks.

The unfortunate reality is that Bandai refuses to put DS2 vanilla and its DLC on sale and third party key sites have been exhausted because there hasn't been that sale in years. The game has all the same content (the scholar boss was added via a later update and the weapon durability bug was fixed on both version) and fixes but 2 just runs and looks better (directx 11 support) and has the bigger online. But if you want to get Dark Souls 2 complete, vanilla edition, you either have to drop 50 dollars (25 for the game, 25 for the season pass) or pirate it. Really sucks. You should honestly get DS2 vanilla for free with scholar now.

I'd also add that there's something just foul under the hood for DS2 Scholar. The hitboxes feel shittier and some of the animations are more delayed, I don't know for sure but something just feels really off playing it.

But if you want to get Dark Souls 2 complete, vanilla edition, you either have to drop 50 dollars (25 for the game, 25 for the season pass) or pirate it. Really sucks. You should honestly get DS2 vanilla for free with scholar now.

I'd also add that there's something just foul under the hood for DS2 Scholar. The hitboxes feel shittier and some of the animations are more delayed, I don't know for sure but something just feels really off playing it.

snippet.textDisplay: I feel really stupid for buying into the hype that DS2/Scholar of the First Sin is a bad game, and this video initially contributed to that notion exponentially. After taking the plunge, I've realized that SotFS is actually an AMAZING game. It just has different mechanics from the other entries. First things first, you HAVE to increase your agility level, because your iFrames when dodging are tied to this stat. This is done by level Adaptability, and Attunement. Ideally you want around 20-30 Adaptability, an agility stat of 105 will give you the same amount of iFrames as a lightweight roll in DS1 (13). This ties into the next point, your carry weight no longer specifically determines how you roll. You will roll the same way all the way up to 70% carry weight, and past that it slows down upto 100%, and past that all movement will be slower. Between 0-70%, your carry weight now determines how FAR you roll, and how quickly your stamina regenerates. You will get the same amount of iFrames regardless of how far you roll. 2 handing a weapon no longer gives you a straight damage increase, it now gives you a strength buff that may or may not increase your damage output based on how well your weapon scales. I could go on, but understanding these things helped me get overcome my frustrations with the game immensely. There are so many thoughtful improvements to the mechanics, you can equip 4 rings, cast speed isn't tied to dexterity, you can dual-wield similar weapons to get a dual-equipped moveset, you can fast travel between all discovered bonfires at any point, there are SO many secrets, NG+ basically overhauls the whole game into a different experience, the list goes on and on. Enough anti-hype for DS2. All it does is keep people from enjoying an amazing experience. We need more videos explaining how to approach DS2 differently to get the most out of it. It's a slightly different flavored version of the formula, but it's a fantastic game.

snippet.textDisplay:
Im going to be honest, Scholar was absolutely a blast up until I tried getting into the DLC’s. Finding keys in really already stupid areas (like the black gulch key) Then you actually get to the dlc’s and it doesnt even feel like a souls game anymore. So annoying having to cut myself out of 3 pieces of brand new content because of how unfair and tedious the game felt at this point. When I got to Eleum Loyce thats when I decided to just give up on the dlc’s as a whole. 

The thing I hate about the ds2 community as well is that all the lovers for the game, especially the dlc’s think that because they like a mechanic, that it’s good. That’s like saying because you like the rattling sound your car makes while driving that means its safe to drive. This game isn’t safe to play if you are just coming to enjoy a souls game. Why do I have to try hard just to enjoy myself? Thats not what gaming has ever been. They seem to have forgot why people enjoyed ds1. Not because it was hard, tricky or tedious… because you could overcome anything no matter what. Scholar dlc just feels like if you dont have this or do this you wont win, simple. And that’s infuriating coming from a souls lover. At the same time, im a grown man who respects his time and sanity so Idrc about locking myself out of content on a game thats years and years old, it just sucks seeing what could have been amazing DLC’s turned into a try hard simulator. Dumb ganks, enemies that can hardly be dodged, massive stamina loss on shield hits, enemies being outright quicker than you, etc the list goes on. I just do the main game for replay value and move on to a souls game (which is any other one lol) that I actually sink time into. Like I said the whole game is great I love it but the DLC’s killed the replay value for me just a little bit and my first time in them frustrated me to no end and it wasnt like a ds1 or ds3 or Bloodborne frustration, this just felt worse. Games arent supposed to be annoying, supposed to be fun.

snippet.textDisplay: I’ve played both Scholar and Vanilla and I can say with certainty that your better off playing Vanilla. Dark Souls has always been built of hard but fair difficulty but with scholar you see none of those principles whereas in Vanilla though still certain parts are bullshit difficulty it still maintains the hard but fair difficulty. I’d say the only reason I bought Scholar is because it came with all the DLC and some visual touchups but at the cost of enemy placements being worse, statues being infuriatingly placed everywhere, and overall just feeling like more of a chore to play. If I were to recommend which game to buy, I’d say Vanilla with all the DLC (on sale of course) as then your getting to see all the content the game has without getting as pissed off and complaining like I did with Scholar. To put things in perspective, in my first playthroughs I beat Vanilla in 20 hours and beat Scholar in 50, died around 400 times in scholar while in vanilla only dying around 85 times, and felt accomplished beating Vanilla while I felt I wasted my time with Scholar.

snippet.textDisplay:
I honestly mostly disagree with this. As someone who started with 2 on the 360, then 2 again on pc years later, then to Scholar in the current year, I feel as if Scholar was the intended experience. Iron keep isn't difficult: I never felt like I was supposed to run unless it was obvious that I should (think vendricks boss run). Taking it slow was the intended iron keep experience. 

The biggest problem you faced from all your footage was that you were under the assumption that you can just run past 20 enemies. That just isn't how scholar goes. You hardly levelled your stamina, you seemed consistently underlevelled (go figure), and I'm just going to assume you neglected ADP.

Though on a blind playthrough scholar is obviously way more challenging, picking up on things through guides or the wiki sticks in the back of your head and it isn't hard to remember what you should be doing. My only real gripe with Scholar was that they never removed that bonfire ascetic from the giant memories, making them an infinite soul and vessel farm (theres your easy mode,  by the way).

The thing is that DS2 vanilla can be seen as a good game overall, especially compared to the others in the industries. But DS1 is an amazing art piece. That's the problem.

Anf if I play DS *two* obviously it's because I wany to replay that art piece, which DS2 isn't.

snippet.textDisplay: ive played and beaten both games twice and im not sure how much i agree.. Your point is most certainly true for the first half of the game, but after iron keep i think scholar is actually the better game. drangleic castle was slightly more fair, not enough to make it better or worse than vanilla though, its more or less the same. shrine of amana is where im confused. the scholar version is WAY easier, id rather run through shrine 10 times in scholar than run through it once in vanilla. secondly, velstadts run is WAY easier, but more importantly more fair. I think the only areas that were messed up were forest, iron keep, no mans wharf, and heides tower of flame as it throws a difficulty that the player shouldnt be expirienced to yet so early on. I think that the problem with no mans wharf was the fact that there was just simply too many enemies. you could easily kill everything in your path in vanilla but i found myself just running through the whole thing in scholar. but they made up with this by adding the shortcut. I think heides tower of flame suffers from putting all the heide knights in the area and making the big boy slam guy in the beginning not drop sublime bone dust and have him respawn, but its not that big of a deal. the worst offender is iron keep, but you summed that up well. While the petrified statues are annoying, again, they made up for it by adding more branches. I think the definitive expirience is shcolar, just because of the fact that shrine of amana, undead crypt, and some of drangleic castle are just absolute garbage in vanilla.  theyre 100x worse than anything scholar did. But i do sometimes find myself recommending new players to play vanilla becuase of the softer introduction. I give you that, its complicated. But i feel like some of your points are exagerated, not true, or opinionated more on the fact that youre playing the version your brain has manifested as the "better" or the "worst" one.

snippet.textDisplay:
My opinion, the only reason someone playing scholar would have issues with the ganks is becuase they are trying to rush past them instead of killing things as they come. I found joy in death to a surprise attack from a creature I didn't know was there specifically becuase if forced me to pay attention and learn something new.. To look for enemies hanging from rafters ect.. Bows were never necessary either.. Sounds to me like this player got frustrated and gave up on the game and thus made it more difficult by trying to run past everything. This makes it harder not easier.. I will say the life gems make the game to easy, but they also make no bonfire no death runs a joyful possibility.
Also, there was an estus shard in the tutorial area behind the statue. And, there are plenty of branches to spare if you explore and know where to look. I enjoyed the extra puzzle to my game. Another decision of where and when to use a key item changes the adventure. 
Great video! DS2 is my presonal fav. Its not the best at many things that were covered in the video but its the one I find myself playing the most.
snippet.textOriginal:
My opinion, the only reason someone playing scholar would have issues with the ganks is becuase they are trying to rush past them instead of killing things as they come. I found joy in death to a surprise attack from a creature I didn't know was there specifically becuase if forced me to pay attention and learn something new.. To look for enemies hanging from rafters ect.. Bows were never necessary either.. Sounds to me like this player got frustrated and gave up on the game and thus made it more difficult by trying to run past everything. This makes it harder not easier.. I will say the life gems make the game to easy, but they also make no bonfire no death runs a joyful possibility.
Also, there was an estus shard in the tutorial area behind the statue. And, there are plenty of branches to spare if you explore and know where to look. I enjoyed the extra puzzle to my game. Another decision of where and when to use a key item changes the adventure. 
Great video! DS2 is my presonal fav. Its not the best at many things that were covered in the video but its the one I find myself playing the most.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm playing SotFS now and not really noticing much of a difference. I'm an experienced player so I didn't use the Branch in Things Betwixt until later in the game, it gets you a Twinkling Titanite so I considered it worth it. I'm at Drangleic Castle and have unpetrified all the statues so far but one in the Shaded Woods. 
Iron Keep literally teaches you how to use a bow/crossbow. get up on the high platform up the ladder then snipe them all. I kind of like it forces you to use one because I can't think of other Dark Souls games where you need to use a bow. you literally get a +3 Heavy Crossbow in Earthen Peak, you don't even have to upgrade it for it to be viable... Shrine of Amana is yet another example of outsmarting the enemies & is my favorite level because you have to think about your strategy. 
the most annoying thing so far seems to be the extra Red Phantoms, it seems like there are more than in the original version. 2 at the Iron Keep entrance was a bit much with all the other enemies you have to deal with. 
DS2 has always reminded me of Demon Souls, because the environment is the challenge you have to overcome. I understand some people may not like that. the bosses are mostly either a joke or very gimmicky.. thankfully DS3 gave us the best boss battles in the series.

snippet.textDisplay:
yes ds is not a bad game. It is a bad darksouls though. 
I played the original ds2 before playing scholars, and actually that was the first one that i played. The problem with ds2 isnt scholar. It has way too many mobs, (and boring ones in fact), in order to make the game harder, and that is painfully obvious on the dlcs, scholar just made it worse. It has quantity and not quality, and that goes for the bosses too. Many boss fights have you outnumbered in order to seem hard. And the best boss in the game is arguably the pursuer, which is an optional boss, in the start. The bosses dont have a lot to offer, even the good ones which are 3-4. Ds 1 was better, in terms of that aspect and the bosses were slow with simple and had a small moveset too. how did they screw up.
   The areas were cool but being the second game in the franchise it got overshadowed by ds1 which did areas better than perfect. It did introduce a lot of cool things, yes you will have fun playing it. 
  But then you remember the hit boxes which are fine for the most part, then again there are the dlcs. Cool areas again, cool fights, hitboxes on raime get you when youre behind him though.. a least not all the time. And lastly annoying areas, that lead to annoyingly boring  bosses. Yeah im talking about the swamp with the many holes in the ground, that are almost invisible due to the camera and graphics of the time, with the 300 wizards of leonidas, that lead to a frog which im sure was made to be laughed at. And lastly that bull-pig-legless dog-demon... How was he called? Coventus? Im not sure.. the damn thing didnt hit me once, it was just rolling everywere.. i was still... I didnt move... 

Anyway the game is fine, but it has a lot of problems, i wont mention any more negatives i had fun with it. I got to ng+4 with my main, ng+2 eith my second and i also have 2 characters in ng completed. I love it, although its like that son that keeps letting you down.

snippet.textDisplay: So two years ago I was trying to figure out what game I should buy on my PS3, and I never played a Dark Souls game before so I decided to buy and download Dark Souls 2. And by Dark Souls 2 I mean vanilla Dark Souls 2, because on PSN on the PS3 they don't have the Scholar version. Thankfully they have the three DLC but for some reason they don't have Scholar, so this whole time I've been playing the vanilla version of Dark Souls 2. So I don't know if I'm one of the only people to actually still have the vanilla version with the three DLC, and with over 1,000 hours into the game it has strangely become one of my favorite games ever and I don't know why this is. So I don't know if I will ever play Scholar and I don't know if I would want to, maybe I'm just lucky.

snippet.textDisplay: I've been saying this for awhile now. I got both at the same time during a Steam sale, started both, and holy shit the sheer amount of unnecessary bullshit they added to Scholar is obvious during that kind of direct comparison. Some of the levels in vanilla are still, indeed, pretty bullshit, but they aren't Scholar-level bullshit. That stuff wasn't there initially for a reason. DS2 isn't my favorite of the series, and I absolutely hate the mechanics they added (ADP, health penalties etc.) but I'm getting fun out of it, and it has its moments. But Scholar isn't all it's cracked up to be, at least on PC.

snippet.textDisplay:
Watched his unlisted in defense of dark souls 2 video, there is no defense at all so it's kinda click bait. to keep it short: he doesn't like dark souls 2 or scholar because he hates rpg number crunching and is effectively choosing to ignore the rpg part of an rpg. tbh I didn't expect much but the gameplay speaks for itself. 

-using two UGS's that have little to no synergy 
(this one is a nitpick but I couldn't stop laughing whenever I saw him using fume and Ivory ugs's for power stancing, it was honestly just comical.)
-artificially increasing the difficulty by purposefully ignoring the build crafting options
-refusing to take his time in a game series notorious for punishing you for not taking your time and complaining about mob density
-flipping to the other side of the coin and praising dark souls 1 for allowing you to take your time and avoid ambushes 
(used a blatantly favorable example to really sell the switch up.)
-claimed that elden ring bosses had little to no openings 
(used Melania's boss footage to reinforce this while not going for clear openings between her attacks.)
-strongly apposed to the idea of learning more about the game aka not gaining game knowledge to get through certain challenges
-loves the idea of brute forcing a game with the starter weapon and is strongly apposed to changing or experimenting with alternative playstyles
(he claimed to try out a power stanching build and went about it in the worst possible way and didn't actually power stance, instead relying on the Ivory king's ultra great sword two handed move set. 
-claimed that he died to cheap gank squads because his build was sub par and he doesn't like grinding for overpowered stats and gear.
(almost all the gank squads in his footage were artificial and would have been easily avoided by killing the enemies and NOT running through the level.)
-makes multiple claims that the best way to enjoy the game is through rpg hit trading 
-made alot of overall single minded and ass backwards critiques about how ds2 is bad because her can't just brute force it
-constantly flexed that his weapons were op and made the game braindead to him 
(this really hammers home his lack of overall equipment knowledge and build crafting expertise.)

overall, his whole critique seems to be that he enjoys playing weak melee builds and hates ds2 because it punished him for playing in a purposefully self hindering way. On top of all that he has a blatant bias towards rpgs in general and invalidates himself most of the time.

on top of all that his "op power stancing hit trading build" footage just showed how little of an effort he made to attempt the quote on quote "OP" playstyles he complains about hating.

in conclusion: action game level 1 challenge runner complains about an rpg having rpg mechanics and chooses not to adjust.
(also the comments are turned off so that kinda adds a bit of salt to the wound.)

snippet.textDisplay: Here's the thing, you liking DS2 does not make it a good game. DS2 is still a broken mess, and it still spams you with enemies, it still has ADP ,and metric ton of other issues which makes it a terrible game. Some of those are subjective, but most are objective, such as "ADP is unclear in what it does" (people still to this day do not know the extent of its affect), and "the movement is horrendous as it doesn't offer 360 free motion, but rather 8 snap-points for direction". As well as amount of levels, healing, AI, and shitboxes. It might be less terrible than Scholar, but it is still absolutely terrible as a game.

Some of those are subjective, but most are objective, such as "ADP is unclear in what it does" (people still to this day do not know the extent of its affect), and "the movement is horrendous as it doesn't offer 360 free motion, but rather 8 snap-points for direction". snippet.textDisplay: I’ve been playing souls games since the OG release of ds1 and they are still my most played game to date. My opinion on ds2 is that you are basically always meant to fight all the enemies. If you take your time with the levels, you won’t have to deal with anything past a 3v1 in most cases. Running past all the enemies is not an intended strat in this game in my opinion. I view ds2 as the hardest of the dark souls games due to this. There is no level running, and I feel like scholar just attempted to make sure you take your time and clear all the enemies before you go for the boss. There are definitive issues with ds2 but overall you just have to embrace it as a different, slower, and more calculated version of the other games.

snippet.textDisplay:
As someone who only played sotfs, always tries to kill every enemy in every level, just to be able to explore them without being bothered, and as someone who tries to fight enemies slowly, i have to say that, while areas like shrine of amana and iron keep seem to be better in vanilla, if areas like drangleic castle and the catacombs in vanilla are anywhere close to how amana and iron keep are in sotfs, then it doesnt matter how late they are in the game, they are still badly designed.
Multi-fights are one thing when they are well designed, but being rushed by a lot of bodies, even if their attacks are slower than in other souls games, isnt good design, especially when hitboxes and hitreg are as awful as they are in sotfs and when the base moveset of the enemies discourages slow and methodical play, like the amana melee fighters and the iron keep samurai fast running speed into instant attacks, as well as the drangleic elephants and knights massive reach and poise.
Add to that the fact that, even if the wikis tell me i should have more iframes than any other souls game after leveling appropriately,  dodge rolling attacks in 2 just feels awful and inconsistent and i dont see how any kind of gank fight in 2 is supposed to be fun anywhere in the game.
i can subscribe to the idea of vanilla being definitvely better than sotfs, but that would still only make it serviceable at most in my eyes.
snippet.textOriginal:
As someone who only played sotfs, always tries to kill every enemy in every level, just to be able to explore them without being bothered, and as someone who tries to fight enemies slowly, i have to say that, while areas like shrine of amana and iron keep seem to be better in vanilla, if areas like drangleic castle and the catacombs in vanilla are anywhere close to how amana and iron keep are in sotfs, then it doesnt matter how late they are in the game, they are still badly designed.
Multi-fights are one thing when they are well designed, but being rushed by a lot of bodies, even if their attacks are slower than in other souls games, isnt good design, especially when hitboxes and hitreg are as awful as they are in sotfs and when the base moveset of the enemies discourages slow and methodical play, like the amana melee fighters and the iron keep samurai fast running speed into instant attacks, as well as the drangleic elephants and knights massive reach and poise.
Add to that the fact that, even if the wikis tell me i should have more iframes than any other souls game after leveling appropriately,  dodge rolling attacks in 2 just feels awful and inconsistent and i dont see how any kind of gank fight in 2 is supposed to be fun anywhere in the game.
i can subscribe to the idea of vanilla being definitvely better than sotfs, but that would still only make it serviceable at most in my eyes.

snippet.textDisplay:
As someone that actually likes ds2, I don't like scholar the same way. I don't exactly hate it, but it's definitely the worst fromsoft souls title for me.

The petrified statues felt like they'd artificially halt progress and enemy aggression range and number was dialed way up. The increase in number of nonsense even extended to poison pots in earthen peak and tombstones in undead crypt. Ridiculous.

Fortunately, the dlc content was basically left untouched (the only bad stuff there are the dedicated co-op areas, anyway).

snippet.textDisplay:
I honestly never even realized why I was so adamant about telling people that my favorite Dark Souls game is DS2. And after watching both of your videos it's like something switched in my brain, the last puzzle piece fit perfectly.

The reason why I loved DS2 the most is so perfectly explained by you I felt like the video was tailor made for me. It was my first Dark Souls game because I played on a shitty computer and DS1 was gatekeped from me by the shitty port I couldn't play because the framerate was so shit on my shittier computer it was borderline unplayable, so of course, the bias is always going to shift towards the first game in the series. On top of that I played and loved DS2 after it released, no DLC, no bullshit scholar. Nothing. And the funniest thing is I've had to play with a mouse and keyboard because I didn't have a controller, and that was great because of the reason you've explained countless of times - no lock on. Switching targets on lock on with mouse is so painful it's natural to play m&b without lock on, on top of the mouse camera control being so much better it didn't even matter because lock on would just take away one of the few advantages a mouse gave you.

Great video, great review. I feel like a brainlet watching you and hearing you describe stuff that's seemingly obvious yet I couldn't reach the same conclusion without hearing you say it first. Cheers.

Even worse, I think Scholar was probably a lot of peoples introduction to Souls. It was mine, and I quickly fell off of it. It wasn't until I got Bloodborne for free on PS Plus, that it all clicked with me.
I'd just farm those crazy boss runs until enemies stopped respawning, which is very tedious, and leaves the world feeling empty as a result.

snippet.textDisplay: I played and beat scholar. But I personally found it easy. Especially compared to DS1, DS2 and Elden. Because I was always using a heavy weapon and just farming enemies in an area out of existence. As for the tutorial area. I get why they block the final fight off because you have to fight 2 ogres and a ghost knight. You won't win against them early game. So unless you're not farming areas then the game would be hard. But you have to farm if you want to level high enough. Especially in the keep. Those enemies give a lot of souls. As for Vendrick I only once. Didn't care to beat him twice for the ring you get from him. He's just annoying to fight. Now fighting those two annoying cats in the cold wastelands was very hard. half tedious because of how far away and half damn cats move fast. And the life gem is kind of funny. You would get so many of those especially if you're playing with someone that I almost never even used the better life gems. Now kings field can go fuck itself. It was a glitchy poorly programed game.

snippet.textDisplay: I've been playing SotFS as my introduction to Dark Souls 2 and I honestly love it. I've been thinking that this game is way easier than the first Dark Souls, which it totally is. A lot of my deaths have been, in my opinion, my fault. The gang squads have always been my fault for not being meticulous and vigilance. The unlimited healing as given me way too much comfort and peace of mind and the fact that enemies eventually stop respawning really takes a lot of the challenge out of the game like the first one had. In the first game every fuck up and mistake was costly and cost you an Estus Flask. There were many moments in the game where I ran out of charges and had to ask if it was worth venturing into the unknown, when I don't have this area memorized in anyway, and I'm deathly afraid of the enemies and don't want to fight them again with the added pressure of souls being on the line if I die again, and would often just head back and start again and keep doing it until my stupid brain got it right. Not really a big incentive for me to ever try and push on and slug through an area when I know that if I *don't* get it the enemies will eventually stop respawning anyway. I've always been a generalist in games, normally playing to be a decent at everything, but master of nothing so I always clear out every enemy slowly and methodically. That kind of playstyle isn't rewarded in the first Dark Souls while in 2 it very much is. I'm never overwhelmed with too many enemies often, I keeping an eye out for archers all the time and don't mind switching to the bow to clear them out, in fact it's one of my main weapons and I'm constantly stocked on arrows whenever I may need them. Like I said I'm enjoying Dark Souls 2 SotFS very much but the fact it's not an improvement on the first game is very upsetting to me. This game is easy, and the only time I've felt challenged was in the DLC areas but again due to the eventualbility of despawns the challenge doesn't stay for long. All you've done is convinced me to never touch the watered down Vanilla version of this game.

snippet.textDisplay: Man i am currently playing scholar,  and it just feels like they want you to kill the enemies on the boss runs considering their placements..  the red phantoms are downrigth annoying and probably my least favourite part. I am not good at the game, most bosses took atleast 2 tries and also most of them took atleast 6 or 7 tries. Especially the dlc bosses. Ivory king took me like 4-5 hours cause of his fcking pre summon mechanic. But this game is teaching me to play extremely defensive and slow and i kinda like it. Also the branches of yore are actually a mechanic i like. It makes me remember spots to return to and most places you have to use the branches you get one back, atleast from what i remember. What i hate tho about DS2 in general is the amount of 2v1 or 3v1 boss figths, i enjoy 1v1 more as i dont have to focus on 2 or more bosses at once. Obviously more a skill issue but as a monster hunter veteran thats just more of my liking. The only 2v1 figth i enjoyed was the watcher duo. That figth felt fair.  And i mean i played the entirety so far with scythes (as soon as i could get my hands on one) and yes i leveled adp aswell as the other stats but i still struggle alot with the game, but i dont know if i would want to play an easier or more fair version after beating it instead of just replaying with the knowledge gathered of the first playthrough. snippet.textDisplay:
I actually think that Scholar of the First Sin had it's ups and downs. To me, while the ganks were annoying, i did kinda like the new item placements, and some new enemy placements made sense (especially the Dragon by the Cathedral, as it's so close to the Dragonrider, who i figure got their name for a reason!). Also, the new dark areas gave torches more use, in addition to the other features giving reason to backtrack more (but not in any mandatory fashion.)
Also, the ember is actually available early, so i no longer have to mix physical/elemental builds if i don't want to!

The one thing that grinds my gears, though... is that damn statue placement. If they wanted the random statues blocking the ways to make a lick of sense,  and having the petrified bastards look like they were trying to either run from Basilisks or intentionally stuffed in the way to keep intruders out, would have been good.

snippet.textDisplay:
I took a years long break from gaming after Dark Souls 1 for personal reasons and am just now going through Scholar (on the DLC areas now) with no knowledge of original Dark Souls 2 aside from people generally saying it was bad and just skip it for DS3. I'm not having any of the troubles you mention about gank squads, and I'm a glass cannon build with 15 VIG and 8 ADP. Maybe it's because of that, that I take my time through a level learning enemy placement and methodically taking them out a few at a time. You say "some of the ganks could have been prevented if I was more observant", and I think you're right. 

But then you say "The game taught me to run past all the enemies." and there I think you're totally wrong. Many of the areas in the game, including the beginner area of Forest of Fallen Giants where the hollowed enemies are laid out around the tree, teach the player that running through an area is only going to aggro more than a dozen enemies and they won't stop running for you until you're dead. Whereas if you pay attention to your surroundings you'll learn to only wake one at a time and easily dispatch them. The lesson you should have learned is to be more observant and learn how to defeat each enemy as best your build can, without aggroing more enemies than you can handle at a time.

I agree with your analysis of DS1 to DS2 though. DS2 certainly has a lot of flaws and doesn't rank as highly for me as DS1. Scholar does seem to delight in frustrating the player by making them use a rare item when they should've saved it as you mentioned with the Fragrant Branch of Yore - for me it was the Smelter Wedges in The Old Iron King DLC. I used them all and didn't know the last one was after the fight with Sir Alonne. So I had to deal with the npc invaders being healed which sucked, but I got through it by switching my tactics a little bit.
snippet.textOriginal:
I took a years long break from gaming after Dark Souls 1 for personal reasons and am just now going through Scholar (on the DLC areas now) with no knowledge of original Dark Souls 2 aside from people generally saying it was bad and just skip it for DS3. I'm not having any of the troubles you mention about gank squads, and I'm a glass cannon build with 15 VIG and 8 ADP. Maybe it's because of that, that I take my time through a level learning enemy placement and methodically taking them out a few at a time. You say "some of the ganks could have been prevented if I was more observant", and I think you're right. 

But then you say "The game taught me to run past all the enemies." and there I think you're totally wrong. Many of the areas in the game, including the beginner area of Forest of Fallen Giants where the hollowed enemies are laid out around the tree, teach the player that running through an area is only going to aggro more than a dozen enemies and they won't stop running for you until you're dead. Whereas if you pay attention to your surroundings you'll learn to only wake one at a time and easily dispatch them. The lesson you should have learned is to be more observant and learn how to defeat each enemy as best your build can, without aggroing more enemies than you can handle at a time.

I agree with your analysis of DS1 to DS2 though. DS2 certainly has a lot of flaws and doesn't rank as highly for me as DS1. Scholar does seem to delight in frustrating the player by making them use a rare item when they should've saved it as you mentioned with the Fragrant Branch of Yore - for me it was the Smelter Wedges in The Old Iron King DLC. I used them all and didn't know the last one was after the fight with Sir Alonne. So I had to deal with the npc invaders being healed which sucked, but I got through it by switching my tactics a little bit.

snippet.textDisplay: Few things .. 1 the skeleton dragon does still come alive in scholar you have to light all the torches and kill the invaders in which it will come alive and then get you the key to the other doors... I've played and beat every boss in every souls game Bloodborne and elden ring. I went into DS2 scholar as the last game because I knew of the infamy. However after playing it it's really not bad majula is gorgeous the content is full the overwhelming mobs never bothered me because I was always op. Easy and I've dealt with plenty of B's in elden ring and ds3 ds1 and Bloodborne I burned through the bosses like a braindead zombie they were just simplistic except a couple in bloodbournes dlc.. MY BIGGEST ISSUE with DS2 was the slow healing which I don't understand when u chug your estus in literally any other game including ds1 it's a automatic top off in DS2 you stand there for 5 seconds watching it fill up so this was a choice for the devs just cuz🤷‍♂️ and when they remastered it... snippet.textDisplay:
I am of those who made the error of playing Scholar for my first playthrough. All I heard was that SOFTS was THE way to play Dark Souls II, and that it's what every new player should go for. Then when I booted up the game, made my way into the Forest of Fallen Giants, and got wrecked a few times I thought "WOW! They hit harder than I thought, but alright." I chalked it up to Dark Souls being Dark Souls. That right there should have an early red flag for what the rest of the game was going to be like.
Like you, Feeble, by the time I got to the end of the base game I was so drained of everything I had that the mere thought of doing the DLC was enough to make me want to vomit. For some reason, my stubbornness stuck with me, and I couldn't play anything else but this game because I was determined to beat it. I wasn't going to let it get me. After spending 139 hours in Scholar of the First Sin, defeating it completely, I have never been more done with a game like I am with this one.

snippet.textDisplay: Interesting, so the reason I enjoy DS2 Scholar is because I tend to despawn enemies on my way to the boss. Checking the wiki I'm actually still not overleveled for the area, but having defeated each enemy 12 times on that last 12th run I don't even get hit and can dance around them and read their movesets easy, because I feel the game gives me ample reason to stay and dwell longer on them that would be nessesary if they did not despawn. Despawning was cemented for me as a tactic when all Heide knights started butrushing me after the boss. I made a break in Iron Keep though after despawning all 25 or so knights who just come out swarming initially when I finally realised that maybe despawning is not as great a strat as I expected - I assumed the levels will be as interconnected as DS1 so me spending time despawning Forest of Giants will be beneficial once I enter it from some unexpected angle, but alas sadly that won't happen which is a big lost opportunity. Maybe if enemies despawned after like 8 defeats instead and all areas were interconnected it would be working better, as I like the idea of working with limited XP, dealing with permadeath effect of losing souls adding extra weight. Perpamently clearing out ganks would be more rewarding if  those areas were used later in the game for traversal.

snippet.textDisplay:
I don’t really disagree with this video in general, but the whole “you can’t aggro one at a time” thing is just wrong. I’m playing through SotS now and that’s exactly how I’m playing.

Even in areas where they spammed enemies, you can drag them out or funnel them into a bottleneck doorway or something.

Like, yeah. The game is hard when you aggro every enemy in an area and die over and over doing that. You absolutely can pick them off one at a time in areas like No Man’s Wharf.

I feel like anyone who thinks Dark Souls is hard always play by running through areas.

snippet.textDisplay:
I don't get it, man. I've always felt running past enemies was the hardest way to deal with enemies because you're leaving yourself open for things to hit you in the back. I feel like if you're good enough to run past things, you're most likely good enough to deal with the guards aswell. Probably just didn't look hard enough if the ambushes were a consistent problem. Enemies are hidden reasonably well, but not entirely invisible. You will usually find a pair of hands poking up, and if ya just slap them, habibi's likely going to fall to his death. 

Also, tastes may vary xD Couldn't stomach  more than 21 hours of DS1, but got 650 in DS2 and 790 in DS3. DS1 just feels super boring to me.

snippet.textDisplay: Vanilla Dark Souls 2 was my first souls game. I'm almost finished with my second run of the game, and you are so right about the game teaching you at a perfect pace how to survive. My first run was slow going and I did not have a high opinion of it, but once I began to learn combat through the well balanced gameplay, my opinion changed for the better. My second run, certain areas that had me stuck for a while the first time through like no man's wharf and the gutter I just blew through. I highly recommend new souls players that go for 2 first to beeline for heide's tower of flame, the bonfire next to an old knight right at the entrance is the PERFECT place to practice basic controls against large enemies, and the knights drop a good number of souls for early game level ups.

snippet.textDisplay:
The only things I agree with is that the statues are stupid and the game gets a bit easier in the end, but this is something that happens with all souls game and is a mystery to me that they keep making this same "mistake" again. I read an interview with Miyazaki where he said he regretted letting Gwyn being parriable because he was supposed to be the greatest challenge in the game, but then the same happens in every souls game basically. If he wanted to make Gwyn harder he should just make him not parriable and give him twice as much life and increase his damage by 100% and add an area of effect attack like burning everything around him in an explosion that is insta kill if it hits the player. Same thing with Nashandra, just give her 300% more health and make her spam dark novas or make  her curse the player just by standing next to her (what should have been the case anyway for consistency as we get cursed by only getting close to her portrait), so that player needs to time her novas and everything to hit her and not get destroyed lol

Perhaps Soul of Cinder was closer to what Miyazaki envisioned in making Gwyn's fight, but it's still FAR from the hardest boss in the game. It seems they never manage to make the end game the hardest part and it's hard to believe this was unintentional.

In any case, good video. It was funny even if I haven't agreed with everything you said.

snippet.textDisplay:
Highly disagree, dark souls 2 was a good game. But it was a very bad souls game.
I still enjoyed dark souls 2, but I was disappointed with it. If I was to replay any of the dark souls games, it would be dark souls 1 all the way (clearly the hardest of them all, not even close).
Difficulty from hardest to easiest: Dark Souls 1 > Dark Souls 3 > Dark Souls 2

Problems with dark souls 2:

1. Too easy, I completed it in a few days. Compare that to the first Dark Souls, where it took me literally an entire month just to get past ornstein & smough
2. Very clunky combat, dark souls 1 and dark souls 3 combat feels like a breath of fresh air after playing dark souls 2
3. Not directed by miyazaki (and it showed clearly, all of miyazaki's games were miles better)
4. Too many ways to heal yourself outside of estus flasks
5. Fast travel anywhere you want, anytime you want ruined the souls games. Part of what made dark souls 1 so great, was having to backtrack through that 1 area you absolutely hated again to be able to progress. But then you see yourself literally destroying that area, because you are higher level, and you know what to expect, where all the ambushes happen and so on. It gives you that amazing feeling that "I have become so powerful". It makes you really feel how far you have come in this world, and adds to its charm
6. World was less interesting
7. Lore was less interesting

Maybe scholar made it worse (didn't play the dlc's, because of how disappointed I was with the base game) but the game was already ruined day 1 launch.

My first experience of playing a soulslike game was 3-4 months ago in a wooden cabin on a friends Xbox 360 on a shitty TV that had its screen damaged by some other tenant. The game was DS2, while I died A TON, I was having fun, I even got to killing Ornstein.
Then yesterday I tried SOTFS thinking it was the same DS2 I played but with all the DLCs in one package, and I'd be lying if I said it did not feel like the most pathetic game from start till I got to the first turtle knight that stood in place of 2 skeleton knights, or even seeing the ogre in the forest of the fallen, or the 3rd tutorial path being blocked off by some random statue.
In short SOTFS sucky wucky.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is a lot of complaining that I'm just not understanding. 
I've played DS1 once, played a little Elden Ring and then tried SotFS. 
It's fine, it's fun, it's good. 
Yeah, there're loads more enemies than I've faced in other souls games. So? Good! DS1 had me running past enemies because I'd already beat them once, there was no point other than for souls, making the game easier for myself, to kill them. 
In Scholar, I need to fight to explore safely, and that's a real reward. 
I respect your opinion but I can't agree on anything. 

Even the Heide Knights; they're no wear near on the same level as DS1's Dark Knights. They stagger easily, don't drop anything nice and half the time just swing wildly, side to side. They don't even have shields, which isn't an aesthetic comparison but more so that there's no tension to fighting them because you can attack freely. 

The Dark Knights in DS1 weren't even that rewarding to fight; you could grab the loot they were protecting without engaging them, and they didn't drop anything useful unless you had the stats for it; The woods area of DS1, Darkroot Basin(?) where you could grab the shield that raises stamina faster, I didn't even see a knight was there. I grabbed the item, looked at it, equipped it, rolled around to compare the stamina regen, exited the menu and then walked on, and THEN the knight appeared. "Oh, he was supposed to guarding that. Guess I'll just run away." - Yeah, really cool enemy. Better than the Heide Knights for sure, but I think you're purposely giving DS1/2 too much credit just to bash on SotFS.

Around 6:40 you say the Heide Knights placement is equivalent to all the DS1 Dark Knights walking around one room in Anor Londo; One room? You mean one area, since Heide's Tower is an area not a room? Like the White Knights? The White Knights very similar to the Dark Knights? Purposely ignorant and exaggerating. 

7:14 How did you get one shot? You're over level 100, ON NEW GAME PLUS, or at least you've raised the NG area. Heide Knights don't drop that many souls or have that much health ordinarily. Again, you're exaggerating and just misleading the audience. You didn't even get one shot; you got hit three times in a row. Your HP is at the 75% cap but that's pretty ordinary, though I'd question why you're still using that ring in NG+ other than to perhaps purposefully get "one shot" for footage. 

You even said something along the lines of "Dark Souls 1 was a good game with a bad endgame" - What a copout way of dismissing a huge letdown. Dark Souls 1 was great until the endgame, yes, but you can't just pretend the endgame isn't a part of it. That's like me saying "SotFS is a great game with bad enemy placement". No. It's a game, that has "bad", or at least questionable by the community, enemy placement, and that enemy placement affects the overall game, just like Lost Izalith makes DS1 worse. You can't pick on one game for one thing and then dismiss it in another game. 

You're also purposefully treating the imaginary "new player" like an idiot. 6:21 - No, there is no forced 1v20; one, because there aren't 20 enemies that anyone would run past (There're 16 on screen from what I counted, and providing this is your footage you've gathered them on purpose just to exaggerate, which you do a lot, just pulling numbers from thin air) and two, these enemies are all downed when you see them. Yes, I've seen players get spooked by the enemies getting up off-screen, but not to an extent where they'd run around the entire tree gathering 16 of them before noticing, especially when you consider you have to stand still to pick up items, and players are likely to look up at the enemy throwing firebombs. The time spent standing still would give the enemies time to reach the player, who would then realise "Oh, the enemies are coming from somewhere", if they somehow before that saw no enemies get up on screen. Of course people will struggle with SotFS if they're the make-believe idiots you're inventing. 

Again, I respect your opinion if you don't like SofFS, but dude, if you're gonna try justifying that opinion, at least try to base it on something real instead of just making stuff up for effect. This and your other video combined just seem like huge baby rage posts that I'd expect to see on Reddit.

snippet.textDisplay: I definitely still love the game and have fun with it, but I definitely think it's the hardest Dark Souls for the wrong reasons. My head canon is Namco said "They love Dark Souls cause hard, so make 2 even harder!" and that was their #1 priority. It feels like the entire game just wants to make your life as miserable as possible. How the estus is slow as molasses. You don't get i-frames when entering a fog wall and it takes 50 years to do so. The fact there are 10enemies in every room with another 10 waiting to make an appearance until you aggro them, including 3 unreachable bowmen. The list just goes on. I do remember Shrine of Amana and Lost Sinner were pretty hard for me in vanilla when the game released (I believe they nerfed both). But I was younger and worse at games.

snippet.textDisplay:
They're the same games. I'd still tell someone to buy Scholar for 20-30$ over Vanilla + DLC for 40-60$. The ganks in Iron keep suck, but enemies eventually stop spawning if you kill them 15 times. I did this and was properly leveled by the end. 
The simple fact is that enemy placement meant nothing since the fog wall and doors had no I frames (except for Temple of Amana). DS1 had very similar enemy placement and ganks for runbacks to bosses or doors. O&S had the giant knights, Capra demon, Fire Sage Demon, Gwyne, Nito, Seeth, and so on all had many enemies right before the fog wall. You could just run past them tho, because as long as you got to the fog wall, you were fine (most of the time, sometimes an enemy with a long weapon poked you before the fight started). 
This small changed ruined several areas in DS2 in both versions.
snippet.textOriginal:

The simple fact is that enemy placement meant nothing since the fog wall and doors had no I frames (except for Temple of Amana). O&S had the giant knights, Capra demon, Fire Sage Demon, Gwyne, Nito, Seeth, and so on all had many enemies right before the fog wall. snippet.textDisplay:
A bit late to the party but a few things.

1) Dark Souls 2 has more effective weapons than either of the other 2, fisting with caesti is actually viable.
2) The most bullshit parts of the DLC are meant to be played in coop, that's why players can be summoned to those areas even from outside DLC even if the summonees themselves don't have the DLC. Doesn't make frigid outskirts any less bullshit but at least they had an idea why they made it bullshit.
3) The DLC have the best map design of all of Dark Souls 2, even rivaling that of DkS1 and that's what makes them amazing, the optional coop boss runs suck ass (as mentioned before) but base parts of the DLC are just vanilla but better.
4) Scholar statues are the dumb
5) Scholar at least has working darkness, a torch is sometimes actually useful in it.

And yes, I played vanilla on release and the DLC in order before playing scholar. With 584 hours in vanilla+DLC and 156 hours in Scholar, so I suppose I agree that Scholar is the lesser of the two versions.
snippet.textOriginal:
A bit late to the party but a few things.

1) Dark Souls 2 has more effective weapons than either of the other 2, fisting with caesti is actually viable.
2) The most bullshit parts of the DLC are meant to be played in coop, that's why players can be summoned to those areas even from outside DLC even if the summonees themselves don't have the DLC. Doesn't make frigid outskirts any less bullshit but at least they had an idea why they made it bullshit.
3) The DLC have the best map design of all of Dark Souls 2, even rivaling that of DkS1 and that's what makes them amazing, the optional coop boss runs suck ass (as mentioned before) but base parts of the DLC are just vanilla but better.
4) Scholar statues are the dumb
5) Scholar at least has working darkness, a torch is sometimes actually useful in it.

And yes, I played vanilla on release and the DLC in order before playing scholar. With 584 hours in vanilla+DLC and 156 hours in Scholar, so I suppose I agree that Scholar is the lesser of the two versions.

...I have never played vanilla DS2, but I freaking loved SOTFS. I don't recall thinking it had excessive cheap deaths compared to, say, Demon's Souls, which was the only souls game I had played previously (I somehow skipped DS1). I should play it again, I think! I might try vanilla but I'm afraid I would just be disappointed by how few enemies it sounds like there are in, like, the first half of the game.

snippet.textDisplay: That was really interesting to hear. I ended up rage quitting DS2 when I stupidly died before getting the after-boss bonfire in Heide. As a result, my only option was to trek through the area again, but with the damn Heide Knights awake and out for blood -- and I really sucked at fighting them. It seemed to me that they had a few common attacks that weren't telegraphed very much. Combine that with the hollowing mechanic sapping my max life away with each death and it becomes clear why I gave up. Git gud, yeah. I've finished DS1 and 3 and Elden Ring, but Scholar just kicked my ass. Maybe I should get vanilla and run it with DS2fix or something. Even better would be if there were a mod for Scholar to de-Scholar it.

snippet.textDisplay: As someone who only knows SotFS and likely won't play Vanilla, I wish I could try it out. I slogged through most of SotFS with a friend which helped but man all the enemy groups are insane in some places. Just enemy after enemy. I basically had to use the despawn mechanic by killing everything in an area over and over again until they stopped spawning when I rested, which is probably the only saving grace but still stupid. At lvl 130 I still haven't beat the game cause I needed a break from the frustration. Yet I still enioy it overall cause DS is just a solid series. I also liked the Bonfire Aesthetic mechanic (not sure if it's in DS1) since you can basically use it to get high level items from bosses and more souls from enemies. However, when trying to get to Freya for the Moonlight GS soul it was so insanely maddening having to fight a room full of highly agile spiders that are literally RIGHT NEXT TO THE BONFIRE.
snippet.textOriginal: As someone who only knows SotFS and likely won't play Vanilla, I wish I could try it out. I slogged through most of SotFS with a friend which helped but man all the enemy groups are insane in some places. Just enemy after enemy. I basically had to use the despawn mechanic by killing everything in an area over and over again until they stopped spawning when I rested, which is probably the only saving grace but still stupid. At lvl 130 I still haven't beat the game cause I needed a break from the frustration. Yet I still enioy it overall cause DS is just a solid series. I also liked the Bonfire Aesthetic mechanic (not sure if it's in DS1) since you can basically use it to get high level items from bosses and more souls from enemies. However, when trying to get to Freya for the Moonlight GS soul it was so insanely maddening having to fight a room full of highly agile spiders that are literally RIGHT NEXT TO THE BONFIRE.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ok, enough. You are the third person to make this critique and I'm sick of hearing it. Dark Souls 2 is not unfun because people don't know how to turn off the lock-on feature. I don't know why Joseph Anderson thought that criticism made any sense, then HBomberGuy copied that criticism because he's a brainless moron and he was desperate for arguments in favor of his beloved bad game, and now here we are with YOU once again resurrecting this tired, bizarre criticism. DS2 is not a bad game ONLY for people who don't realize that clicking in the right stick while locked on can turn the lock-on off. I understand how the lock-on feature works, I turn it off sometimes, and other times I leave it on even when fighting groups. So does Jospeh Anderson, so does HbomberGuy, and so do you. There are way more enemy groups in Bloodborne, DS3, and Elden Ring, and yet people don't hate THOSE games like they hate DS2. And no, those games never have tutorials that explain that you can fight without lock-on. It's a moronic criticism, it makes ZERO sense, and you people need to stop using it. Nothing against you personally. I don't know anything about your content; I'm just sick of this bizarre insult disguised as criticism. You're literally saying "Look, I'm sure it IS tough to like a game when you're stupid and don't realize this very basic aspect of the game, but if you knew how to play, you'd probably like the game more!" Every FromSoft game after Dark Souls 2 has MORE group encounters and they NEVER teach you to lock off in those games, yet people had no complaints about groups in THOSE games. Come on. Use your noggin here.

People don't hate DS2 because they lack basic critical thinking skills. They hate DS2 because there's no inspiration in the characters, the story, the lore, the levels, or the weapons. The animations in particular are painfully amateurish. Part of the appeal of DS1 was how realistic all the weapons felt, and then in DS2 most of the weapons are swung haphazardly with what feels like zero effort from the chosen undead, like he's lazily swinging around a limp noodle. It's laughable to imagine that half of the weapon swing animations would do any damage to the enemies with how weak they look. There's no feeling of progression, the enemy design sucks, none of the weapons look cool, and nothing that happens in the game makes any sense. THOSE are some of the reasons DS2 sucks. It's still a game with the souls mechanics, so it's still a solid 5.5/10 and I enjoy the simple act of running through the game and genociding the enemies, but it's not what I would call a GOOD game. And it would be a bad game even without the gank squads or increased reliance on annoying groups of enemies. ALSO, as MauLer pointed out in his novella on DS2, you can't just turn off the lock-on in every scenario. Using a rapier without lock-on makes it SUPER difficult to aim your attacks in an effective manner. Also, as one final point, it's not even remotely difficult to fight multiples while locked-on. That's probably why you and Hbomb and Joseph all do that even though you claim you don't.

snippet.textDisplay:
I now see why I didn't like scholar. Just felt like it wasn't right, and now this video has shown my intuition valid.

The petrified statues are a good example, as dark souls makes progression fairly straight forward, if a little cryptic, but doesn't really obviously block your way like you need a red then a blue then a yellow key card, essentially the same solution to a repeating, boring problem. The problem resolutions are usually unique and change with each area. Progression is a question of adventure and not 'get this item, but it's rare, expensive, and you could soft lock yourself'. Dark souls will usually let you fight and advance and adventure well beyond your level if you've got the courage and/or skill to attempt it. Stopping you from dying unnecessarily seems the antithesis of dark souls. Who dares wins. The tag line for dark souls 1 was 'prepare to die'.

snippet.textDisplay: Good video. I picked up DSII SOTFS after finishing Dark Souls Remastered on Switch (which I absolutely LOVED) and I am freaking TIRED of SOTFS. I bought a PS5 to play DSII, DSIII, ER, Sekiro, BB, etc. and jesus is this game testing my patience. It's kinda fun and all but it gets really tiring after having to clear for the fifth fucking time the Iron Keep (and 5 times is an understatement), or even the DLC's. In fact I don't ever remember raging in Dark Souls one, not with Artorias, not with Manus (I beat them all at like the 3rd try because I got very comfortable in late game) and for example Kalameet felt like a challenge but I don't remember actually raging, DS1 is a brilliant game which teaches you to be good and precise, SOTFS is just BS after BS after BS, I don't think I'm gonna finish everything, I don't have time for that. And to finish off, Iron passage, Shrine of Amana or whatever felt like a chore and they physically stressed me out. Look it's fun and all but I don't wanna spend my damn time picking enemies off with bow and arrow. Fuck this game lmao

It's kinda fun and all but it gets really tiring after having to clear for the fifth fucking time the Iron Keep (and 5 times is an understatement), or even the DLC's.
