snippet.textDisplay:
I disagree that the intent was to make money quick. If that was the whole point they'd just do what they had done with Dark Souls """Remastered""" and DS3: The Fire Fades Edition, release the regular game with all DLC bundled for more sales. Scholar, awful as it may be, put way more effort in by making changes that they NEVER had to if they just wanted money.

As you pointed out, people loved the DLC and praised it to high heaven while having issues with the base game. The DLC is where there was a lot of ganking, strange puzzles and unfair design/enemy placement, yet everyone loved it. So, I believe they misunderstood WHY people liked the DLC and added all these things into the base game through Scholar.

You almost had the narrative right, but it's nonsensical for them to do more work if their goal is to simply make a quick buck (especially when they've shown a willingness to do the bare minimum in other cases).

snippet.textDisplay:
PSA:
You are not supposed to run towards the tail in the ancient dragon boss fight! Idk who started this trend because since when has going for a dragons tail ever helped in any dragon fight in souls games? Go for the head and front legs and when he flies up runaway from the head ( not towards the tail) and then go back when hes done. Definitely not a good boss fight but i dont find it so bad when you go for the head and not the tail. its a 5/10 for me.

But yeah i actually never played the vanilla version. I didnt have enough money and i bought DS2 on steam and it only costed 10 dollars (scholar version plus the 3 dlcs) so i never bothered to buy the original. Now that i watch this video it definitely makes me wonder if the original is really that better!
Nice vid and i love the hollow knight music!
Merry Christmas Everyone! :)

snippet.textDisplay:
I was very poor for a long time and only had access to vanilla DS2 even well into DS3's release.
Eventually I managed to get a PC and have all three games.
Scholar is just dumb man. Like, the item locations are fair enough for a change, but the amount of extra enemies actively works against their own AI.
Those katana wielding knights before smelter demon?, they keep fucking pushing each other off the bridge if you position yourself right. Their AI is straight up not designed for the amount of them there is, and it either leads to a ridiculous spam of enemies, or a bunch of them dying because you stood in "the spot" and they just don't understand spacing or how many of them there's meant to be.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
I had the opposite reaction; I played Vanilla DS2 for about 200 or so hours according to steam, and then later on scholars for another 350+ hours. (IIRC Vanilla also contains the time for the DLCs, since, if I remember correctly, I also bouth the DLCs seperately (too poor for a season pass back then)).
Still, I remember that I liked Scholars much, much more. Maybe because I played Vanilla already for quite a while, maybe because I played many segments with a friend, yet I wouldn't want to play DS2 without Scholars any longer.
It is a little bit harder, I agree - especially for beginners, at the start, where you have a couple of fights against the "Pursuer" or "Chaser" or however you translate his name, yet it's also just.. feeling better.
If you suck with normal enemies, all I can say is the same that the whole DS Community always said if you bitched about the difficulty: Git gud.

I like this video, but I have some objections/remarks to it:

19:10  - It`s not true. I`m personaly tried this on Scholar version, and it`s worked for me. Just need to remember, that you need ONE million more soul memory in first walkthrough, TWO million on NG+, THREE million on NG++ and so on, at the same time souls that collected on previous walkthroughs are NOT COUNTED.

19:25 - Dragon can come back to live, but you need to light some tourches in the location, with one hidden in count.

30:55 - they have a reason, developers placed it in their armor description, in which they referencing to Heide (Heid Tower location).
snippet.textOriginal:

no, it's the same game with a few edits, I agree some of them feel a bit dumb though, but the overall difference isn't that big. 
cash grab? how about elden ring?
and most importantly: the original ds2 only had ONE (morally suffocating) ending. there have to be two, it's a golden standard. like the moonlight sword originating from king's field. I completed softs after vanilla just to see the other ending and it was way way way worth it. 
personally I think I love ds2 more than any other from game, including elden ring (how shockingly glimmering, shiny, sweet and dull it is... I hope they'll drop this open world idea and won't continue to descend to generic fantasy).
it's surprising to read comments like "it's too difficult". it's dark souls man, it has to be very difficult, that's the catch.

snippet.textDisplay: See, my experience went like this. I tried DS1, but hated it. I made it to Sen's Fortress and quit. I wrote off all the DS games until Elden Ring was announced in development. Around that time all the games (1 Remaster, Scholar, and 3) went on sale. A friend talked me into buying them all, and we ran through Scholar together (the whole game and DLC, did the whole thing together). This time, for whatever reason, I liked it. I started 1 again and beat it, but I didn't really enjoy it. I then played 3, and loved it. Soon after I got a PS5, and did the Demon's Souls Remake and Bloodborne 100% (everything past 2 I played alone). I always heard how horrible DS2 was, and Scholar in particular, but I really liked it. Still haven't played the vanilla version, and I did eventually do NG+ and all the DLCs alone. Honestly, I still think DS1 is the worst. You move too slow, and there's just something about it I really don't like. DS3 or Bloodborne are probably tied for first and second, with Elden Ring coming up 3rd. I'd say Scholar is 4th, then Demon's Souls, then DS1 last.

snippet.textDisplay:
The biggest crime of Scholar was how they announced it right after only just releasing the last DLC for the original. To me this seemed like a negligent way to treat the fans that bought their content day one. It's true that for the Steam version they released Scholar at a discounted price for people that already had vanilla but that was regardless of whether you had already bought the DLC. In terms of multiplayer the vanilla DLC was made redundant almost straight out of the gate because most people were migrating to Scholar.

Furthermore the 360/PS3 release of Scholar didn't even have the rearranged enemy placements. It was basically just added Aldia's ending and had a few patch-like tweaks. You might say that 360/PS3 Scholar is more like the most complete version of Vanilla. But with no discount available to vanilla owners and a 30 fps cap, it was all the more of a poor investment for those who already owned vanilla on those consoles.

snippet.textDisplay:
I may have started out with S.O.T.F.S and enjoyed it, but i can see your point on this Topic.(i also never played the Vanilla version and don't feel like doing it) 

There really is a Ton of Enemies and you potentially die a lot in this Game, but this isn't entirely bad because it thought me to be cautious and witty in my approach, as well as being aware of my surroundings as much as possible. 

I usually avoided going against several enemies at once if they where strong enough to pose a serious Threat and i also never viewed Dark Souls as a "multi-combat simulator", but as a Game that requires you to think differently and adapt, in order to overcome what seems impossible. 

(the heinous amount of Enemies also made it easy to occasionally farm lots of souls, if it was necessary. BUT..; the SOTFS is an absolute time-killer, not gonna lie. I spent well over 200 hours in this game by beating it and it's DLCs once. I should also mention that i spent quite some time farming here and there as well as discovering any secret or item in the game. That naturally consumed lots of Time.) 


...I also wouldn't say that you need overpowered builds in order to do it solo. (unless a "Quality-Build" is something to be considered OP) 

However... 

I may not share your opinion, but i can kind of empathize with the Fact, that you feel somewhat left behind by the Devs, because these Changes basically made your playstile as unviable as possible, which kind of ruined the Game for you.

snippet.textDisplay: About the only true improvement SOTFS added, to me, was putting the keys to the DLC areas in the game world to be found rather than dumped in your inventory at the very start like some common... Bethesda DLC.  Beyond that, I used Steam's built in "dead zone" alteration to fix the dead zone issues in DS2.  Frankly, it's a much more enjoyable game now.  Not perfect.  I have a list of fixes I'd apply if they did a re-re-master.  But, enjoyable enough to work into my playthroughs of the series.

snippet.textDisplay: Vanilla DS2 was my third souls game (played them all as soon as each game released), but it still remains my favourite in the whole series. It has problems, sure. Every Dark Souls game has. But DS2 just has so many things done right and in many ways feels superior to the first game... to me. SOTFS on the other hand has a couple of good improvements (DLC key placement, No Man's Barf shortcut to the ship, and other minor things), but at the same time it outright ruined A LOT of things compared to the original game. I always strongly advise against playing SOTFS before completing vanilla. It's more like another level of NG+ rather then a way to get to know the game. Your video is yet another confirmation to that.
snippet.textOriginal: Vanilla DS2 was my third souls game (played them all as soon as each game released), but it still remains my favourite in the whole series. It has problems, sure. SOTFS on the other hand has a couple of good improvements (DLC key placement, No Man's Barf shortcut to the ship, and other minor things), but at the same time it outright ruined A LOT of things compared to the original game. snippet.textDisplay: I love DSII, but everyone is entitled to their opinions. No need for backlash, just pushes those who don’t like it even farther away. There are things DSII introduced that changed the franchise for the good forever and I personally loved even more than the things they added which stayed in future games. I always try to highlight the good things it introduced, but there are definitely things done wrong in the game, and it, rightly so, isn’t for everyone. I feel similarly to how you do on DS3 and people love that game. I have hundreds, if not over a thousand hours in 3 and still wouldn’t say I like it overall 🤣. All achievements and I find it’s faults overwhelming. Opinion is opinion and we’re all allowed them, lesson of this comment, find what you like and don’t shove it down others throats. Same goes for things you don’t like.

snippet.textDisplay: I see your point but I sort of disagree. I played DS2 when it first came out and loved it. When scholar came out I played that and loved it even more (may or may not be because of the changes made). I took a different approach than you though, when I play scholar I play very slowly, methodically, and patiently. Checking out an area before running through, looking for enemies on ledges, etc. with the intent of clearing out areas and exploring/collecting everything. It's a playstyle that some may not like, and can get boring when you want a fast-paced action duel, but I find it fun. It also adds more tension as you expend more items and risk more souls on death, also respawning enemies. One smaller but still important change I liked was the Ancient Dragon area. Some simple changes gave it so much more character and memorability.

snippet.textDisplay:
Personally I do actually think Dark Souls 2 is better than 1. It's personal preference of course but still, 1 is definitely bottom tier for me.
2 has more bosses I like (which isn't much since 1 only has two and a half bosses I like, one of them DLC), I prefer its healing system (I just think it's really annoying when I'm doing a run to a boss and know I'm not gonna beat it even before I reach the boss room because I already used up half my healing. It's not perfect and DS3 fixed 1's issues via better level design instead which I prefer to 2's healing), speaking of: I *especially* prefer the level design (the level design is the reason for why I quit DS1 after Taurus Demon and 2's level design is what made me actually start liking the franchise), the story is *a lot* better (no, seriously, it's *so* much better. That moment when you walk in on Vendric and realise he's lost his mind is still one of the best moments in FromSofts's library. While the rest of the video is pretty bullshit I do think that Hbomberguy's "In Defence of Dark Souls 2" video's story section is spot on, Dark Souls 1's story is mostly lore whilst Dark Souls II has an actual narrative which I find much more compelling), and I find fighting to be less annoying in 2 than in 1 (emphasis on less, Bloodborne and Dark Souls 3 are where the fighting *stopped* being annoying to me and became more fun, Bloodborne especially. pls FromSoft make another game with its combat system)
Oh, I also had to use a guide far less with 2 than I did with 1. Largely thanks to the level and map design

All in all, while I'm not the biggest fan of Dark Souls 2 it is still the game that got me to like the series after 1 had driven me away for several years because it wasn't fun to me. I still don't find Dark Souls 1 fun and whilst Dark Souls 2 is a bit boring to me these days, especially after experiencing 3 and Sekiro and seeing how great Bloodborne is (would love to play it some day), 2 is still a game that I actually had fun with and liked when I first played it.
Oh, also, I never finished 2 so my personal experience with actually playing the game stops before the half way point. I still feel like I can translate my experiences with the early game and figure out how I'd feel with late game bosses etc

snippet.textDisplay:
I feel like the little tweaks in scholar are, most of the time, improvements to the level and enhance the experience since DS2 is more strategic, it demands more adaptability from you, not the stat, I mean true adaptability and to think before run into a crowd area. It takes more seriously the punishment for dying and the aggresivity of the enemies to incentivice a metodical approach.

DS2 isn't perfect, is very flawed but most of the time I see someone complaining about ds2, scholar or vanilla, the gameplay on the background is the same, people running into a gank or getting teleported by a grab (granted the bad hitboxes are bs). Now listen, I'm not saying you are playing the game wrong, but certainly you are making it way harder than it has to be by just trying to literally skip the game, not be the best solution for the specific challenges DS2 gives you. Adaptability is the key, again, not the stat, my first time fighting an ambuish was dumb, but after 20 ambushes you should be expecting them instead of jumping into maybe even more ambushes.

DS3 has a lot more ganks but more scripted and harder to avoid and DS1 has some weird hitboxes sometimes too, the difference with DS2 is how it wants you to take it slower, to retreat if you are having problems, not trying to pass everything like if it was DS1 or spam attacks and dodges like in DS3. Sometimes it works sometimes don't but then again, is a flawed game and just like the other souls DS2 is not a game for everyone, you don't have to like it as much as the others, but saying the scholar version ruined the game its an exaggeration, just made it harder for your playstyle, Scholar is not perfect either, but even if turns DS2 into a worst DS1, imo made it a better DS2.

snippet.textDisplay:
I exclusively play DaS2 v1.0. It's just good. 

The kinds of builds you can make are amazing, and the "souls economy" is booming. Miracle builds are amazing. You can make a fast-rolling, hex-casting Havel. You can do a lightning-STR build. You can just run around with 2 daggers (I prefer one lightning, one dark) and do backstabs. With the 3rd person bow-cam, you can do ranged builds in boss fights, especially ranged poison builds. 

 People hated ADP, but leveling it up enough gives you a massive amount of I-Frames. There are like 7 roll speeds. Bonbfire ascetics really help you power level (Old Iron King) and gain NG+ equipment early. Also, NG+ is actually different and a challenge with new surprises. 

It's my favorite Souls game, even more than Bloodborne.

snippet.textDisplay: In MY personal approach in playing souls games, i don't skip killing enemies, i don't move from one area to another till i've hacked and slashed my way through everything, i can't understand how you can complain about the game being harder when you're Iron with a broadsword, it honestly feels like you're making it harder for yourself my guy. I've never personally felt that any area was difficult in any souls game EXCEPT , ringed city in DS3 , frigid outskirts and shrine of amana in DS2 SOTFS and blight town in DS1 kind of.

snippet.textDisplay:
lol you're just impatient and whiny. the reason DS2 isn't as good as DS1 or 3 isn't that it's harder--it isn't. it's the easiest FromSoft game i've played (and i've only played SotFS)--it's how generic it feels. the fact that so many bosses just look like fancy knights in bulky suits of armor, and the level design is bland, nothing in the world feels connected to anything else, etc. just, generally mediocre design choices.

i never had any of the problems you described...i didn't die at all in No Man's Wharf, because, you know...i wasn't impatient. you're trying to run past enemies in every clip you showed, of course they killed you! you can't run past enemies in Dark Souls games; DS1 should have taught you that! the key to all FromSoft games is patience and taking your time clearing out an area rather than trying to run through. if you try to run through, you die. that's a lesson i learned in the Undead Burg.

i didn't like the Iron Keep that much, not because it was hard--it wasn't--but because it felt like a generic Zelda fire dungeon. i got through it pretty easily tho 🤷‍♀️

snippet.textDisplay: I just finished Scholar about an hour ago and i've got to say I agree with a lot of this (even if I haven't played Vanilla yet). Iron Keep and Amana was a complete mess IMO. I usually don't use a bow in Dark Souls games because it just isn't my play style. I like to use a shield and a sword.. and that's it. But in these two areas I felt like if I didn't use a bow to pick up the attention of some enemies, it would be impossible to get through the areas. Another aspect is that the bosses simply aren't that difficult. I did my whole playthrough with a Scimitar which was my starting weapon and when I got it to +10, I could easily melt bosses with spamming, and just going around them and hitting the legs and or the back. I still think Scholar isn't a bad game. I've enjoyed my time with the game and I'm happy I didn't skip DS2 as many people said to me before.
snippet.textOriginal: I just finished Scholar about an hour ago and i've got to say I agree with a lot of this (even if I haven't played Vanilla yet). Iron Keep and Amana was a complete mess IMO. I usually don't use a bow in Dark Souls games because it just isn't my play style. I like to use a shield and a sword.. and that's it. But in these two areas I felt like if I didn't use a bow to pick up the attention of some enemies, it would be impossible to get through the areas. Another aspect is that the bosses simply aren't that difficult. I did my whole playthrough with a Scimitar which was my starting weapon and when I got it to +10, I could easily melt bosses with spamming, and just going around them and hitting the legs and or the back. I still think Scholar isn't a bad game. I've enjoyed my time with the game and I'm happy I didn't skip DS2 as many people said to me before.

snippet.textDisplay:
If you want to know something funny, most of the map changes that screwed the player in Scholar are actually very similar to the optmized(ish) route the players had made early on in DS2. I'd reccomend checking the oldest Let's Play of Dark Souls 2 by Northernlion, notice the path he makes and then see how most of them have turned obsolete by the changes in Scholar. 
They didn't just randomly add more mobs, they added mobs where people found convenient to move just for the sake of making those areas harder - it's like if Dark Souls Remastered placed 5 basilisk where you could do a dragon-butt skip in painted world.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: I cannot agree more with the vast majority of this video. Another thing that pissed me off about scholar was that it made my collectors edition strat guide worthless. Ill admit that most players may not agree, but i deeply enjoyed getting the guide on launch night and as a new area name would appear with the new area sound que, i would find the nearest bonfire and the pull up that area in the guide and look through the item list for that area. The reason i did this is that if there is a weapon or armor set i want in this area, i can explore that area until i find it before moving on to get maximum enjoyment out of the game. But scholar said “nah we are going to change around a bunch of shit including important items like estus shards so now that nice book is worthless and wrong”

snippet.textDisplay:
Maybe I’m a freak, but I’m playing through scholar right now and enjoying myself. Iron keep wasn’t too bad but the packed enemies around smelter demons area was suuuper annoying, fortunately I had barely enough stats to use a short bow and some kiting. Shrine of amana sucked. That area is horribly designed and whoever keeps bringing back the poison swamps is now a saint compared to whoever decided to create Scholar Shrine of Amana. but I found a glitch to make it much more bearable, so those zones aren’t really something that come to mind anymore when I think back on the game.

But yeah, vanilla does seem much more fun to actually play.

Edit: Skipping the beginning once you have 1million being removed in scholar is untrue. I’ve done it once when I first got the game and the only version I’ve played is scholar

snippet.textDisplay:
At first I thought this video was too much and an attempt at an edgy joke, as critics almost unanimously defend SOFTS as 'the absolute and improved version'; but, for some reason, I decided to test DS2 Vanilla after watching the video and I can say that my experience was very similar.

Until watch this video I had only played DS2 SOFTS for the same reason as the author of the video, convinced that it was better, and I thought the game was actually much worse than the average DS1 and DS3 and other recent fromsoft games, but everything that is analyzed in video is real: DS2 Vanilla is a pretty decent game. I hated every run I did on the DS2 SOFTS and had it to myself that as an 'improved version' the DS2 Vanilla should be a resounding flop, complete crap.

But, now I have for myself that the DS2 Vanilla was simply wronged; it's not as good as the DS1, ok, and the expectations at launch were high, but it's a good game, even a decent Soulsborne: good levels, good progression, some fun maps... and SOFTS, which supposedly 'fixes ' the game spoiled all that in its idea of ​​being completely crazy, making ambushes and unnecessary gang fights, with a thousand underused areas and simply LOADED with enemies everywhere.

Anyway, I can now agree 300% with the video: DS2 is MUCH better in its vanilla version.
snippet.textOriginal:
At first I thought this video was too much and an attempt at an edgy joke, as critics almost unanimously defend SOFTS as 'the absolute and improved version'; but, for some reason, I decided to test DS2 Vanilla after watching the video and I can say that my experience was very similar.

Until watch this video I had only played DS2 SOFTS for the same reason as the author of the video, convinced that it was better, and I thought the game was actually much worse than the average DS1 and DS3 and other recent fromsoft games, but everything that is analyzed in video is real: DS2 Vanilla is a pretty decent game. I hated every run I did on the DS2 SOFTS and had it to myself that as an 'improved version' the DS2 Vanilla should be a resounding flop, complete crap.

But, now I have for myself that the DS2 Vanilla was simply wronged; it's not as good as the DS1, ok, and the expectations at launch were high, but it's a good game, even a decent Soulsborne: good levels, good progression, some fun maps... and SOFTS, which supposedly 'fixes ' the game spoiled all that in its idea of ​​being completely crazy, making ambushes and unnecessary gang fights, with a thousand underused areas and simply LOADED with enemies everywhere.

Anyway, I can now agree 300% with the video: DS2 is MUCH better in its vanilla version.

It sounds like you’re predisposed to running past enemies in the first place. The coolest change in DS2 for me was the enemies despawning after 7 or so kills. I was lucky enough to discover it naturally on my first playthrough because I really wanted that Old Heide armour set. So while I did get impatient and run past enemies to get to a boss quicker sometimes, there was also that alternate option: I could take a break from boss progression to spend a little time grinding and despawn some enemies along the path.
All that is to say: git gub scrub lmao

snippet.textDisplay: i logged about 500 hrs on both vanilla and scholar. I prefer scholar because it was a gruelling gauntlet. vanilla was a picnic i barely remember. Myazaki did not make DS2, it was never his vision of difficulty, he just came in after making bloodborne and added the scholar dlc to try and give the fans what they were asking for at the time, which was more difficulty and better bosses. vanilla had 50% of it's game content cut pre release. that tunnel in the hub area, led to an underground area that spanned the entire game world, and it was all cut which made the world feel disjointed. you can cheese fume knight, you can respec over and over, you can use a heavy armor set and shield and tank all but 1 attack from sir alonne no problem. the only true cancer of ds2 was the trek through the 3 gauntlets to get to shadowlurker boss.

snippet.textDisplay:
Scholar _did_ fix a couple things..!

The fact that only "tangible" one I can remember off-hand is that Spiders are afraid of the torch, making Freja less annoying, especially in NG+ and beyond... Doesn't speak all too well of those "fixes".

Scholar's lighting also looks absolutely atrocious, to me. Everything looks so faded and over-exposed, where the hell is all the contrasting colors what made this game stand out?! At least I know where DS3 got its ashen-ass from.

That being said, my new favorite way to play this game, is actually the 'Seeker of Fire' mod. A lot of really fun level changes, big and small. As would become a trend for basically all Souls games including Elden Ring already, I can hardly go back after getting a taste of modding. This community can make some amazing things.

snippet.textDisplay:
I like DS2 because it has the best magic system by far. Running around with spell caster in the off hand and a buffable sword in main hand never gets old for me. Ds2 is by far my most played game of the DS series. It's just fun to replay. 

Also I can snipe the archers with binoculars because the soul arrow and the hex poison mist is really long range in that game.

Personally, I really miss the old magic system of 'so many casts per spell'. It felt good to try and manage your spells for both long term fights such as bosses and short term fights like killing fodder along the way.

Ds1 is the best game narratively, imo. And Ds3 is the easiest to get into, imo. But Ds2 is the most fun to experiment in and screw around with no particular goals in mind. I will also say that Ds2 is my favorite dark souls to co-op with my friends with. With the combo of the large and small soap stones, you can practically do the entire game the entire way with a friend.

Personally, I really miss the old magic system of 'so many casts per spell'. It felt good to try and manage your spells for both long term fights such as bosses and short term fights like killing fodder along the way.

I will also say that Ds2 is my favorite dark souls to co-op with my friends with. With the combo of the large and small soap stones, you can practically do the entire game the entire way with a friend.

snippet.textDisplay: Oh man now I'm conflicted. I played through DS2 twice when it came out in 2014 and thought it was about a 7/10. A good enough game, but nowhere near DS1. Over time my opinion soured as new, better games can out and I'm now a proud DS2 hater. However, I wanted to see if my opinion was still justified so I recently decided to pick up Scholar, the Reddit Approved™ definitive version and... it sucks. Like badly. The game is unplayable with anything but a UGS because of the sheer legions of enemies. Even with a UGS the game is just boring because the weapon is so damn strong that not even bosses can stand up to it. My problem now is that I still don't know if DS2 sucks, or just Scholar sucks. Do I have to play Vanilla again just to be absolutely sure it's bad? How tf did I get fooled into playing a game I don't like twice?

snippet.textDisplay:
I think you make plenty of good points regarding Scholar's design, and even though I liked Scholar more, you actually changed my mind about it a fair bit. However, some of your gripes look to me like they were coming from you simply refusing to adapt to the game. You learn that you cannot leave enemies behind at every opportunity, from the very moment you get out of majula.  Since you stated yourself, that you chose to defy the game (by rather running past enemies) instead of adapting to it, it is very much understandable why you feel like the deaths were cheap... yet they were very much your own doing.
I cannot believe you when you say, the game taught you to just run past fights. How often do you need to get ganked in different areas to understand that running past enemies isn't a good approach? Why do you run into a group of enemies, instead of drawing them towards you, maybe even towards a more advantageous position? Why don't you separate the melee from the ranged attackers? Why would you run into more uncharted or otherwise dangerous territory, rather than going back to safer areas for you to fight? It sounds a bit more like you were trying to be done with it, rather than actually engaging with it.
It seems obvious that your attitude towards Scholar heavily affected your experience. A lack of patience - as far as I know - is the number 1 reason why people quit dark souls games, and your lack of patience led to you having a bad time with it as well.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi! Coming by a little late, as per usual with me, but here I am nonetheless. I am one of those. One of the weird ones. I played Dark Souls 2 before any other souls, and since that day I love it. Not because it introduced me to a genre of games I didn't know existed, nor because it has shaped my taste and my future now that I'm a game developer myself, and obviously not for introducing me to likeminded fellows that enjoyed similar games like me (totally not gods fkin no), but because it taught me patience, it taught me to look around and try to reasonably prepare myself for a fight before taking it on and fkin around and finding out. It taught me that for any sort of battle you must be as prepared as you can be and to, once in, make my best small bites at a time. I used to play this back in my pre PC days on my PS3, and I believe I sank over 500hrs into this game. currently here on steam I've barely surpassed 50hrs in SoTFs.

For me Dark Souls 2s spirit came mostly from its intent in making you prepare the arenas to your favour, into going around if a section seemed way too hard and making it less hard. As an easy example, you showed much that nasty section of Nadalia's Tower where u get mega ganked by immortal enemies until you break the fragment of Nadalia. Even once the fragment has been destroyed that battle is quite challenging if you take it head on. But there are this little scared bomb stick guys that run away from you around the upper sections of the level, that you can collect and add to the arena. Now some explosive enemies don't really make much sense when it comes to making the fight easier, but the big mace guys spews lava from one of his arms, lava that can detonate those little guys, meaning that if you time your entry properly with enough of this guys in the battle you can instantly whipe the entire gank just by pushing a little stick guy around. You could also use some of the grenadier guys above to indirectly blow up everyone by connecting with one of the little guys. And this is just one situation. 

Now ever since then, I've had the chance to play Dark Souls 1 and 3 and whilst I've come to adore the first one, I can't say so for the third. Now, I love Dark Souls 1 for what an amazing accomplishment it is, the amazing story it tells and definitely the rush of adrenaline you get when you have been about to be thrown down Anor Londo's Archway thingies by those pesky archers but you finally made it through (ehem... that last one sounded a little to personal ehmmm). In terms of three I like it mostly from the story part, and some of the lore, but shockingly nowhere near as 1 and 2. Hence my ranking for these three games its actually its release too, three being at the bottom, definitely thanks to the idea and term I've ended for it with being "R1 Spam".

But anyways, speech over, so back to topic. Thanks for giving Dark Souls 2 "vanilla" a chance, and thanks for sharing with us your changed thoughts on it (I share on most of them btw). This was the first ever video I've sen from you (I think) and I've been quite pleasantly surprised and "touched", so time to go down another channel's upload history again. See you maybe in a couple of months.

TLDR: Dark Souls 2 is aight, SoTFS did a lot wrong. Dark Souls 3 R1 Spam KEKW. Thanks for the vid Feeble.

snippet.textDisplay: “Scholar quickly makes me lose my patience, while vanilla respects my time.” This utterly meaningless sentence basicaly sums up how fucking dumb this video is. This isn’t an analysis, this is you starting with a  conclusion and working your way backwards to prove yourself right. It’s fine to prefer either edition, but to claim that scholar “ruined” the base game is fucking ridiculous. It’s the same game. “Oh no, one extra enemy now aggros in this room, this game is RUINED, completely unplayable piece of shit, compared to the vaaaaastly superior base game that has like, 10 minute details different about it. Fuck the actual gameplay, the artistic value, the worldbuilding that remains unharmed, we all know what really matters in gaming is that it appeals to my very strict, particular and totally objective sense of fairness.” I wonder how long one has to rot his brain in online circlejerks before this sort of opinion starts seeming reasonable.

Be I’ll be honest i came into this video a bit angry cause i genuinely love ds2 but after watching you compare the two versions and even comparing it to 1 i can’t help but feel like you kinda force feed the whole “scholar bad cause gank + fight = death!“ when in reality all you had to do was play it the same way you play vanilla?? I won’t sit here and act like there isn’t a ton of issues with 2 some sections like smelter boss run aren’t horrendous but the gameplay you showed is literally how i first played/play when i die to something and i get upset like me mismanaging my stamina against an enemy i could easily take out and lose tons of souls yes running seems like a good option so you can get your shit back or whatever but if you just take a second to deal with enemies the game honestly isn’t THAT hard/different from vanilla (yes i played both)

snippet.textDisplay:
Never in my life will I forget or forgive how they screwed over DS 2 fans by releasing Scholar on year later. One entire year to buy the vanilla version, only to then make a re-release with shuffled enemies, slightly better graphics and lighting, and split servers so people couldn't even play together. And to add insult to injury, it took years before Scholar offered even a 50% discount to owners of the vanilla version. 

Seriously, screw Scholar of the first Sin.

Seriously, screw Scholar of the first Sin.

Heres some more fun PTSD stories about Shrine of Amana, this time featuring Console Launch Vanilla DS2.
The Priestesses used to have an aggro range so gigantic they could quite literally shoot you from outside their visual render distance, so you'd be getting sniped from across the map and couldnt even see what was sniping you, just magic phasing into existence once it enters render range and the piercing sound of it approaching.

snippet.textDisplay:
Man this is what I've been saying. All *major* complaints about DS2 come from SOTFS. I appreciate the comparison because I bought DS2 at launch and bought the DLC season pass and played them as they came out one by one, so I never actually played SOTFS. I just knew SOTFS had statues blocking everywhere, ganks everywhere, and a bloody dragon in tower of flame ( which is a boss presented as an enemy before encountering the actual boss ).

By the way, waaay in the beginning, Nashandra was the end. There were no Throne Watchers, there was no Aldia. And yes Ancient Dragon and Vendrick are not only optional but I always took them as specifically discouraged bosses - I've not even ever killed Ancient Dragon, it's presented as an ally.

Another thing I have to add. At the time the DLCs were advertised as to be played with friends or other players and that's how I largely view them. They were designed around the same time as main story SOTFS so the philosophies will be similar, with multiplayer in mind ( RIP to the servers ) and gank, but the gank isn't presumably as bad as main story SOTFS because they were actually DESIGNED around this style, whereas the main story was hacked into it later on, with SOTFS. My 2 cents.

I played Demon's Souls before any Dark Souls games, so for me to die and immediately be on 50% of your max HP is just part of the game, so that complaint I feel is totally unwarranted. If anything, Dark Souls 2 got closer to the real 'souls' difficulty than 1 and 2.

snippet.textDisplay: I always got the feeling that SOTFS was a spiteful rebuke to the 'experts' complaining that DS2 wasn't what they thought Dark Souls was. They heard that DS2 wasn't as punishing as DS, they heard that DS2 wasn't as unforgiving as DS and they heard that DS2 wasn't as much an experience of frustration and suffering as DS was so they turned around and said "You think you know what Dark Souls is? I'll give you exactly what you asked for". They basically gave their critics the Faust treatment.

snippet.textDisplay:
How could they sell the game again at full price?

The SCholar of the first sin patch was made regardless if you bought the upgrade or not On PC, atleast. Buying SOTFC only upgraded the graphics. Basically you get the "balance" revamp for free, but if you want to upgrade the graphics you bought the upgrade.

But other than that, yeah. DS2 was already hard, Scholar , while balanced some enemies to be less frustrating, put them in even more dickinsh places.

I still like it more than DS3. DS3 felt like the series was already tired, repeating a lot of scenarios from DS1. I mean DS 2 Repeats the concepts for the scenarios, but not the scenarios themselves.

You got the destroyed village , the venom death pit, that other venom death pit but with deformities. Anor Londo, It even copies the worst fight from DS 2, (the cathedral fight), altough their version is better because you hardly finish it  in 5 seconds.

Dark Souls 2 has a special place in my heart because it tries to replicate the first game, but in it's own way. It even feels a little like the Kings Field Series instead of Dark Souls with the level design, it even has pushwalls , wich It's a terrible idea in DS, but still! It picked the previous 2 games and did it's own thing with the formula. Wich i guess pissed miyazaki, because he got rid of half of the good things brought by DS2. So when you play DS3 you play a sequel to the first game, disregarding the cool things of the second

the ladder guy dead in a corner represents the sentiment FROM has towards the sequel. Guess this game almost kills the franchise. Som they want to pretend it doesn't exist, All im saying is Capcom still puts DMC 2 in it's timeline, And DMC2 is a horrible game.

snippet.textDisplay:
Just a warning for anyone watching this: keep in mind this guy is not ever going to give a fair review of souls games. He said in his elden ring review that he likes to just play soul level 1 with a broadsword. And as you can see from his gameplay, he runs through the level, then tries to fight every enemy on the level at once and dies (since hes pretty bad at the combat in these games). Theres nothing wrong with running past every enemy, or trying to level 1 with a broadsword...but uh...you cant review an entire game by forcing yourself to do A CHALLENGE RUN AND GETTING KILLED BECAUSE YOU DECIDE TO FIGHT 20 ENEMIES AT ONCE. Of course the game isnt going to cater to your overly specific and down right stupid playstyle. Look at 9:25 for an example. Hes complaining about level design having too many enemies while actively having lead four enemies into a small chokepoint, where he finally decides to fight them.
After watching a few of his videos ive come back to say this is either the best satire ever invented by man, or this man has autism and cant actually realize hes the cause of the majority of his own issues. Which is sad.

snippet.textDisplay:
I played vanilla on release and sotfs with the same build, power stance ultra great swords. I had 1 issue in vanilla with the chariot run up where I needed to use a shield. In sotfs I had tons of extra struggles and now I realise why.

I always enjoyed 2 over 1 in the game feel aspect. 1 was definitely clunky and rough around the edges controls & performance wise. Vanilla ran at 60 fps and innocuous things like jumping weren’t horrendous to input. 1 is the best dark souls game for my money, but boy does it feel dated now!

Also the fast paced, glass cannon builds truly prepare you for Bloodborne, ds3 and sekiro. I really didn’t struggle with Bloodborne and first times many of the bosses (including kos 💁‍♀️) because of the training ds2 gave me.

snippet.textDisplay: It's honestly baffling to me how rarely this opinion is shared online. I refunded Scholar shortly after it came out because of the issues you mentioned (I especially remember the gank in FotFG right after Pate, which in vanilla was perfectly reasonable and a good early challenge). Some years later I bought Scholar super cheap and beat it just to see if my opinion changes. It was horrible, and I don't understand where this "scholar > vanilla" popular opinion comes from. I imagine it's only damaging the already fragile reputation that DS2 has in the community.
snippet.textOriginal: It's honestly baffling to me how rarely this opinion is shared online. snippet.textDisplay:
I thought I was alone on this. When I say I liked Vanilla more than SOTFS people are like "R U Serious???!"
But maybe I was lucky and by accident I started playing Vanilla as I had bought this version on Steam while there was the "improved" Sotfs.
Someone else told me, hey you are playing the old version, you should have started the new one.
But then I was already into and already a bit frustrated by some horrible hitboxes, especially my inability to hit things. But kinda managed to finish the game and the DLCs.

Much later I decided to have a look at the Sotfs. OMG. I was hoping they will fix the real problems of the game, like the doubly unfair hitboxes (You fail to land hits that visually look like they did, while enemies hit you when their end of their attack didn't even remotely touched you). They fixed NOTHING. And then added way more enemies! I even noticed at some places more red invaders. Somewhere I got one, killed him then I got another one. After fighting all the gangs. Wtf? Enemy placing has changed, there are the many statues, the floating knight you fought is everywhere (although I love to fight this enemy, I learned to avoid his attacks, so I am kinda ok with this change). And yes, the white knights where the curiosity in the vanilla, if you found one it was unique, like a rare enemy, it made an impression on your journey. But now they have them all over that area like a common enemy. They were the mysterious enemy you don't need to engage.

After I finished sotfs for completion (I managed by doing the opposite of what you do, just having the patience to kill enemies one after the other, not rush it as I will be ganged from behind, in worse case after 10 times they dissapear at least), i went back to play the Vanilla and oh boy it feels so much better experience. It was already too much so I don't understand why they screwed this up with an "upgrade" which is a "downgrade", but most people think I am crazy.

DS1 > Vanilla DS2 > Sotfs DS2

snippet.textDisplay:
Personally i started with Scholar, it was only my second Soulsborne game after Demon's Souls, it was frustratingly hard, i raged a lot and kept dying to no end, but it ended as my favourite Dark Souls game, i love the difficulty of it, the whole story about the war with the Giants and the curse messing with everything you see, i highly disagree that having a lot of enemies made you run past everything it should be the exact opposite XD, pretty sure the developers just wanted to stop people from just running past and actually play the game, fight, i feel like limited enemy respawns are obvious proof, even with that out of the way i still love having tons of enemies, certainly beats just having constant giant enemies to push difficulty even if i've come to like bigger enemies as well now (thanks to Dark Souls 3 i guess).

I don't know about boss design, but i couldn't disagree more about the Dark Souls 1 bosses, i can't remember a single boss i actually liked where i have favourites otherwise in any game, in piles, and i think the best enemies or bosses are always the ones that are the same as you, knights, just a fair duel with your equal, and Dark Souls 2 has so many lovable bosses like that, the DLC is definitely the best in the series 3 enormous content levels worth your money, lastly i will admit i don't use lock on, there's nothing i hate more than having something automated like my camera, i wanna move it myself, i can play a video game, although i think from now i think i'll use lock on using Rapier cause i miss so many thrusts.

Edit: I dunno how much differences the changes make honestly, i platinum'd both versions, but im gonna say im going with Scholar being better, can take screenshots on PS4 and the tiny slowdown is gone even if i didn't particularly mind it, was still noticable and some of the worst in any game ever, also the areas in vanilla and the added stuff being gone can feel hollow, more enemies and stuff to do is always better im my book.

snippet.textDisplay:
idk dude ds2 has always just been a good enough game with or without scholar, having played both I do prefer scholar overall but thats probably cus I'm used to it more, and as you mentioned at one point, the balancing matters alot to me with it, and I think scholar is by a mile the best pvp we've had in a souls game with the most variant builds you'll find in any of the games.

That being said, the enemy placement in softs was always just another thing for me to adapt to personally, years ago I'd say it was difficult when I didnt have a mindset for it, but nowadays it's just another souls game, and each souls game is approachable with it's own mindset cus the games are all wildly different while being similar. 

That being said AGAIN, I have the most amount of hours in ds2 out of all souls game and have no lifed it and memorize everything well enough to no death it, so I'm not exactly the common voice here that is gonna give a general opinion. So things naturally differ alot

I will say that alot of the complaints about every single level being flooded with way too many enemies, is just a bit too exaggerated and overblown, not to mention as another comment mentioned already, if you skip all enemies you will just naturally end up being underleveled, souls games are all about how you approach them and their difficulty is tuned to your own decisions in that regard with alot of areas, unless you REALLY know what you're doing, all souls games will naturally be way harder if you actively are avoiding combat.

snippet.textDisplay: After I initially hated SOTFS, it has become my favourite Souls game after I understood how it's meant to be played. The ports for example are supposed to explain to you that you only need traverse an area once. And you're supposed to do so carefully and deliberately. So, if you run into gank fights often without any recourse, it's because you weren't paying attention. If a certain point becomes too hard for you, you can also simply kill enemies until they stop respawning. Once I engaged with the game properly, I started really enjoying the puzzle of how to get from A to B without dying which was a lot more avoidable and exploration more rewarding as well.
snippet.textOriginal: After I initially hated SOTFS, it has become my favourite Souls game after I understood how it's meant to be played. The ports for example are supposed to explain to you that you only need traverse an area once. And you're supposed to do so carefully and deliberately. So, if you run into gank fights often without any recourse, it's because you weren't paying attention. If a certain point becomes too hard for you, you can also simply kill enemies until they stop respawning. Once I engaged with the game properly, I started really enjoying the puzzle of how to get from A to B without dying which was a lot more avoidable and exploration more rewarding as well.

snippet.textDisplay: I enjoy Scholar because I like the difficulty, it is objectively a lot worse but I find the difficulty to be what I was looking for. I found Dark Souls 3 too easy, Bloodborne wasn’t easy but wasn’t really as hard as I would have hoped, and I’ve played Dark Souls Remastered too many times for it to be a challenge. Along side that my first play through of any souls game has to be 100% to make me feel accomplished and Dark Souls Remastered and Dark Souls 3 took me a total of about 100 hours where as Scholar took me over 300 hours. Now you could say I’m just bad at the game but this is with me not using any tutorials. Sure it’s been annoying but it gave me 300 hours to play a game that I genuinely fell into and gave me tons of fun. Also to be fair I might just be a masochist

There IS a video that has a side to side on how relentless those shots were (I can't find it but if you check oroboro's original playthrough you can get a taste of it. Projectiles had so much tracking they could do a 180 and hit you from behind, running past the mages was not an option considering that as soon as you turned your back on the mages you were basically renouncing the only way to dodge their projectile which was rolling diagonally toward them). Big recommend, that area scarred me

This is the dumbest video on the citadel.  Scholar is an infinitely better product, not because it's an 'optional hardmode', but because they fixed a lot of the wonkiness of DS2's hitboxes, low internal FPS, and catching. DS2's reputation was maligned before scholar and only got better after scholar.

another solid video! and I definitely agree with the whole DS1 v DS2 being a sort of "high art" v "pretty good game" debacle. ultimately, DS1 comes out on top in the trilogy for me for those artistic and emotional aspects.

a couple of small things, though:

1. you can skip to Drangleic Castle in SotFS, but the amount of souls needed is different based on the NG cycle; only the first NG on a character takes only 1,000,000 souls
2. the dragon bones in Aldia's Keep do technically resurrect in Scholar, but only after lighting the sconces that summon those stupid-ass Forlorn enemies

snippet.textDisplay:
As I have played both for hundreds of hours

I can say that Scholar is better, feels better and is more fun. 

Original Ds2 had very clear issues with uninspired enemy placements, lack of interaction with the game and of course specific items drops. Aka grinding for the shadow dagger and shadow in NG+ agaijst the flexile sentry. Grinding for the heide knight set and weapons. Constantly grinding flexile sentry for the auroros set. Going into ng++ to get great magic barrier from the dude in drangleic castle. Weak reasons to explore and such

Scholar on the other hand has easily the best enemy placements in the series and is the only one that doesn’t make me roll my eyes whenever fromsoft thinks putting generic anorexic hollow to shove you off the edge is clever enemy placement. Enemy density increase made it more fun and more HOLY SHIT. They fixed the difficulty of obtaining those armor sets and weapons locked behind a tedious unforgiving grind. Added new npc invaders, Forlorn included even if he may be annoying at times, it gave us a new armor set and weapons. Only had to pay 60$ for a game with all its dlc’s instead of paying 60$+15+15+15 for OG Ds2 at the time. They Integrated the dlc keys into the World of Scholar of the first sin. Overall item placement changes made the game better and more explorative. One of the best changes is taking the Grand Lance from the literal end of the game and making it accessible at the start of the game. They improved questlines and they can’t be accidentally fucked up by an npc dying in the boss fight or forgetting to summon them entirely. They even left the out of bounds glitches with the butterfly ser in the game on purpose so we can abuse these exploits since the set is locked to higher ng’s.

Imo Ds2 Scholar of the first sin is a MASSIVE improvement over the original. It’s literally B-team giving us a fun Director’s cut of the game. It’s what Deadrising 2 off the record is to regular Deadrising 2

snippet.textDisplay:
Gonna be that guy and point out that at 12:07 you talk about how vanilla has a positive feedback loop while scholar causes a negative loop. This is false, both of these are examples of positive feedback loops, just in different directions. 

Positive feedback means the better you play the more powerful you become and vice versa. Essentially, being more skilled at the game means the game will become easier and playing badly will make the game harder.

A negative feedback loop on the other hand is the opposite. If you play better the game gets harder to match your skill, if you play worse the game gets easier to help you through.

The leveling system in dark souls kinda works as both in a weird way. If you are really bad and die before reaching your souls often, you won't level up as much due to having fewer souls, and so the game gets harder for you (positive loop), however if you die a lot but are able to reclaim your souls then the souls from each run compound and you are able to level more than if you get through in fewer attempts, making the game easier (negative loop).

 Negative loops are not necessarily bad game design, and both types have their uses depending on the intentions of the designer.

I never understood how the DS2 bots on Reddit could claim that Scholar fixed DS2's bad design, when they ran vanilla item and enemy placements through a randomizer and slapped a few forgettable DLCs on the end. Talk about the opposite of the thoughtful deliberate design of Dark Souls 1. 

Overall I'm glad we got DS3 and Bloodborne as worthy sequels to DS1, so we can ignore DS2 and forget it ever happened.

snippet.textDisplay: The weird thing about scholar is that it gets better with every playthrough after the first. Like exponentially. Never played vanilla, went through scholar thinking "well this is bullshit" like every 20 minutes or so on first playthrough, felt very unsatisfied and lowkey angry at the entire game after the "take the throne" ending, especially after killing 3(!) boss encounters IN A ROW in the last room(managed to pull it off, I know you don't have to start at the first fight if you die on second or third). On my second run I realized methods to deal with the big enemy groups, tried a different route, it was much more relaxing. After that on subsequent playthroughs I discovered the dragonrider cheese strat in heide without looking it up, which enabled me to make every character I had reasonably strong 15 minutes after starting; that you can cancer parry pursuer very easily to oblivion on his sliding uppercut attack so you get ring of blades on first encounter and skip a fight with him later, and just started to genuinely enjoy the game. And don't get me started on pvp, which is imo the best in the entire series.

snippet.textDisplay: I actually much prefer SotFS over Vanilla. In both versions, the boss fights are pretty awful and way to easy, besides a couple dlc bosses maybe. Since the bosses are the main draw of the Souls games and both versions failed in that aspect, I had to find something else to fill the role of bosses. Vanilla didnt have anything like that for me since the game was fairly easy across the board, but SotFS in all of its gank glory managed to fill the void. Due to the big difficulty spike in SotFS caused by the sheer volume of enemies, I felt the same way about making my way through the areas and basic enemies themselves as i do about fighting bosses in the other Souls games. It felt rewarding to finally make my way through an area i kept struggling against, and I never felt the need to run past enemies either.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ds2 vanilla is fine. It still has many of the problems people often site. Many of the core aspects to the gameplay loop are just straight up broken. But it still worked as a challenging, but (mostly) fair journey through a (mostly) beautiful land. 

SotFS is painful to play through. SotFS shows no response to feedback from the core player base. They (kinda)  put the advertised lighting engine back in and put the framerate at 60 for the graphics nerds, but completely ignored almost every other criticism of the vanilla game. The only thing they took to heart was people saying it was "too easy." So what was the solution? Put in more and bigger frustrating mobs with stronger enemies, move items to places that make less sense to cripple the early game for new players, and move/add/replace all the enemies to slow progress as much as possible. 

Not only is it all a huge missed opportunity and disappointment, but it's basically a slap in the face to the community who supported the series at the beginning.

snippet.textDisplay:
The worst thing about Scholar is that the base game's difficulty usurps the difficulty of the DLC areas.

What I will say about your approach to DS2 is that, going melee only with no ranged option in a game filled with easily usable ranged options is a massive handicap you placed on yourself.  Just having a bow, or some ranged AoE makes Scholar infinitely more tolerable, players customize their difficulty based on their toolset, and you just limited it.

And just to be clear, I dislike scholar as much as you do, because it makes me ABUSE bows/magic.

snippet.textDisplay:
This feels... Kinda braindead. I might have a different perspective due to "Souls veteran status", but I disagree on the reasons as to why Scholar is worse than Vanilla. I'm not gonna go into the usual text-wall levels of explanation I tend to spit out when I disagree with someone, so apologies in advance if I make something unclear.

I wanted to touch on the 1 mil soul skip and skelly dragon, but I see you already mentioned that in a comment.

So, I will focus on what I understand to be your main two issues with Dark Souls 2, or at least SotFS.

Firstly, the simpler one. In regards to your complaints about Fragrant Branches of Yore and the statues they are used for - I believe you're using some really bad logic. I understand it, but I don't think it's in any way reasonable. Your main issue is, basically, not that people CAN softlock themselves, since that of course doesn't happen. So from what I understand, your issue is that the game makes it LOOK like you can softlock yourself. Which is certainly an issue, but not as big as you seem to believe. It's a pretty scary bit of miscommunication, but the only way this can become a serious problem is if you let it; in other words, this is only a big issue if you're dumb enough to believe a game dev would actually let you softlock yourself - and on top of that - in a "better" (as per marketing) version of the game.

If you see an obstacle and go "hurr durr I guess the devs are dumb and they made me softlock myself, there sure ain't no OTHER way to progress, wah wah wah" then you're just dumb. By the way, genuinely sorry if I'm coming off too strongly on the topic, but honestly ask yourself, do you actually think it's normal to blame the devs the moment you can't immediately see where you're supposed to progress? The "fix" to this issue can only be either the devs telling you "Hey, if you can't get past this statue, there's another way!" via Message, but that would be debatable (complaints of handholding), OR the hypothetical player I've been using up until now activating his brain and realizing "Oh, well, there must be another way!" Bottom line is, it's illogical to assume a respected and beloved developer would actually just fuck up so horribly and in such a brainless, dumb and easily fixable manner (if it actually was a way to softlock yourself, they would have patched the statue out.)

As for the second bit, that being "enemy spam"... Well as it turns out, counter to my assumption, this might actually be the one that takes shorter. Again, this might be an honest mistake, but to me the whole thing sounds like nothing more than skill issues, bar some of the TRULY shit enemy placements that you can only reliably survive when you actually know they're there. AKA, the shit ambushes. But as for the areas that just have a lot of enemies, and honestly even some of the ambushes (some are really easy to notice, like the Huntsman's Copse ambush you showed), I've genuinely never had any issue with them and am simply convinced you got yourself in trouble and are now blaming the dev. Your main point is that the number and aggro of the enemies is too extreme, leading you to getting used to running past them, which inevitably sets you up for failure. You argue that this is an issue from the very start and I disagree fiercely. Let's take the "Pit of Hollows"; the one bit in Forrest of Giants where you go up a ladder. Your argument for that part specifically, due mainly to it's shortness, is "There's like 20 of them" actually being said, while what's shown is them being aggroed, which leads to the inevitable conclusion that they're just waiting for you there, active right off the bat. This isn't the case, as anyone who played the game should know. All of the hollows, besides one that throws firebombs and the one at the second ladder, are inactive and laying down on the ground. The only immediately active enemies are three dogs, which are easy to deal with. After that, it's entirely easy to deal with the other hollows, even if you don't know about the one that throws bombs. You literally just walk up to one, kill it and move to the next one. The most that will aggro at once is two at a time and only in some cases. The only way to aggro all of them, subsequently screwing yourself over, is if you kite one around too much, get spotted by mr bombs, panic and run past all of the ones with their faces in the dirt, which I personally think is on the player, not the game, as I believe the enemy placement is clearly communicated and executed in a way that is easy to deal with, again, even if you're on a blind playthrough. And hell, if you screw yourself once by running past the enemies, surely the next time you decide to take your time, thereby dealing with them successfully and NOT getting in a dumb and illogical habit as running past all of them. The game isn't impossible, or even that hard to beat for you to NEED to run. I won't comment on why you might decide on running anyway, but it IS a dumb decision which I can't see anyone reasonable making.

So, what did we learn? Well, first of all, that I'm shit at guessing how long stuff takes. (Yes, I put this entire paragraph here just to make that joke.) But, jokes aside, I really don't think you thought this out too well. Personally, I find it better to talk to someone who has the opposite opinion first, before you make these videos. I'm not saying that because I think you're wrong, but because it can save you a lot of embarrassment in the future, IN CASE you happen to make a silly argument, like the bit where you genuinely said incorrect information about skelly dragon and the 1 mil souls skip. Basically, just have someone proofread your shit, but have it specifically be someone who disagrees, since those mfrs are gonna go through hell and high water to look for literally ANYTHING to disprove your point, while someone who agrees, obviously, is just gonna nod along the whole time and most likely not even pay attention when something OBJECTIVELY wrong (skelly, souls) sneaks in past all the SUBJECTIVE (enemies, statues) stuff you're gonna cover.

snippet.textDisplay: There are two more Heide knights in Scholar besides the ones in Heide's Flame Tower. One is sitting in a cell in Sinner's Rise (and drops the spear) and another one is sitting at the bottom of the Gutter (he drops his helmet and lance in NG+0 and the Heide greatlance in NG+1). For getting the sword one needs to farm the knights at Heide's Flame Tower for an infinitely long time (the droprate is incredibly low). In this respect I, too, like Vanilla more, as the knight who was located in the Forest of the Fallen Giants had a guaranteed drop of his sword.

snippet.textDisplay:
I played scholar first, but never felt like I should run away from the "unfair bullshit". I approached the levels in a paranoid and methodical manner, learning how to single out enemies, find cover from archers, check my surroundings for ambushes, etc. Sometimes I would reach the boss gate and decide to go back because I couldn't clear the area with a reasonable amount of healing left. By the end, I was not lacking in levels. I'm not saying I would have enjoyed the saner difficulty less, just that my experience was very different from yours. 
edit: Shrine of Amana did break me, tho, it was traumatizing.

snippet.textDisplay: I think the exact opposite. I love DS2 SotFS, and DS2 vanilla feels gimped. Heide's feels empty, the forest is boring, Amana loses all character (not because it's unfair in SotFS, but because it's too simple and easy in vanilla. Not that hard is implicitly good, but that it's an end game area that's supposed to challenge you.), the statues are a good way to gate progression, make it more metroidvania esque, even no man's wharf is boring in vanilla. Maybe it's because I already think DS2 is the easiest, even in SotFS, but I think it's more because I understand what the combat wants you to do and enjoy it, rather than just wanting more DS1.

snippet.textDisplay:
Interesting video, but I feel like it didn't get a deeper view of the two Dark Souls 2 games you can play. For example, saying that scholar has more bugs in it than the original is false. Why? Because I played scholar on console, PC, and steam deck but never experienced the same bugs you have. Which tells me that it may be on your end with your software/settings. I can't say but it is hard to buy that bottle of bugs you're selling when I haven't experienced it at all.

For the item change out, enemy placements changed, and increase/decrease of enemy count between the two... I won't say that is enough to call it a cash grab. Think of it this way. Dark Souls 2 was set at 30 FPS when it came out for the consoles. The game was rushed and there were some parts that wasn't polished or just quickly threw items in whichever way. Then Dark Souls 2 Scholar came out a year later that included the DLCs, at 1080p, locked at 60 FPS, with visual improvements, and ect. The Castle having less enemies is most likely because of the frames not being at 60 with the weather, water effects, visual effects, and the large amount of enemies. So the enemy count had to take a hit instead of removing or limiting the environment. 

I don't want to go into detail about everything, but I do think you didn't give vanilla vs scholar a proper look. Most of it is on your own opinion without understanding why the development team went with those choices. Because of that I do think you are not fair towards the two games. If someone talked to me about which Dark Souls 2 to play, I would still recommend the scholar over the vanilla because I feel like (after playing the two for years) scholar makes it a bit more enjoyable, plus the DLCs are included.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark Souls 2: Scholar was my first ever souls game. I've never had half the issues you're talking about here. 
The game certainly did not teach me to run past enemies. If anything, the game taught me to be slow, careful, and thorough, as to not die and have to repeat the whole area. 
The dragon peaks where you have to duel the champion to be let past? That part literally goes against what you say the game is trying to teach you. It makes you fight one guy - a relatively quick fight - and not run through, because that is MUCH more difficult. If you look at that area and think "wow the game teaches me to run past enemies", that's just your stubbornness and unwillingness to adjust the way you decided to play the game, my guy. 
At the end of the game, I had less deaths than you (somewhere around 80-100, I think) and I've never even touched a Souls game before, so I'd say, a lot of the criticism here is your personal preference, at best. 

Was Scholar a great game? Eh, probably not. Was it an okay game? Yeah, I'd say so. Was it as terrible as you make it sound? No.

snippet.textDisplay: The ending statement of this video is one of my major complaints with Dark Souls 2. I had a... Some what enjoyable experience with the game and most certainly enjoyed my time with the pvp more than I did with dark souls 1. But in nearly every other area the game just seemed inferior to the first one. But any time I would try and discuss that, I would receive so much vitriol from the community of DS2 stans, many of who refused to even acknowledge the potential issues in the game, especially the issues with SOTFS. Those community interactions really burned me off of a game that I thought was fun all things considered.

snippet.textDisplay:
I played vanilla DS2 first because at the time I didn't have a PS4, so I had no way to play SotFS. I'd say you're pretty correct that you're conditioned to fight and engage with the enemies in vanilla. There are less so it's easier to do. In SotFS, you can still fight through every single enemy until they all stop respawning. Because of how many more enemies there are in the rerelease however, that's obviously more difficult to do as the chances of dying or running out of Estus, your primary source of healing, is greater.

In vanilla DS2, I fought through every enemy encounter until they did stop spawning, and thus I was able to level a lot quicker. But even doing it in SotFS is viable. It's still possible, even though it tends to be more tedious. Regardless, I've always liked that DS2 has a somewhat compelling way of trying to make fights more challenging. First off, those life gems are plenty and the Estus shards to upgrade your flask are scattered all over the game. Combined with the ADP stat, you're forced to not only play slower, but play more tactfully and make the pressing decision of when to keep fighting and when to heal, and with what. The combat is slow, but it all culminates in a game that tries to force you to be more careful about every move you make.

I'd never really considered SotFS to be any evolution of this, nor an overblown gambit to be more challenging outright. How one approaches the game, and how they interpret what the devs intended for the gameplay, can drastically change one's experience with it. Like I said, Scholar was the second version I picked up when I did finally get a PS4. But aside from the enemies and odd choices of those statues, it didn't really feel any different to me. SotFS is still DS2, even if it's more baffling than it has any right to be. That being said, I do agree that all the enemy placements, etc. could have been amended in the rerelease had it only been optional via the Covenant of Champions or new game plus. Again, I don't know why they did what they did to Scholar, but it being a rerelease, they had the chance to do whatever they wanted. Several item descriptions were changed among the alleged balancing and so on. So in a sense, I do think Scholar was at least intended to be a definitive version, but it doesn't succeed where it should.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey, someone who understands that SoTFS is a master quest version of DS2. Holy shit, you even made the direct comparison right after I started writing this, well done. Fun fact basically no one knows, the devs when SoTFS was being marketed outright said that it was intended to be a harder, more lore cohesive version of DS2 because they knew that most of the people that were gonna buy it were people who had already played through the base game and they wanted to address concerns about how much easier DS2 was for people (if you believe the internet discourse) than DS1 was and also give them a reason to re-buy a game they'd largely already seen (also DS2's development was infamously horrible and disjointed, to the point that the OG director got stealth fired and hasn't shown up in anything since).

Relatedly, DS2 is a response to DS1. For example, the devs saw that people praised DS1 for having slower, more methodical combat, so they made DS2 slower. If you go back and read forums from when DS2 was being previewed and in beta, people didn't complain about the speed or controls much, and even for a while after release that wasn't a mainline complaint like it is now (even though DS2 plays and controls far closer to BB onward than DS1 and DeS but WHATEVER). Then they saw people complain DS2 was too slow (while also praising BB for its speed) that when they made 3, they sped it up to match. And then people complained that DS3 was too fast for Souls combat and the combat felt like trying to play against BB enemies while not being as fast (which isn't valid whatsoever but you know, internet bitching), so ER slowed down a bit (and now people are complaining about combo strings being too long and not having enough openings to get safe damage in with slow weapons, so they ended up patching everything slower than a greatsword to be a bit faster and now we're back to DS3 speeds).

There's no winning, but FROM keeps trying. Personally I like all the games and what they're trying to do individually, but I've learned to just not interact with most of the fanbase's discussions because whenever I do I start losing brain cells and there were only so many years I could handle of that.

(Also pre-patch Shrine of Amana in base wasn't quite as bad as pre-patch Lost Izalith, but it was PAIN. The casters had higher aggro range and that says enough.)

snippet.textDisplay:
Regarding your issues with the DLC, from what I could understand, all the troubling areas are completely optional. I know that because I never went to the Frigid Outskirts, never fought the twin tigers, gave up on fighting the blue smelter demon after completing the DLC, meaning killing Sir Forever Alone (me and the summons bullied him and got him 1st try). So yeah, while I will agree and/or take your word that those areas are very nasty and sometimes purely awful, it's not like the game forces you to go through them. This does not excuse them from being the way they are but I think it's not as big of an issue. 
Overall I loved the video. I was one of those people who would tell others how awful the game was without having played it myself. Then one day I decided to give it a try. Got to the Pursuer boss fight, got salty, uninstalled the game. Few weeks later picked it up again, killed the Pursuer, got to the Ruined Sentinels, got saltier, uninstalled the game again. Few more weeks, picked up the game, killed the Sentinels, and went all the way. I died over 30 times to Fume Knight because I didn't actually know he was part of the DLC, which I entered right after Iron Keep...I am not a smart guy. But anyway, I went through the whole game with the DLCs and have to say, I loved it. Don't get me wrong there were many MANY times where the game really pissed me off. But by the time I killed Nashandra and sat on that throne...I was kind of sad it was over.

The Heide knights moving from early game locations to the tower of flame just to torture me for fighting Ornstein was particularly striking because I always loved fighting the knight in forest for his sword.

snippet.textDisplay:
Erm... I got notice that, you are not taking in consideration something when talking about Dragleic being "easy" in SoFT.

First of all, in lore perspective, Drangleic castle is in shambles. It's suppose to be almost abbandoned and completly isolated, like Shana told you when you first reach it, that's why there's little enemies there, and is easier to travel across.

Iron Keep, in the other hand, still has its lord in it, like commanding his forces, hence the amount ot enemies there.

I played both versions of the game, and Scholar isn't harder in Forest of the fallen and in Wharf, it's just slower.

Also, the statues, are an incentive to come back and explore earlier areas, that you don't have in Vanilla. Ruin Sentinels aren't an obligatory boss fight also. You can skip them, in both versions. Same as the Gargoyles.

snippet.textDisplay:
IIRC, white knights attack you ONLY after you beat Dragonrider, which means if you want to go to Ornsteiner - do not kill Dragonrider.
Also, after you beat Dragonrider you can invest all those souls into HP and drop into Majula well (you need 1350-1360 HP with 0.0% equip load to survive) and I'm pretty sure you can get 2 fragrant branches (if not 3) before you reach first bonfire in Black Gulch.

Of course, new players don't know that.
And yes, Scholar is my fav Souls game. 😁
