snippet.textDisplay:
So I did exactly what you said you should never do. I started with SotFS as my very first souls/borne games. And I absolutely fell in love with it, the challenge of the ganks is what I actually enjoyed. The item management (the branches for instance) was puzzling and made the world feel alive. My choices would affect my journey and I wouldn't know how until I did it once. Power-stanced ultras are still my favorite way to play and the combat makes everything incredibly methodical. 
I went back and played vanilla during quarantine and I still prefer SotFS. The easier game didn't feel right. I didn't understand why the "Hyde knights" weren't in "Hyde's Tower of Flame". The Shrine run felt much easier  but from the perspective of the lore and why that shrine is there, I didn't like it. It's guarding the tomb of the king and Velstadt, there's no reason it should be easy to get through. 
I do however agree with the bad points Iron keep. That area is bad regardless in my opinion tho as someone who doesn't like using ranged tools. 
Long story short, as someone who plays these games as my character with the world's perspective in mind, I love it through and through

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm seeing a lot of pushback in the comments for various reasons so I thought I'd throw my 2 cents into the mix. I played vanilla DkS2 mere days after it came out and I loved it. Including the Shrine of Amana pre any supposed nerfs. Then, a couple of years down the line, I picked up SOTFS and I barely got to Iron Keep, which then made me lose my shit. I quit then and never looked back. I despise what SOTFS did to the game, except of course the prettier rendering and the fact that you can get the Dull ember at a reasonable point in the game. I should also mention that I play the exact polar opposite of the way you do. I always fight the enemies and I use a bow to pull them in reasonable amounts, so it's not really a matter of playstyle.

I strongly disagree with you on two points, namely that the devs had no idea what they were doing, and framing DkS2's resemblance of King's Field as a bad thing. While we may personally vehemently disagree with the changes SOTFS made, that doesn't mean the team making it was comprised of brainlets on their first days on the job. Likewise, one major reason why I adore 2 is precisely because of its atmosphere and the King's Field vibe it has going for it. Those two points were massive misses in this critique, but overall I agree with this video. I'd give it an 8.69/10, could use some more water.

snippet.textDisplay:
SoTFS has 2 huge advantages to me
1) you get the ember after the pursuer fight so you can differentiate your build sooner with weapon enchants rather than having to go to the ironkeep before you can enchant
2) The enemies are weirdly pretty balanced for co-op so as a co-op game it winds up being my favorite of the souls series. (This is boosted by point 1 as you can both make interesting or synergistic builds as right after the Forest of Fallen Giants)

Also, on an unrelated note Master Quest was immediately accessible on the game cube port of OoT and it was the first iteration of it I played because I thought the icon of Link with a bow looked cooler.

snippet.textDisplay:
I've only played scholar, played through twice now both plays melee only no summons no hit trading (I did summon an npc to get me through frigid outskirts zone the one time I bothered to do that - that one area I can't argue it's terrible). I like the multi-fights I agree that's sort of the core idea of the game, but the Scholar version felt like the right level for me. I like the tough areas that you have to go through carefully. But I also get not liking them. I also just instinctively killed everything my first time through, I guess if you don't I can see why you wouldn't like it but I'm not totally convinced that the game really pushes you that way versus it just being a thing you decided to do for some reason.

But the main reason that I needed to comment was that at 19:30 you talk about the dragon skeleton. It does wake up in scholar, so I'm not sure what you're talking about there?

And for what it's worth I think I pretty much entirely agree that hit trading with high poise and buying and using life gems would make the combat feel a lot more like Skyrim than what I think of as "Dark Souls combat." Which is why I would never play that way.

Actually I just replayed all three DS games in order recently, and while I can't put my finger on it there's just something magical to me about the feeling of DS2 that 3 felt like a huge step down from, 3 feels much more hollow and safe to me.

snippet.textDisplay: You didn't even mentioned a mechanic only present in Scholar that should never have touched a souls game: enemy despawning. Each time you kill an enemy 10 times, it stops spawning unless you are on that hard mode covenant. I find it weird you saying you were conditioned to run past everything because, as you said, you had to luck out on fog walls. You can't really explore and find items (including those stupid branches) while running past all the bs because the AI never forgets about you once aggroed and the lack of iframes on opening doors, chests, fog walls, etc, so either you played on that covenant and were way too patient with fog walls or there was trick to running past the AI I never learned, which might be the case. Because to me, the game conditions the player to despawn stuff, one gank squad at a time until the boss run was bearable. Iron Keep and Shrine of Amana were endless grindfests to me, along with the DLCs. Maybe I got conditioned like this because I never got that NPC that sells infinite life gems to start selling them, so to me life gems were a finite resource I didn't had the luxury of spending on normal mobs to get to the boss fight in good health and heals and risk dying to the boss and lose them. Either way, Introducing this mechanic only gave the devs reason to increase the bs because they knew players could grind away, and grind is the opposite of what Dark Souls represented. It should never have been thought of as a way of counter balancing anything.

snippet.textDisplay:
sorry people have been mean, & definitely play sekiro.  i could be wrong, particularly if you bounce off the parry system (har har puns), but it very much seems tuned towards the classic single player, starting weapon, boss oriented, action game > rpg mechanics hardcore souls fan, and in particular is neat with the way the parry system keeps the gameplay active even while playing defensively in a way that dodge rolling just doesn't compare to.

sekiro's definitely not for me with my casual, low skill, co-op, high poise, hit trading, level grinding, spell casting, op building, character skill > player skill sensibilities, but I've got demon's souls, ds2, and elden ring catering more to me already.  I'm happy to let the real gamers enjoy sekiro, and we can meet in the middle for ds1, ds3, and bloodborne.

snippet.textDisplay: I think dark souls 2 is a really bad game to play immediately after dark souls one because all the hard learned lessons in dark souls one actually work against you in dark souls two. In dark souls 2 the game should be played without lock-on camera, in dark souls 2 you should have weapons with big hit boxes or stagger to help with large group fights, great clubs are OP in this game. In dark souls 2 the combat is more turn based, the opposite of most other games in the series, then there’s stuff like adaptability, since ds2 was my first game I naturally just levelled adaptability because I figured being faster to help avoid getting hit was a good thing; and as a result it was never a problem for me, but ds1 players who have the thought ‘I want a strength build’ will level strength without a second thought and as a result get punished for it. Durability, ranged combat, enemy Aggro distance, smaller health bar per death, so many things in this game are completely counter to dark souls 1’s play style, but when you don’t have that game to compare it to, you just accept these things as what the game is meant to be, you don’t have this restiance to it, so it doesn’t bother you and you learn to play how the game is teaching you to and it’s really fun. I think scholar is a good game, but it’s a bad sequel to dark souls

snippet.textDisplay:
Both games have issues of a similar nature. 

Vanilla has too few enemies. You'd walk through empty hallways and fight 1 or 2 enemies in a massive empty room which results in a somewhat hollow experience at times.
Scholar meanwhile overstuffed the rooms with copies of the same enemies a bit too much which forces players to play slower, making it a huge slog at times.

However, only one of these is stimulating. 
As in, you'd stop playing scholar because it's a slog and does a greater job of highlighting the inherent problems with ds2 as a whole. You'd stop playing vanilla because you'd rather play the more exciting game of solitaire.

Note that vanilla ds2 is popularly considered the easiest souls game(after the balance patches). That definitely changes some perspective on things.

snippet.textDisplay:
Oddly enough, I hated the game and played it Vanilla first. What I loved though was the PvP, so most of my hours (like literally a 10:1 ratio lol) were spent on that.

I then tried Scholar. The awful level design changes made me literally mad. The stone statues, the Heides Knights being removed, the DLC keys, the DLCs enemy spam areas not being tweaked, more ganks (even tho the first big Forest of Giants gank was toned down, the rest of the game had more), Iron Keep being *a s s* while it was a normal level back in Vanilla, the random drake in Heides that requires you to *cheese* the game to fight Ornstein early, a thing that was very commom back in Vanilla, the upgrade materials being thrown at you to justify the amount of enemies through "eh but you'll be overleveled all game long so you'll just twoshot all of them", baby jumps still existing, Forlorn being random, the fucken Horse in the castle and the fact they nerfef the Castle EVERYWHERE *BUT* the big enemy spamming room with the sentinels, giving most items away in random chests (placed badly too. Like, in the Bastille I'm gonna meet the blacksmith in 3 minutes and you place the ember next to the bonfire? I get it the old placement in Iron Keep was too far into the game, but at least place it before the sentinels or after, not before the blacksmith himself.) 

The entire community just decided to forget how much of a cashgrab the whole community considered it back when it came out. Everyone, Dark Souls 2 fans too, hated the mere existence of SotFS.

snippet.textDisplay:
Played DS1 lots of times, so coming to DS2 was a surprise to say the least. Very easy, a little too easy, and the lore didn't quite sucker me in in quite the same way, with weird choices with regards to combat and movement. Finished the game using the mace because it's busted, really enjoyed a good number of the boss fights, but didn't really want to jump back in. 

When I heard about Scholar and three different DLC's, I waited for the full release and all the patches that tend to come with a steam release, and when I jumped in I was delighted; way harder than the base game, better overall feel to the game, those statues encouraged a LOT more exploration (and thus I found a bunch of things I missed in the base game), and the DLC's were stellar, even if I found myself making silly mistakes with regards to the sometimes cramped geography. 

Overall, much prefer Scholar because I wanted the same challenge from DS1, and while it's not quite there, it's far closer than vanilla. I especially like the surprise enemy placements, especially the dragon in Heide's Tower of Flame, which required me to clear out enemies carefully, meticulously, before tacking the big guy and moving onto budget Ornstein. Beaten Scholar roughly six times, couldn't go back to vanilla after all that.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm well aware that I'm in the minority here but Scholar is actually what sealed DS2 as my favorite of the 3. 

I actually find enemy placement in vanilla to be much more annoying. Take for instance the hallway to Velstadt. In vanilla there's about 10 knights with 2 literally right in front of the fog wall. In scholar you have 2  knights and a dragon rider. In huntsmans copse the invader spawns just before the fog wall. For scholar she's on a side path guarding the key to the optional 3rd bonfire. 

I'm even going to say Iron Keep is easier in Scholar. No I'm not being needlessly contrary. It legitimately is. Super easy to bait one allone knight at a time and use walls and pillars to block the archer. If you're brave, take the jump to the stairs and skip over half the knights. 🤷

Let's also not forget Scholar gave us a short cut in No Man's Warf. 

Then there's the best change scholar made. The Dragon Sanctuary. In vanilla you get flanked by tons of dragon knights. In scholar they all take a bow and leave you to just fight the large ones.

"Every area in Scholar is like Velstadts boss run or worse". Except no they aren't. Every bit of footage in this video from Scholar showed you having already messed up. The only major gank areas in the entire game are the DLC optional areas which are also in Vanilla. Opinions are one thing but the tired argument of Scholar being nothing but a gank fest with video evidence shown after a player has already messed up and agroed a bunch of enemies is just getting old 😂

snippet.textDisplay: The devs never intend for you to run past the enemies in any of these games. You're supposed to slowly, carefully pick them off as they come and be aware of your surroundings/not rush. As someone who's played both versions I can safely say I've never once decided to give up fighting enemies and run through the level--that sounds like a horrible idea. Hence the difficulty balance of 2 that if you keep dying in a given zone you will eventually despawn enemies after ten or so kills, that way even if you're literally terrible you'll eventually make progress.
snippet.textOriginal: The devs never intend for you to run past the enemies in any of these games. You're supposed to slowly, carefully pick them off as they come and be aware of your surroundings/not rush. As someone who's played both versions I can safely say I've never once decided to give up fighting enemies and run through the level--that sounds like a horrible idea. Hence the difficulty balance of 2 that if you keep dying in a given zone you will eventually despawn enemies after ten or so kills, that way even if you're literally terrible you'll eventually make progress.

snippet.textDisplay:
Well this... Explains a lot.
I read THE EXACT DARN REDDIT POST you used in the Video a five years ago when i wanted to get my hands onto Dark Souls.
Played it, hated it, tried playing it again a year later, hated it even more because the first level just was absolute crap, and then very quickly closed the "Dark Souls"-Chapter in my gaming carreer.
It was "too complicated" as my young and stupid brain thought this immense not-fun came from the fact that i spent the few levels i could afford into the wrong stat.

I only saw a single boss bar once, and it was in the wrong area (The one with the tower and the buff knights), as the game taught me that the intended first level is just as good as the non-intended first level if the gameplay consists of running until you finde ONE (1) enemy that looks like a fair fight.

Then Elden Ring came, i chose to give the genre another shot, and i absolutely loved it.
Then i played Sekiro, loved it too and thought to myself "Okay maybe the souls series isn't shit"
Just finished DS3. Man what a great game, i may be still biting my teeth out on Blackblade Friede, but it is FUN to try at least.
DS2 is not. At least not scholar.

If it hadn't been for elden ring, i would have never touched ANY of Fromsoftwares games ever again, just because that HORRIBLE experience i had with Scholar of the First Sin, i wish, for every future player to come, that they just take it down from Steam and sell the Vanilla version at an upmarket instead, because that's what ill probably play after the DS3 DLCs.

I hate reddit.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm certainly interested to try vanilla now because Scholar is absolutely exhausting going back to with how poorly designed it often is. However one game that always scratched that "I wish Dark Souls 2 was better" itch for me has got to be Hellpoint, where DS2 disappointed and infuriated me Hellpoint did what Dark Souls 2 did well and improving upon what it sucked at. Level design, world design, boss design, multi fights, co-op and many more things were done objectively better - however it is janky, buggy, a bit too easy without using the difficulty raising item and has its weird quirks, but it's great fun and I often consider it Dark Souls 2 2. Its DLC even came out a month ago and is excellent, I recommend it to fans and non-fans of DS2.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm certainly interested to try vanilla now because Scholar is absolutely exhausting going back to with how poorly designed it often is. However one game that always scratched that "I wish Dark Souls 2 was better" itch for me has got to be Hellpoint, where DS2 disappointed and infuriated me Hellpoint did what Dark Souls 2 did well and improving upon what it sucked at. Level design, world design, boss design, multi fights, co-op and many more things were done objectively better - however it is janky, buggy, a bit too easy without using the difficulty raising item and has its weird quirks, but it's great fun and I often consider it Dark Souls 2 2. Its DLC even came out a month ago and is excellent, I recommend it to fans and non-fans of DS2.

snippet.textDisplay:
I haven't played the original, only sotfs. I found Iron Keep much, much worse than Shrine of Amana. Shrine of Amana and Iron Keep are both awful for the same reason - you practically need to kill every enemy that aggros you or you're going to die before getting to the boss. With Iron Keep I think it's 15 knights you need to kill before reaching the boss. I remember being so pissed off that I counted them. Not only this but their aggro range is insane, there is no other enemy or set of enemies in DS2 that has the aggro range of these knights, they'll sprint to you from every corner of the castle so if you're not careful you can end up fighting 10 at once. You'll randomly get NPC invasions here too, which just adds insult to injury. Oh and there are also loads of archers on this level who stun you on hit, leaving you open to die to the swarms of knights and invaders. In my playthrough I ended up killing all of the knights the 12 times needed so that they don't spawn again, that was the only way I could make the runback to Smelter Demon bearable.

Shrine of Amana is also scummy but I think it feels better because of the distance you cover. It feels like you're making progress. Iron Keep is one small area so it feels like you're gaining inches. In Shrine the enemies are easier to fight and is a lot less taxing on resources than Iron Keep. You'll be murdered in both if you just run through, most of the time. Another thing I prefer about Shrine is that it's just a nice looking area with some good music, it's definitely easier to progress through, and you're fighting 3 varieties of enemies instead of literally just the same dude copy and pasted 15 times like in Iron Keep.

I hate Iron Keep with an absolute passion and I felt degraded and insulted trying to get through the area. By killing most of the enemies to the point where they stopped respawning I just felt like I avoided the "challenge" while also wasting my own time. After reading about horsefuck valley and the runback to Allonne and blue Smelter Demon I just had no desire to play any of the DLC because I'd tasted that rotten fruit that was Iron Keep.

That great and vast world that always got me back for another run with a different build was ruined with the overwhelming amount of nonsense they added, for no reason. I didn't even plat ds2 again, even though I really wanted to at first. Scholar of the first sin is not a good enough """"remaster"""" to me, someone that fell in love with this game by playing with the first try they had to make it.

Never trust reddit kids. They don't seem to understand these games since most of them also hates invaders lmao.

snippet.textDisplay: Iunno, I've played ds2 vanilla first then SoTFS second and found scholar to be alot more enjoyable and makes alot more sense. The increase in statues were there so you can actually use the branches as an actual mechanic in the game unlike vanilla where basically close to none of them were there. Iron keep in scholar was ridiculous, but I usually had a bow to at least get the aggro of one enemy. Another thing is, why isn't anybody mentioning on how bad vanilla brightstone cove tsladora was? Like i genuinely got PTSD from those spiders coming at me from every direction whenever I went through that area or fought dukes dear Freya. But in scholar they fixed that, they actually made the torch have a passive effect where whenever you have it out lit on fire, it scares the spiders and keeps them away from you at all times. That was probably the main selling point for me when getting scholar cause fuck that cheap bullshit. Now, the Heide knights. I prefer the scholar's version on how they set it up where all of the Heide knights are in heide's tower of flame, but I can see why ppl like vanilla's use of them. If they're wandering knights, then yea makes sense why they're all over the place. But on the other hand, for an example. If you went to a specific place that's literally the home of a specific group of creatures/ppl and no form of those creatures/ppl are there, then it's a bit stupid. Like let's say someone said "hey, lets go to Japan, home of the Japanese!" And when you get there, you see every other race of ppl but see no Japanese ppl what so ever. I'm gonna have to fully disagree with you bud, IMO scholar was better. But I can see the argument where vanilla might be better for ppl.

snippet.textDisplay:
DS2 had good ideas, cool armour and weapons but was executed poorly

Soul memory - get 1 million and you can unlock the kings gate, issue is that soul memory also effects multiplayer 

Human effigy - ok thing but having health go down to 50% (excluding the hollow ring) from dying is BS

bonfire esthetic - actually a good thing that i wish was added to future titles

Ill be editing this when i can remember other things

Edit ⬇️

Fragrant branch of yore - i like this but there either isnt enough of them or when you use them, its most likely a 80/20 you're gonna waste it

Covenant of champions - nice idea of increasing enemy health and damage for more challenge but its BS that i have to join this covenant just so enemies dont despawn

snippet.textDisplay: Brilliant and i completely agree. I played DS2 forever back on PS3. It was the first Souls game i finished. Still remember dying over 100 times to the Pursuer before the Souls combat finally clicked with me. Is it a really uneven game? Yes. Is the viable build variety insane and only topped by Elden Ring? Also yes. Majula is not just one of my favorite locales in the Elden Blood Souls series, it is one of my favorite asthetic areas in gaming period. It feels even more dreamlike than the Hunter's Dream. Then everything changed when the Scholar edition attacked. What pisses me off the absolute most about Scholar is why not just include the vanilla setup as an option in game?! This is what Master Quest let you do. It's not like there wasn't space on the disc. Just idiotic to FORCE people to only play one way. I feel like some money grubber at Namco Bandai hired the janitor to do the remake and he studied top down maps of all the levels in DS2, shot each one with a shotgun and wherever the pellets went on the maps, he put an enemy there. And it's not really that much more difficult but it is WAY more time consuming.

snippet.textDisplay: Your hypothesis regarding fans of Scholar is far too speculative to treat as fact. And ultimately nothing you’ve said throughout this video is based in fact, it’s all defined by your subjective opinion on the game, and it’s players
snippet.textOriginal: Your hypothesis regarding fans of Scholar is far too speculative to treat as fact. And ultimately nothing you’ve said throughout this video is based in fact, it’s all defined by your subjective opinion on the game, and it’s players

snippet.textDisplay:
I firmly disagree with your title. Scholar improved upon the systems and balance of the game from a level design perspective.
Branches are not particularly hard to find, you just play the game. Does “this door does not open from this side” ring a bell? 
It’s just another locked door, find a different route, or find a key. 

Evaluate the potential consequences of your actions before you make a decision you can’t reverse. Play cautiously, patiently, or with npcs. Shake up your fucking strategy if your god damned broadsword misses so often. Fucking throw something at a dude if you can’t fight an entire army at once(shocker!). 

DS2 vanilla is trivial, scholar is forcing you to struggle and come up with an actual strategy or solution to your obstacles, which you seem to despise for some reason. Vanilla is EASY, scholar is a challenge, and that makes scholar the actual dark souls experience. These games aren’t hack and slash feel good experiences like god of war, for instance, you are meant to take your time, and the fact that you perceive your deaths and failure as a “waste” of your time is a you issue, it’s in your head. And you seem to be insistent on resorting to running away, which is never an appropriate solution to any encounter. Sure, you can get lucky, and if you keep hitting your head against that imaginary wall you might actually make it through any given gauntlet of enemies with some amount of consistency, but DS2 is not a game you “luck” your way through.
You also mentioned many things that are outright incorrect regarding changes from one to the other, which leads me to believe you desperately need some friends that understand this game in your life. The dragon skeleton in aldia’s does still animate in scholar. I can not for the life of me conceive of how you thought ancient dragon was your opponent, he is entirely optional ALWAYS. yes, vendrick is not meant to be killed when you first discover him. And Aldia’s fight is fun, in my personal opinion. You’re just obsessed with close melee dodge rolling builds. Adapt your strategy, and yes, USE A FUCKING BOW. You’re complaining about the challenges in front of you, but you’re not adapting your response to the challenges, just trying to muscle or race your way through it. These games are designed to push your buttons, but nothing in them is unbeatable, and that is what makes the games challenging yet fair. 

Please stop uploading lukewarm takes that highlight your ignorance of the subject in question

snippet.textDisplay: Personally, I found scholar to be one of my favorite games of all time, I’ve even gone back after elden ring, I do get that it’s very difficult and there’s a lot of enemies and it can feel unfair, but the thing is, you can SL1 this game, you can challenge run this game, I’ve done challenge runs, which means that there is a learning curve and a “fair” challenge so long as you can learn the world, and to me, the massive amounts of enemies in scholar, to me at least, actually made me feel like one person, tackling an entire kingdom by myself, that being said I actually felt that your criticism on dragnleic castle is actually not the right thing to be criticizing, not no much the lack of enemies but the general randomness, alone knights, desert pyromancer, Syan knight, executioner chariot, I felt thematically the emptiness made sense personally, but the enemy composition is so random and weird, same thing with ancient dragon for me, it’s frustrating as hell, but again, I feel like I’m a human who decided to try and kill a dragon, a monster that killed “3 score” according to ds3 silver knights per dragon killed, so yeah, they’re supposed to be insanely powerful, and therefore I really actually don’t mind, but I also understand that it’s a personal, and niche opinion at that, also the aldia’s keep dragon has to be brought to life, 100% the original was cooler, and the 1 mil soul skip does work, speed runners ascetic the rotten pretty often to do it, but awesome video! I love this game and anything to get people talking ab it (and maybe playing it) again is good stuff

snippet.textDisplay: Scholar makes me appreciate how well Fromsoft do with difficultly and balance in their other games (for the most part!). All of the games are hard and have scenarios where the player is disadvantaged or ganked, but they give you tools, opportunities or paths that can help level the playing field a bit whilst still maintaining a difficult challenge and rewarding patience and learning the game and the level. Scholar just feels like a shitty player made mod where the creator just assumes more enemies placed willy-nilly equals more fun. I wish I still had my copy of vanilla :(
snippet.textOriginal: Scholar makes me appreciate how well Fromsoft do with difficultly and balance in their other games (for the most part!). All of the games are hard and have scenarios where the player is disadvantaged or ganked, but they give you tools, opportunities or paths that can help level the playing field a bit whilst still maintaining a difficult challenge and rewarding patience and learning the game and the level. snippet.textDisplay:
I made a comment response video: https://youtu.be/rR-a3zIOE2w

Apparently the ps3 and xbox360 versions of Scholar did not change the enemy placement, so this video doesn't apply to those versions.

2 things to correct in the video:
1: Scholar did not get rid of the 1 million souls skip to get to Drangleic Castle. I thought that I had heard this from another Dark Souls 2 video essay, but I was wrong.
2: The dragon skeleton in Aldia's Keep can come alive in Scholar, but you have to light some torches so it's hidden away and I still prefer how Vanilla handled it to Scholar.

Also, the comments have told me that Shrine of Amana was nerfed into the ground after release, so that's probably part of the reason why I liked it in Vanilla while other people hated it.

I finally decided to make the "In Defense of Dark Souls 2 video" unlisted because it had too many mistakes. You can still watch it with this link.
https://youtu.be/2A6s_Wq-6PU

snippet.textDisplay:
"... not sure if the developers want me to clear an area or run past enemies"  99% of souls the answer is the devs want/expect you to clear the area.   A lot of those ganks you saw only happened because you weren't killing enemies as you went.  Boss runs are one thing, but generally you kill your way from bonfire to bonfire.

That said... I've only played Scholar, but it sounds very much that vanilla is way more tolerable.  I wish we had a 64bit version of vanilla, or a mod for scholar that restored vanilla enemy placements.
snippet.textOriginal:
"... not sure if the developers want me to clear an area or run past enemies"  99% of souls the answer is the devs want/expect you to clear the area.   A lot of those ganks you saw only happened because you weren't killing enemies as you went.  Boss runs are one thing, but generally you kill your way from bonfire to bonfire.

That said... I've only played Scholar, but it sounds very much that vanilla is way more tolerable.  I wish we had a 64bit version of vanilla, or a mod for scholar that restored vanilla enemy placements.

snippet.textDisplay: I played Scholar for my first playthrough of DS2, and while I realize it's objectively not as good as the other souls games, I loved my time with the game. It still gave me trouble, just like the others, but there are some things that I thought were super cheap, such as not being able to run past enemies because all 30 enemies in an area chase you and never stop, as well as no i-frames opening doors and going through fog gates. But apart from other nitpicky stuff, I loved the game, and can't wait to play it again.
snippet.textOriginal: I played Scholar for my first playthrough of DS2, and while I realize it's objectively not as good as the other souls games, I loved my time with the game. It still gave me trouble, just like the others, but there are some things that I thought were super cheap, such as not being able to run past enemies because all 30 enemies in an area chase you and never stop, as well as no i-frames opening doors and going through fog gates. But apart from other nitpicky stuff, I loved the game, and can't wait to play it again.

snippet.textDisplay:
So basically you say that the other games are easier than dark souls 2, because there you can run through all the enemies and they didn't care about the player's presence in the scenario, sorry but I totally disagree with this argument, this change in AI of DS2 is one of the best points of the game because in fact it is a challenge and not multiple enemies launching random blows with the intention of killing you, it has several invading and summoned NPCs, which have AI equivalent to real players and this is fabulous, it's more than of course to get around this the main bosses of the game are relatively easy because the way to them is the real challenge, the completely optional areas are usually more difficult because there are many enemies that require you to use the game's gigantic arsenal of weapons, I don't know how Haven't you noticed yet that the 200 deaths on the counter are because you're wearing a straight sword and clothes that barely defend the attacks of hollows at the beginning of the game? spam R1 with straight sword is not the best weapon for anything, you said you prefer the DS1 bosses because the fights involve more strategies but you don't want to use bows in iron keep ? where is the use of strategies now ? honestly I'd rather pay full price on a version that actually makes changes both in scenarios with enemy repositioning and in better graphics, than paying for a higher resolution remaster.
The vanilla version is not bad, everything that DS2 does best is still there, with build variations, multiple scenarios, balanced spells, etc. especially after patch 1.10, I recommend for those who only tried it SOTFS, Aldia and forlorn were the additions that I liked this version, but vanilla is by no means better than this definitive version for me

I think the biggest point I disagree with this video is the comparison of master mod and scholar. OG Dark Souls 2 already has its own master mode, it's called New game plus. New game plus adds a lot of stuff which significatly changes the early areas of Dark Souls 2. Heide and Duke's is the best example of this considering the added enemies specifically phantoms and an added boss phase for Dear Freia

A better difficulty comparison you would know is Skyrim Lengendary difficulty

snippet.textDisplay:
SotFS was my entry into souls and while I was deeply tilted by some of the previous points you made in the defense video, I'm acknowledging my own emotions. Upon reflection, perhaps what SotFS did was not far from abuse and my drive for mastering all the areas (Frigid Outskirts excepted) was nothing more than conditioning from the years of neglect I have suffered. Is this why I still enjoy the bullet-hell gank invasion system of Elden Ring? Despite fights usually being the same repeat of edgy t-bagging screechers who freak out when their level x00 summon dies, am I now trying to conquer the same sense of challenge and absolute bullshitfuckery that SotFS belted us with?

Thank you for your thoughts FK, dont go hollow

snippet.textDisplay:
There's no validity to your position, because all of your arguments can be applied to all other Souls games. 

First off, You can spot almost every enemy that ambushes you, beforehand. It's a lesson you would have learned, had you not, noob sprinted through the entire game. 

You can skip areas in any dark souls games by running past the enemies, Leaving you underleveled.  Thats not just a SOTFS problem. 

You commited the grave sin of enemy skipping.... which, in essence, teaches you the mechanics of the game, and you have the balls to critique it? 

You can get ganked in every single scenario, if you dont prioritize removing certain enemies. You didn't learn that, because again, you noob sprinted. 

I can appreciate that you don't enjoy SOTFS. That's fair. 

But don't critique a game, that you cheesed by sprinting through, using knowledge received from your previous playthrough. 

Here's an example:

This was like playing Halo: Anniversary on legendary, immediately after playing Halo: Combat evolved on heroic. 

The enemies are barely harder, but instead of adapting, You chose to run past everything... and then called it trash. 

I think you were just bored and wrote  a critique out of frustration.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have to disagree about one point here.  Vanilla did not cause me to level more and become stronger.  I ALWAYS kill all enemies in any game I play so Scholar leveled me a lot more and as such the "harder" areas didn't actually feel very hard to me because I had tons of levels.  Vanilla on the other hand, having less enemies and also in some places weaker enemies meant I had way less souls throughout my Vanilla playthrough and that made the bosses feel a lot more punishing which felt way worse.

Also you can absolutely still skip the lord soul bosses with enough souls in Scholar, I've opened the door early plenty of times.

And the big skeletal dragon also still comes to life and attacks, only it's got a different trigger.  To do it in Scholar you need to light all the torches in the level and kill the invaders that lighting them spawns.  I'll admit though that this trigger change is terrible, but it is still there unlike what you said.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have played Scholar and the original. And Scholar is better. In my opinion, it is the definitive edition of Dark Souls 2. You and I can agree to disagree I hope.

Do not get me wrong. I 100% respect your opinion. I watched the entire video and I see your point. Additionally, you used Hollow Knight music, so extra respect there. I understand you prefer the original and why you do and I respect it totally. With that out of the way…

Firstly, some things I agree with:

- The removal of Heide Knights from basically everywhere and stuffing them all into Heide’s Tower of Flame was a negative change.

- Iron Keep. That’s all.

- I agree that the runs in the co-op content in the DLC are overtuned bullshit (however do not forget that they are optional and intended to played in co-op).

- Hbomberguy’s DS2 video is plainly not all that great, regardless of his opinions on the game a lot of points he makes in his attempt to justify why he thinks DS2 is a better game than the first make zero sense or are just straight up wrong. I like Hbomberguy but this and his Bloodborne video are awful and you have every right to rip on them, because they suck.

Some things I disagree with:

- Vanilla Dark Souls 2’s enemy placements feel mostly random and strange and many levels feel unfinished. There are many areas in the vanilla Dark Souls 2 levels that feel barren of enemies and generally unfinished. 

- Archers in Scholar are mostly well placed and are overall a positive addition in my opinion. They add extra challenge and put a lot of pressure onto the player. They encourage you to tackle enemy encounters in different ways rather than just charging in there and killing all the enemies like you do the whole game in Vanilla. For example, luring enemies to cover where archers cannot hit you so you can fight them fairly. 

- The difficulty curve is fixed in Scholar (for the most part, because Iron Keep exists). In vanilla, the game is far too easy for the entire first half of the game and hardly increases in difficulty. Once you reach Drangleic Castle, the difficulty spike is enormous. However, the game then gets easier and easier until the end of the game which is piss easy by that point. In Scholar, the game starts off fair but not too easy or too challenging, and Drangleic Castle is harder than your average Lord soul path (emphasis on average, because Iron Keep) but isn’t a gigantic difficulty spike like in the original. The game then peaks in difficulty at the endgame in Shrine of Amana and the Giant Memories, like these types of games should, which is unlike the original where the game just gets easier from Shrine of Amana to Aldia’s Keep to Dragon Shrine to the Giant Memories. 

- Dark Souls 1 is indeed infinitely better than both versions of its sequel, but the diversity of the locations in Dark Souls 2 is part of what makes the game unique when compared to the other Fromsoft titles. There are countless breathtaking shots and locales in Dark Souls 2 and it has its own unique feel from 1 with its colorful pallet, in direct contrast to Dark Souls 3 which is all drab and gray and the locations are mostly your standard dark fantasy RPG (I do not prefer DS2 to 3, and the drab colors of DS3 is by no means a bad thing, I am just using it for comparison to DS2). In DS2, you go from Forest of Fallen Giants to Heide’s Tower of Flame to No Mans Wharf to Lost Bastille, all visually distinct, interesting and unique. In DS3, you go from boring cemetery to boring castle wall to boring Bloodborne village to boring forest to boring swamp to boring cemetery, and the locations don’t get interesting and unique until the Cathedral, Smouldering Lake and Irithyll. The diversity and unpredictabliltiy of the locations in DS2 is part of what makes the game special and gives it its own identity. I personally love this about DS2 but you are free to disagree. (Note: this is in response to what you said about the DS2 locations and is not a comment on your comparison between DS1 and 2, since I mostly agree with that)

One thing I REALLY disagree with: 

- Scholar is by no means a cash grab. Vanilla was broken and unfinished and Scholar fixed it. Enemy placements make more sense and the game is a big visual improvement. The game is also the same price as the vanilla but has all the DLC included.

And, now for the obvious:

- Skill issue. You have a skill issue. You approached every fight with a basic mindset and called bullshit when you saw yourself getting ganked by a dozen enemies while an archer shoots at you without thinking about what you could do to give yourself the advantage. You then lost your patience and ran through the rest of the game, including the DLC, because you had a skill issue and couldn’t be bothered with the game. The DLC is not better in vanilla, nor is it better in Scholar, because they are exactly the same. You getting mad at the game and losing your motivation to play it thus running past the DLC is a result of your own incompetence and skill issue. DS2 is not the same game as DS1 and 3. You were not taught to run past enemies by Scholar. You taught that to yourself because you grew impatient and dismissed every enemy encounter you felt was unfair as bullshit and ran past it. Dark Souls 2 Scholar of the First Sin is a very fun game when you approach it with the right mindset. 

Some things you said that are objectively wrong or invalid:

- You do not need to fight Ancient Dragon to fight Aldia. Also Vendrick is indeed awful but even with 1 giant soul missing he still does not take that long to kill.

- The petrified statue that blocks a path to the ‘cool dragon level’ does not have to be broken. You can take an alternate path to access the level.

- The changes to enemy placement in Scholar are not as simple as ‘minus enemies in mid game to make that easier and massive surplus of enemies everywhere else’.

- The skeleton dragon in Aldia’s Keep does still come to life, you just have to do some stuff in the area beforehand now.

And lastly for the even more obvious, Scholar is a big graphical improvement and runs at twice the frame rate, can’t forget to mention that. 

In conclusion, Scholar of the First Sin doesn’t change things in ways that make no sense, it changes things in ways that do make sense, and that’s where you and I can (hopefullly) agree to disagree.

snippet.textDisplay:
About the skeletal dragon, that cutscene thing still happens in scholar. But, you need to light 4 torches in the area and kill 4 forlorn invaders that spawn after lighting them. Then you need to be in human form and then AND ONLY THEN it happens. Like what is even the point of doing that. The only thing you get from it is a key that nets you some items absolutely not worth the hassle.

Also fuck scholar for adding more of those fragrant branches of yore. They essentially doubled the amount of branches you have to get. Take shaded woods as an example. After the last bonfire, there were only 3 statues, of which one unlocked ornifex and the other 2 had some goodies behind them. This is imo already much, as branches are pretty rare and using 3 of them early/mid game is quite the sacrifice. And then scholar doubled the amount of statues in that area. 

The worst statue they placed has to be in dragons aerie though. In scholar it was one of the best main game areas for me (which says a lot), but I didn't reach it until my 4th playthrough of the game. I legitimately thought it was a small area with some items behind that statue. Scholar never seizes to amaze me with the amount of stupidity they added.

snippet.textDisplay:
19:24 Undead dragon comes to life, I managed to trigger him, I don't know how. Dragon level is not locked, this petrified statue is an optional shortcut. Almost all blocked paths in Scholar have an alternative path, so you have the option to save your branch and unlock optional areas or unlock the shortcuts. The one occasion that you really need a branch is to use it on Rosabeth. I can say the same thing for hidden paths in DS1, you have to hit every wall, like you have OCD (Great Fun). or you are probably going to miss out a great amount of hidden content in your first blind play through.

For me, vanilla felt boring having played Scholar first. And over all Scholar is not a bad DS game either, because it manages to get people into DS, just like my experience. I like Souls-like games, started with The Surge, but I wasn't got into DS franchise until I tried Scholar (because of its level structure reminds me that of Hellpoint). If Scholar was bad, I would never touch another DS game,

PS: As for Heide knights, it's the freaking heide's Tower of Flame.

Edited: Your suggestion is an inferior and unfinished game, a DS walking simulator, instead of what the game should be at its release. FYI Heide's Tower area has only 7 statues to fight in vanilla, the whole area feels empty.

You neglected on purpose to compare areas in first DS which are as annoying and bad as Iron Keep or (in your opinion) no man's wharf. Areas like: 
- New Londo ruins (ghost through walls and ceiling) 
- Duke's archives (archers and casters in hallways!) 
- Blight Town (where did this gang come from? / Poisoned all the time fun) 
-Tomb of Giants (gangbanged in the the dark) 
- and Crystal caves. 
Same goes with uninteresting or unfair boss fights like:
- Capra Demon (First strike everytime) 
- Ceaseless Discharge (that I actually fought in my first playthough) 
- Moonlight Butterfly (OK let's wait it to sit down)
- Iron Golem (Timbeeeer) 
- FREAKING PINWEEL (that 4 seconds fight was a boss?)!, 
- Seath (First time you are dead/ second time look I'm behind you can't touch me na na na na) 
- Four (and a half) Kings 
- and last but not least Bed of Chaos (ladies and gentlemen roll the dice). 
For a game with 1/5 of the content DS2 has, what a masterpiece that is.

snippet.textDisplay:
I agree with several of your points. The only area I believe your critique may be skewed is when you talk about enemy placement in scholar feeding a negative feedback loop. I dont think the intention of FromSoft (or any developer) is to create content with the hopes of you running by it blindly. I just finished a 100 hour playthrough of SOTFS and will admit, it was definitely more challenging than vanilla, but it did not feel intentionally unfair. I was over-leveled as a result of the challenge and constant enemy killing.

 In most cases the SOTFS ganks can be avoided with observation and utilization of consumables and weapons. SOTFS definitely taught me to appreciate the alternate pathing of ds2 as well as the vast amount of items and resources.  

Lastly, a game’s worth or critical assessment should never be validated off one’s own self-imposed challenges-ie “broadsword only runs”. These self imposed challenges or viewpoints of what makes a “worthwhile” play through” hold no pertinence to a games overall ability to convey, play, and express a story.

snippet.textDisplay:
Im not gonna lie: I've watched your Dark Souls 2 Video series now and I've always wondered why you had such a bad time with this game. Especially since I didn't remember all the enemy spam (which made the argument "you triggered all the enemy spam on purpose" sound believable, even though I myself couldn't remember any) But after taking a look in my Steam library I noted that I played nearly 300h of DS2 Vanilla  (little to no PVP actually, mostly PVE, NG+ and different builds) while I only played around 40h of SotfS. Then I remembered: I ragequit DS2 Sotfs (and consequently DS2 Vanilla) because the re-release was so fucking hot garbage. Even after playing 300h of Vanilla DS2 I didn't manage to finish Sotfs!

And with that in mind your experience makes total sense now.
DS2 Vanilla is not without its flaws and I know that. And I still had a blast playing DS2 Vanilla back when it released. But I nearly instantly quit playing the Sotfs Edition because it WASNT FUN. And I really can't be mad at someone hating on DS2 if the Sotfs is the first version they play. It broke me, a DS veteran, after a week of playing. Add all the issues DS2 Vanilla has on top and the game is actually not worth playing. 

So after watching the video I agree with you. I'm glad you found DS2 actually enjoyable. Im happy the mystery of why there are so many DS2-defenders out there is solved. They probably played the vanilla version on release, kept the good memories and never touched sotfs. 
Personally I would rate DS2 a 6.5/10 or 7/10. Not perfect but definitely something you can have fun with.

I hate this game so much, I hate everything about it, the gameplay, the setting, the graphics, the enemies, the boss fights

Yet I watch everything about it. I hate it so much that it turns into appreciation for the people that worked on this game and made it out of passion and commitment to an incredible series of games. The fact that I hate this game is enough to nake me see that it has it's own personality and I can understand how people can love it.

snippet.textDisplay: 1. The community hated DS 2 because it was deemed as too easy. 2. Shrine of Amana is a beautiful area, you can chose to go melee or ranged, hard way or easy. 3. Iron keep is not difficult, maybe if you do a speed run, but play the game as most people do, it's a challenge but not difficult. 4. Dark Souls 2 has a ton of invisible doors, which makes it fun to explore in depth. 5. The vanilla game was also changed, enemy placement and the final boss room addition, after the Scholar, and thus Scholar is just a more pretty version of Dark Souls 2. 6. PVP was more fun, cause a kind of chivalry spirit persisted in pvp. 7. Dark Souls 2 is a unique game, and should not be compared to DS 1 and 3. 8. People who hate Dark Souls 2 are probably copycats, influenced by youtube videos, and in this way, have an opinion before they start the game. 9. I don't think the game is too slow, in comparison, the Beast Clergyman in Elden Ring is way too fast, you don't have a fighting chance to think, prepare or heal. 10. Never run past enemies in your first playthrough. If you do, you will never understand or learn the game. Have fun playing Dark Souls 2, and don't listen to shallow Youtubers, who are too lazy to play the game in depth.

Here's a like, agreed with every word and I'm really glad you made this video. Title says it all 👌I hope people who haven't played this yet but at some point will want to after Elden Ring take this video to heart.

And I say every word but I guess there's one I didn't agree with. Playing vanilla several times over first didn't make me like scholar better at all. It just turned a game I love into something I find insufferable. I can't understand why anyone would say otherwise it's like you said, objectively worse with every change.

And I say love, but when I played it I have always lamented the sorry state of most of these bosses and the way the world is layed out, even the first time around. It's just that that didn't stop me from enjoying the game and wanting to replay it immediately. Which resulted in my beloved Mountain King character, (going for the great club and havels leggins and gauntlets right from the start) a build which has found it's way into (re)playthroughs of all games since that playthrough. Much to be thankful for in my case.

snippet.textDisplay:
I exclusively played Vanilla, from 2015-22. Played it all the time. It’s been a source of constant frustration that DS2 gets almost wholly judged on Scholar edition.  

Finally, my PS3 died, so I got Scholar on PS4. Beat it with 14 deaths. Playing Scholar , finally,  simple reinforced my thoughts about it , after having watched it streamed many times. Vanilla is the superior single-player first playthrough experience.  Vanilla gives you a great balance between exploration and combat. 

Scholar is better suited as a co-op experience. Scholar wants to fill all your holes. Pretty much every area Vanilla leaves open for exploration, Scholar adds enemies there. It should be noted that Scholar lets there be 3 summons, instead of Vanilla’s 2. 

Something worth mentioning is how very different item placement is. Vanilla has a much more difficult item placement. The Dull Ember is in Iron Keep. The Bastille key is after Gargoyles. Uber weapons  like Grand Lance, Staff of Wisdom, or Dragons Tooth, are very late game. Many armor sets were very difficult to obtain in Vanilla, like The Armor of Aurous, Warlocks Mask, and Heides set. 

A couple notes. I use lock on. Works great. Not sure why there’s been a recurring emphasis in these videos that no lock on is necessary. 

Lifegems are not a band aid. Another recurring complaint. They’re the grasses, from Demons Souls. There’s a ton of Demons DNA in DS2. Like reducing max hp after dying. Lifegems are a functionally different way of healing. And serve to compliment the way Estus works differently.  In combat, do you stay mobile, and get a small, slow heal, or plant yourself for a big chug? 

I frames tied to a stat is functionally no different than tied to a roll type, except for naked pro players. And it’s more interesting, bc not every game starts with access to the best roll, before even taking a step, by getting naked. 

Hit boxes are fine. Level iframes, and they’re no worse than other souls. Players are confusing what looks like a fast roll and should have iframes, but doesn’t, as a bad hitbox. Level iframes, and you’ll roll just fine. 

Bosses should be judged against other souls bosses after ng+, at least. To understand why, you need to understand how Bonfire Ascetics work. Basically, the devs wanted to encourage players to use this genius new consumable. To do so, they didn’t act like other souls, and make the bosses give you all you can handle. If they made them too tough, players would never use a incredibly powerful and fun item. From my experience, bosses in ng+ use more rare attacks, punish healing and ranged better, and more follow up swings on combos. You can definitely see the AI stepping up its game. But if it was like that during the first try, far fewer players would interact with the game using Bonfire ascetics. 

DS1 has a great map before Anor Londo. A masterpiece. No other game compares. But from Anor Londo on, nothing special. I’m sick and tired of hearing how great DS1’s map is, bc only a portion is. DS2’s map is Demons Souls inspired. A hub, with spokes. Fun fact- you can walk everywhere, except to Lost Bastille, in DS2. 

Not every weapon has a guaranteed combo. You’ll have to react to the times when the enemy is out of range for the second hit. Like the Mace, sometimes you need to do the heavy instead of the second light, bc the enemy was pushed back. If a true combo weapon is that goddamn important to you, pick something else that does that. There’s plenty to choose from. 


Story is a personal thing. Both games have their merits, narrative-wise. Personally, i like the agency DS2 gives the player, to make a decision, instead of a pawn in the lord’s power-struggle. 

One thing I feel like mentioning is that I never cared to replay DS1 in ng+. Not once. But i have multiple high ng+ cycles characters in DS2. The game makes real changes to the world, not just in ng+, but for every one of the next 6 cycles. Plus, you can reallocate levels, and try new builds, or weapons. DS1 felt suffocating in that way. Want to be a Wizard after awhile, but have been a big bonk build? In DS1, that means start over. 

DS2’s PvP and invasions are the best in the series. DS1 requires a PhD in glitches, and DS3 is roll-spam wars of attrition. DS2 is the sweetspot. That alone is going to keep DS2 forever in the limelight. 



Is DS2 perfect? Hardly.

snippet.textDisplay: Elden ring really took dark souls 2 as a prototype. Technically it is possible to beat the game with a two handing broadsword, but the game[s] give you a lot of tools. 4 different schools of magic (where pyromancy still requires only attunement slots), bows/cross bows with ammo for every element and power stancing. I only played scholar and never played vanilla, but in scholar there are a lot summonable npcs if you need that help (mostly for bosses, but there are bonfire summons that will help you clear the area) if you want that kinda help.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think I qualify as one of the people who played vanilla first and now holds that Scholar is superior. I think you sort of gloss over very quickly the amount Shrine of Amana was nerfed in vanilla. The degree it went down was larger than even Radhan was in the first Elden Ring patch. 

For me I played vanilla twice through on release on Xbox 360. Really didn't enjoy it, so I didn't buy any dlc past the Sunken King. I didn't buy Scholar until 2019 on PS4, and had largely accepted DS2 for what it was. Knowing the games to come after DS2 I'd end up liking much much more. So jumping back into Scholar I just felt like I was ready to accept and like DS2 for what it was. 

And the fact that the final 2 DLC's were essentially brand new to me and are some of the best parts of the game. Including Fume Knight etc. 

Which left me not remembering that vanilla actually had less enemies in certain areas. And when I saw those inflated enemy counts in Scholar, I was able to just accept it because "well I know ds2 is full of enemy spam. At least scholar made these sweet new areas"

And the fact that for me I played Scholar on PS4 vs an Xbox 360 I'd say is an underrated aspect. To just have that much smoother of an experience.

snippet.textDisplay: I just beat this game the other day for the first time. I never played a souls game before Elden Ring and because of that masterpiece i went on this journey. Dark souls 1 blew me away, the level design is some of the best I’ve ever seen. Absolutely loved everything g about it. But I was so excited for DS2 because I’ve heard all the shit about it. If anyone was gonna love DS2 it was gonna be me my expectations were low but my excitement high. I was gonna be happy even if it was a 6/7 out of 10. Once I reached No Mans Wharf I said wow this has got to be the worst area of Dark souls history I couldn’t believe it.  Little did I know it was only the beginning of a downward spiral of absolute hell. I still don’t know what to think of DS2. A horribly designed game but I can’t forget the journey I went on. I’ll never forget the struggles and rage I went through. I’m on DS3 right now and everything I struggle and every time I look out my window and think about diving through it to put me out of my misery, I remember DS2 and I relax, I can beat this shit.

I’ll never forget the struggles and rage I went through. I’m on DS3 right now and everything I struggle and every time I look out my window and think about diving through it to put me out of my misery, I remember DS2 and I relax, I can beat this shit.
